title: mystery digger driver sacks kent building site
story: Workers were carrying out drainage work in Whitstable when they struck upon two black, rubble sack-type bag two metres underground.Someones obviously dug them up from somewhere  and then buried them here. They could be from anywhere.Mr Dawkins believes pieces of skulls, leg and arm bones were among the findings on the construction site, where nine houses and eight flats are due to be built.Examining a photograph of the bones, which are brown in colour, Canterbury Archaeological Trust’s outreach and archives manager, Andrew Richardson, confirmed the remains were from multiple people.“There are quite a few bones there - we think at least four iniduals based on the number of long bones, perhaps more,” he told Kent Online.“These bones have been in the ground for some time,” he added.“How long is hard to say. Based on their colour and fragmentary nature, I’d say that it is probable that these represent older burials disturbed and reburied, perhaps during building works.They may have originally been found on the Days Garage site, but they could just have easily have been disturbed where and reburied there.A source at the site previously told Kent Live the bones could be from as many as six people.Kent Police are looking into the age of the bones but have not yet opened a criminal investigation after the discovery on January .Spokeswoman Natalie Hardy said: “A number of bones were found in one small area of the site in Shaftesbury Road, which has been undergoing excavation work for the past six months.“Experts confirmed the bones are human and are now working to establish their age. This process could take several weeks.“No further bones have been found at the site despite further excavation as a result of this discovery.Enquiries remain ongoing and officers will review whether any further action needs to be taken in due course.”This isnt the first time suspected human bones have been found in unexpected places.In , human remains were believed to have been discovered in an Aldi carpark, previously home to a former burial ground.While last year outraged locals in Bristol called the cops twice after finding suspected human bones in a rubbish skip.

title: business secretary greg clark nissan sunderland
story: The Japanese car giant went back on a post-Brexit pledge to make its next-generation X-Trail diesel motor at the flagship plant.No jobs will go as a result of yesterday’s decision.And Nissan insisted that - separately - production on a new Qashqai would begin as expected in .But Tory MPs admitted the decision was a setback for No  given Nissan’s pledge in late  was hailed as vindication of Theresa May’s Brexit vision.In a statement yesterday, Mr Clark said: “Nissan’s announcement is a blow to the sector and the region, as this was to be a further signicant expansion of the site and the workforce.”Unions and Labour warned the PM that more investment would leave Britain unless the PM took the threat of a No Deal off the table.In a message to staff yesterday Nissan chairman Gianluca de Ficchy said “business reasons” lay behind the company’s decision.But he added: “Clearly the uncertainty around the UK’s future relationship with the EU is not helping companies like ours to plan for the future.”Eurosceptic Tory Jacob Rees-Mogg said he believed this was a “fake issue” and the collapse of the diesel market was the main driver for Nissan’s u-turn.Nissan was due to announce its decision later on Monday but the news leaked after Nissan informed Greg Clark on Friday.The X-Trail is already made in Japan and the US.Ex-Nissan boss Carlos Ghosn decided to use Sunderland for the car in late  after seeking assurances on Britain’s Brexit plan. At the time, the PM labelled the decision “fantastic news”.Mr Ghosn is now languishing in a Toyko jail on allegations of tax evasion and financial irregularities.Japan’s free-trade deal with the EU – which will gradually lower tarfs on car imports from the Far-East- came into force last week.Car sales in the UK plunged  per cent to a five year low in . Diesel made up less than a third of the total – two years after parity with petrol cars.Unite acting national officer Steve Bush said: “The government’s mishandling of the transition away from diesel - allied to the continuing uncertainty around our future trading relationship with the EU - are extremely unhelpful.”Treasury minister Liz Truss dismissed claims that Nissan’s decision was as a result of Brexit.She said: “This is everything that is normal, that happens.“Speculation about industry has been pushed into the Brexit story. I don’t think that is fair.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: 9 excuses tory candidate shaun
story: NewsAnalysis excuses Tory candidate Shaun Bailey gave for his comments about womenHeres all the ways Mr Bailey gave to explain away saying good looking girls "tend to have been around" and single mums are not "acceptable".ShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAnalysisthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video tory-london-mayoral-candidate-shaun-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailShaun Bailey is the Conservative Partys candidate for Mayor of London - and he is perhaps most famous for having made a number of inflammatory comments about women. This morning, during an increasingly awkward interview with Sky News Sophy Ridge, he was confronted with two of them.Mr Bailey, who in December was polling a stonking  points behind Sadiq Khan , does not have the luxury of being able to blame youth for the unfortunate remarks - he was  when he made them.But in a few short minutes he found and delivered a dazzling array of reasons to defend them. Heres the comments he was defending - and a full list of the excuses he gave. Statement : Good looking women tend to have been around  In a pamphlet for the Centre for Policy Studies think tank in , he wrote about his experience with sex education as a youth worker. He wrote: The boys have got this opinion thata girl looks clean, and that generally means she’s good looking, she appeals to them, it is less likely she’ll have an infection” He went on to say that when he talked to teenagers, he would warn them: If a girl appeals to one that way, she’ll appeal to all of them. She’ll tend to have been around. It wasnt mentioned in the interview, but he went on to complain about condoms, which prevent sexually transmitted infections, being handed out to teenagers in schools, because it makes sex more possible. Heres some of the excuses he gave for that one.   . I didnt say that So two things, I never actually said that... He did. Its here. . ...It was a conversation ...that is me having a conversation with someone.Oh, you did say it  Glad we got that cleared up.. I was talking to poor people But let’s be clear, I’m talking about a very poor community facing very tough outcomes.It is unclear why talking to poor people rather than better off people changes the character of his comments.. I was mythbusting That’s about mythbusting, because we’re talking about boys who live in a very sexualised environment. It’s traded as a way of being popular or not.It is unclear why it is better to replace a myth that people are likely to be free of infection with a myth that attractive people are likely to be promiscuous.. Did I mention they were poor  And as I said, you’re talking about the poorest communities, and dealing with the toughest issues. It’s people like me who are on the front line having those conversations.Again, it is unclear why characterising attractive women as promiscuous is more appropriate based on the wealth of who youre talking to.. What do you think youth workers are doing  What makes me laugh about your slick, career politicians who run around saying nice things about communities, they always talk about youth work. What do they think youth workers are doing  What kind of conversations do they think were having that other people won’t have with young people Many, we imagine, would hope that youth workers are not talking about young women in that manner.  . It wasnt the smoothest language Of course, was it the smoothest language  Of course not. Andanybody’s thinking ‘why did he say that ’ Remember, you’re talking about - years ago, when I was faced with young people who are being stabbed, murdered and all kinds of things - the language isn’t the smoothest, but I’m not sitting at home thinking ‘what will look good on Sky ’ - I’m thinking how can I get across to these people Mr Baileys team has previously dismissed this particular comment as raw, blunt and the work of a man who hasn’t figured it all out. Mr Bailey now appears to be saying that the sentiment was fine, but the language was the problem.. You have to mirror the language young people are using And of course, young people I’m speaking to, I’m having to mirror the language they’re using.OK.Statement : Single mums are unacceptable, or at least undesirable  In a  article for the , Mr Bailey explained the reason our streets are so violent - and gave an account of his time growing up in London. He wrote: Many of the first single mums were housed in my part of London, reassuring them that it was acceptable - even desirable - for mothers to have babies on their own. That assumption is flawed because we now know that a child growing up without a father is so much more likely to be disadvantaged. Again, its not brought up in the interview, but he goes on to suggest women deliberately become pregnant in order to claim benefits. He wrote: For example, any young girl living in the inner city will be clued up on how the system works. They wont be too careful about not becoming parents. In some cases, they will deliberately become pregnant - as they know thatthey do, they will get a flat.So has he changed his view . Poor people make themselves vulnerable to get benefits We had a system, and in many ways we still do now, which encourages poor communities to make themselves vulnerable in order to receive benefits or be supported.No. No, he hasnt changed his view.

title: brave woman jumps freezing lake
story: NewsBrave woman jumps into freezing lake and swims  metres to rescue drowning dogThe woman amazed bystanders as she leaped into icy waters at Hulls East Park and saved the white bulldog-type breedShareCommentsByTom Kershaw:,  FEB NewsThe woman risked her le to save a dog from a freezing lake "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman risked her own le and jumped into a frozen lake to save a drowning dog. The hero plunged into the icy water at swam  metres at Hulls East Park in a bid to save the struggling canine on Sunday. Bystanders say the woman - who has not been identied - had to break chunks of ice on the water before she came to the dogs rescue at around noon. It is understood she undertook the daring rescue after the white bulldog-cross was seen bobbing up and down in the water. The dog belonged to an elderly man who was seen looking for his pet, HullLive reported. An eyewitness said: I think an old gentlemen lost his dog and it had jumped in the lake and couldnt get back out.  The dog became really distressed, the water must have been very cold and freezing. A woman then came along, broke the ice in front of her and jumped in. She swam  metres out into the middle of the lake and then brought the dog back with her. I heard all the commotion, looked over and just got in the water and broke the ice to get to the dog. The woman has been hailed as a hero by eyewitnesses after she braved the plummeting temperatures to rescue the hound. Members of the public stepped in and wrapped her in blankets when she emerged from the water.  The dog, which emerged unscathed, made its way onto the verge and shook itself dry. One onlooker said: At one time I thought she was going under, but she managed to get out of the water. She was very brave. She struggled at one point, but got to the dog and back in the end. She did really well, it was amazing.

story: NewsCadburys rivals get green light to use iconic purple colour on sweet wrappersNestle said the wording of Cadburys -year-old trademark for the colour was too wide-rangingShareCommentsByNadeem Badshah:,  FEB NewsNestle feared that Cadbury’s claim could threaten its Quality Street hazelnut and caramel treat"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailRivals could start using Cadbury’s iconic purple on their sweet wrappers after a choc legal ruling. The confectionery giant tried to update its -year-old trademark for the colour last year after Nestle said its wording was too wide-ranging. Nestle feared that Cadbury’s claim could threaten its Quality Street hazelnut and carshyshyamel treat – the Purple One – and its decoration on the box. Cadbury has now surrendered its  registration for exclusive use after the Court of Appeal backed its Swiss rival.   Cadbury’s Dairy Milk bars have been wrapped in purple for over  years and it was chosen because it was Queen Victoria’s favourite colour. Trademark lawyer Rebecca Anderson-Smith said the case was “bad news” for the firm, adding: “It seems Cadbury realised their existing trademark registration would be dficult,not impossible, to enforce.   They still own a separate registration for that purple, covering ‘chocolate in bar or tablet form’.But this includes the same description of the mark considered too broad by the Court of Appeal.” Cadbury’s US owner, Mondelez, said: “We have not appealed but will continue to protect what we believe is a distinctive trademark.” Nestle hinted at further action because products like Quality Street “famously use purple”.

And he was delighted it cleared the final hurdle in the Lords on Friday. “It is shybrilliant news, fantastic,” he said. “I am so glad it passed.”   The law is due to come into force next year and will mean everyone is presumed to be an organ donor unless they opt out. story: NewsMan lives in converted horse box with dog and parrot after accident left him unable to workStephen James, , has equipped the £, trailer with TVs, an oven, sink, microwave, bedroom and even a shower roomShareCommentsByChris kitchingBeth Pridding:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video man-living-converted-horse-box-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA former bin man is living inside a converted horse box with his pet German shepherd and parrot after a bad accident on the job left him unable to work. Stephen James has equipped the pound, trailer with several televisions, an oven, sink, microwave, bedroom, space for his dog Kaiser and parrot Charlie Bitefinger, and even a shower room. Its powered through a mix of generators and solar  that he has fitted to the roof. The -year-old is currently parked up in a lay-by near Willington in South Derbyshire, but hes stressed out by his situation because he is often told to move and hes living in fear of being burgled.   Stephen, who receives regular compensation payments, told Derbyshire Live leaving the trailer and his belongings unattended is a gamble. Hes looking for a permanent place to park the horse box. Stephen converted the horse box himself after buying it for pound, in .   He now wants to find a quiet spot, possibly one where he may be able to help farmers to protect their land amid a spate of thefts from rural properties. He said: I feel pressure all the time. It is hard for me, because I always worry thatI am out for too long someone will try to break into the trailer. Leaving is always a gamble.  I also cant find anywhere to stay that is safe for me and I wont be asked to move on. Usually, I can only stay where I am for a few weeks before I have to go where, which makes it dficult for me. Im hoping there is somebody out there who has a small piece of land where I can stay, and inI can keep an eye on their land and make sure nobody is doing anything they shouldnt be.  And Kaiser will scare off any thieves or trespassers. Stephen said he grew up in Sutton Coldfield in the West Midlands and spent his childhood years in a childrens home. When he left school he got a job working as a bin man and bought a bungalow in Littleover in Derbyshire.  But he suffered an accident at work when he was in his s and he was left unable to work, he added. Stephen said he struggled to pay his bills and decided to sell his home and buy a canal boat for pound,. He said he enjoyed a quiet le on the waterways and even saved a young woman as she was attacked by a dog.  He said: I was watching an Aston Villa game at the time, when another guy I knew from on the boats came running down shouting for help. I went outside and down the path and found a woman who had a dog clamped around her arm and she was screaming. There was lots of blood. But I helped get the dog away from her and keep it away and she was taken to hospital.  Eventually, Stephen had trouble finding a safe and affordable place to moor his boat. Thats when, he said, he decided to sell it and buy a horse box to convert. He bought his trailer in  and overhauled it, transforming it into the home that it is today. He lights fires inside a stove to stay warm during the cold winter nights - including recent freezing temperatures - and has a number of things to keep him occupied, including multiple televisions.

Two brothers and a cousin were also jailed for their part in the scam, which targeted poundmillion lottery winner Gillian Bayford. title: gloveless staff disposed clinical waste
story: NewsGloveless staff disposed of clinical waste at hospital where babies died from infectionThe porters at the Glasgow Royal Infirmary were spotted taking out medical waste at the under-fire hospital after two premature babies died of infectionsShareCommentsByJohn FergusonMatt Leclere:,  FEB NewsHospital workers move waste at the Princess Royal Maternity Hospital in Glasgow "Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailStaff at a hospital where two babies died after catching infections have been pictured discarding dangerous clinical waste without gloves. The NHS porters at the Glasgow Royal Infirmary were spotted breaching strict hygiene guidelines designed to prevent infections. An immediate investigation has been triggered by hospital managers after the images were captured by a photographer for a Scottish newspaper. The photos were printed today by the Sunday Mail in the wake of an ongoing investigation after two newborn babies died at the hospitals maternity unit last week. A spokesman for the NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde said the department would be investigating immediately and have already spoken to members of staff on duty on Friday and Saturday. They added: We will also be reminding staff in all of our sites of the importance of wearing full PPE.   “It should be stressed that when our porters collect waste – particularly within Glasgow Royal Infirmary and the Princess Royal Maternity – the waste holds are located outside the wards, therefore he or she would never enter a ward while performing this duty. The porters were seen moving several dferent colour bags - believed to be coded based on their contents. A source told the Sunday Mail they saw some of the workers wearing gloves but at least two were not. It would seem like an obvious precaution, both for their own safety and in terms of infection control for the whole hospital, to have had something on their hands, they said. Labour health spokeswoman Monica Lennon has demanded a speedy and full investigation. She said: “This is a really serious matter and it must be investigated fully and without delay.  “Infection control procedures at hospitals are incredibly important. “It’s essential they are communicated to all staff properly and that they have the necessary equipment for their protection and for that of other patients and staff. Recent events have highlighted just how crucial this is and the public deserves to know with confidence that the Scottish Government is making sure our hospitals are a safe and clean environment.” Writing in today’s Sunday Mail, Health Secretary Jeane Freeman said the deaths of the premature babies was “desperately sad”. She confirmed a “heightened programme of cleaning and a review of infection control measures” to make sure “everything that should be done to prevent infection, and infection spread, is being done”. Dr Alan Mathers, chief of medicine, women’s and children’s Services at NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, admitted last week the source of the bacteria that contributed to the deaths may never be known. A third baby also contracted the Staphylococcus aureus blood stream infection but is said to be giving “no cause for concern”.   Mathers said the newborn children who died had been among the “most vulnerable patients” in the country. He added: “It may be that we don’t ever get to the root of the problem. “The issue is that everyone carries bacteria in their skin and are colonised by these things – that is very dferent from an infection. “The premature baby has lots of systems that are just not ready for the world, including its immune system.” NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde launched an investigation into the deaths on January , with Freeman informed on Monday last week. The probe emerged after prosecutors confirmed they were probing separate incidents in which two patients died in another hospital run by the same health board. A -year-old boy and a -year-old woman passed away after contracting an infection linked to pigeon droppings at Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow. The NHS has also been battling a clinical waste crisis for weeks after disposal firm Healthcare Environmental Serviceswas stripped of its contract after collapsing in December. It has resulted in body parts, blood, tissue and other clinical waste being stored in containers outside hospitals, as well as at other sites around the country. We revealed in December that porters were furious at being drafted in to help dispose of waste after HES were axed.   But the spokeswoman for NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde denied any link between the HES crisis and the deaths in Glasgow, insisting there had been no changes to waste management processes or pick-up frequency at Glasgow Royal Infirmary. She said: “There has been no reduction in our waste collection service since December  when HES were no longer able to supply a service. “The storage, transport and disposal of all of our waste is compliant with national standard operating procedures. All waste is segregated and stored in safe and appropriate areas. “All NHSGGC hospitals continue to receive waste collections from NSS approved contractors with the same regularity as HES provided. “Glasgow Royal Infirmary receives a minimum of two waste collections per day, seven days per week. Additional uplts are available on request.” The Scottish Government added: “There is absolutely no link between the disposal of clinical waste and the deaths of patients. To suggest otherwise would be highly irresponsible and utterly incorrect.” About  staff were made redundant without pay over Christmas after the NHS ripped up HES contracts across the UK. Environmental protection watchdog SEPA said it was working with the Scottish Government, NHS Scotland, NHS National Services Scotland and health boards on contingency arrangements for the storage and disposal of clinical waste. We told last month how a worker at Raigmore Hospital in Inverness had suffered a needle injury moving piles of the waste, after having to take on extra duties. The GMB union confirmed four men out of a team of  porters had sustained injuries. A senior source at collapsed HES said: “Infection control is worse right now as porters are handling waste more often. “I also doubt porters have the correct protective equipment as was reported at Raigmore.”

title: mcdonalds customer who complained veggie
story: NewsVegan McDonalds customer who complained about veggie wrap told to kill herself by trollsEleanor Dix, an -year-old vegan, says she was left in tears after finding chicken when she bit into the veggie wrap - and felt degraded by vile abuse from online trollsShareCommentsByChris kitchingKrishan Davis:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsEleanor Dix reported the abusive messages to Twitter "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA McDonalds customer says she has faced a barrage of abuse from Twitter trolls after she allegedly found chicken in a vegetarian wrap from the fast food giant. Eleanor Dix said she ordered a Spicy Veggie Wrap and was left in tears after she bit into it and discovered that it contained meat. The -year-old vegan, from Bristol, complained to McDonalds on Twitter but she soon received vile tweets from trolls who had discovered her plea to the Big Mac chain. Eleanor told Bristol Live she was stunned as one hurtful Twitter user told her to kill herself and others sent sexist and misogynistic abuse or accused her of overreacting.  The teen, who describes herself as a lelong vegetarian who went vegan four years ago, ordered the McDonalds wrap through UberEats while at university in Cardf on January . It was supposed to contain vegetarian red pesto goujons, tomato relish and salad. But Eleanor claims it contained chicken, and shes not the only one to make similar allegations. People in London, Birmingham, Kent, Lincoln and Liverpool have reported similar claims since the new vegetarian option launched.  Eleanor said she first complained to UberEats through its app, but she didnt receive a response after two hours and decided to send tweets to McDonalds. She wrote: I ordered a spicy veggie wrap from one of your stores and thanks to the sheer incompetency of some of your staff I’ve been given chicken. I’ve been veggie my whole le and this has literally put me in tears as I ingested part of this wrap thinking it was veggie. In a second tweet, she wrote: Please can you ensure your staff are fully trained and competent when issuing out food in future please. This is a really important issue and can easily offend many customersmistakes like these are made often. Thats when she was inundated with vile messages, mostly from users who appeared to be grown men. She told Bristol Live: When people think other people are questioning their lestyle they feel quite threatened by that, even when its such a small thing in their lives.I felt patronised, degraded and small by the comments. They were just nasty. She added: I was brought up vegetarian so Ive been veggie my whole le. Its for ethical reasons and the environment is a big concern for me as well.  Ive never eaten meat before and Ive never wanted to. I was quite shocked by it. Its completely disrupted my ethical beliefs and lestyle choice. Its happening all over the country, its quite serious. Eleanor reported the worst comments to Twitter and they were removed. She has not reported the abuse to police. McDonalds UK responded to her tweets, writing: Hi, sorry to hear that. Wed like to look into this further, so please DM us with more detailsand well look into it. Thanks for contacting us. A spokesperson for McDonalds said: “We’d like to apologise to customers for any mistake made, we absolutely understand and appreciate that it is not acceptable to serve meat when our vegetarian product has been ordered. We would like to reassure that we have a number of measures in place to avoid inaccurate orders, and that, after a small number of similar customer contacts, we have also introduced immediate changes in our restaurants to ensure this mistake is not made, and communicated with all restaurants to ensure order accuracy. We would encourage anyone with any concerns to contact our Customer Services team.”

story: NewsOver two thirds of children have NEVER heard of classic fairytalesTwo thirds of parents admit their children have never heard of the classics from their own childhoodsShareCommentsByDaniel Bird:,  FEB NewsHalf of the kids in the study have not been read The Selfish Giant by Oscar Wilde "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFairytales are dying out, with two-thirds of parents admitting their children have never heard of many classics. Half of them have not been read The Selfish Giant by Oscar Wilde. The Pied Piper of Hamelin by Robert Browning and Thumbelina by Hans Christian Andersen were next on the list of unfamiliar stories. Youngsters were also unaware of the Brothers Grimm tales of Hansel and Gretel, Rapunzel and Rumpelstiltskin, along with Puss in Boots, Pinocchio, Sleeping Beauty and others beloved of past generations.   Three in  parents admit their children believe Cinderella and Beauty and the Beast are Disney films, not Charles Perrault books. And more than half of adults do not tell their primary school children stories every night, with TVs, tablets and smartphones acting as replacements. A fth said they find it impossible to wing telling stories.  But nearly four in  parents and a similar amount of children say that bedtime tales are a joy.Ben Hogg for storytelling aid Rory’s Story Cubes, behind the poll of parents with under-s, said: “Story time should never be lost.” Ex-Children’s Laureate Michael Rosen added: “Children benefit hugely. story: NewsSix stone man whos barely able to walk denied benefits and told to go find workStephen Smith, , suffers from severe health problems that recently saw his weight drop to just six stone with his bones visible through his skinShareCommentsByLiam Thorp:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video man-who-weighed-barely-six-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:,],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man has told how he was denied crucial benefits and told to look for a job despite severe health problems that left him looking like he is wasting away at just six stone. Stephen Smith is so thin in these images taken during a hospital stay over Christmas that his bones are visible through his skin. The -year-old, from Liverpool, said he isnt healthy enough to work and he can barely walk on his own due to a number of serious conditions. He was forced to get a pass out from hospital so he could fight a Department for Work and Pensionsdecision declaring him fit and capable of finding work, and denying him benefits, the Liverpool Echo reports.   Mr Smith won that appeal after a tribunal judge saw that he can barely walk down the street let alone hold down a job. At the time, his weight had dropped to just six stone and he feared he would die as his health worsened. Repeated calls to grant Employment and Support Allowanceto Mr Smith were denied even though doctors had written stating that he couldnt walk  metreswithout collapsing in pain and exhaustion. The DWP claims he has continued to receive all of the benefits he was entitled to, but a man who campaigned on his behalf believes he is owed pound, in back pay.Mr Smith suffers from debilitating and incurable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which causes severe breathing dficulties that gradually get worse over time and limit normal activities.   He also has excruciating osteoarthritis and an enlarged prostate, and he uses a colostomy bag to go to the toilet. Despite his health problems, Mr Smith failed a DWP work capability assessment in  and his ESA payments were stopped. He was told to sign on for a pound-a-week Jobseekers Allowance, visit the Job Centre once a week and prove he was looking for work. Mr Smith said: I could only make it to the kitchen to make food once a day. I had no muscles in the back of my leg which meant I couldnt stand up at all - and had to lean or sit down all the time - but they were telling me I was fit for work. Mr Smith believes his le was saved by two men - Tony Nelson and Terry Craven.   Mr Nelson runs the CASA community centre, which acts as an advice and resource centre for local residents, and introduced Mr Smith to Mr Craven, a former city council welfare officer who helps people at CASA with benefit claims. When Mr Smith lost ESA, Mr Craven battled with the DWP to restore his benefits, and sent the opinions of two doctors who described the signicant dficulty and pain Mr Smith suffers when he does simple movements and daily activities. One doctors note stated: It is my opinion that Mr Smith could not walk  metres without pain or exhaustion. Despite the evidence, the DWP rejected Mr Smiths appeal in January last year and told him that he didnt meet the criteria for having limited capability for work. Mr Smith and Mr Craven continued to fight the DWP for months and were given a hearing at a tribunal earlier this month, one year on from the DWPs decision.  By then, Mr Smiths health had taken a turn for the worse as he struggled to look after himself. Mr Craven said: Around December time me and my we went to check in on him and my we said  we dont do something now, hes not long for this world. Mr Smith was suffering from pneumonia and was taken to hospital, where he was pictured weighing just six stone. After getting a pass allowing him to leave the hospital, Mr Smith attended the tribunal and won. A judge stated he satisfied the requirement for ESA due to his limited mobility and health problems. Mr Smith will be put back on ESA, and Mr Craven believes the -year-old is owed about pound, in back pay. Mr Craven said: I have got lots of cases like Steves - I have a client at the moment who is actually on dialysis and has been thrown off benefits. Mr Smith said: Without them [Mr Nelson and Mr Craven] and this place [CASA] I probably wouldnt be here today - I had nowhere to turn- they have saved my le. In a statement, a spokeswoman for the DWP claimed Mr Smith has continued to receive all of the benefits he was entitled to, as well as offers of personal support to improve his skills and health issues. She added: He has now been reassessed, reflecting his changing condition and will be receiving full ESA support. “We’re committed to ensuring that people with health conditions get the support they’re entitled to. Decisions for ESA are made following consideration of all the information provided by the claimant, including supporting evidence from their GP or medical specialist. Any claimant can appeal a decision for free to an independent tribunal.”

title: spent week living universal credit
story: NewsI spent a week living on Universal Credit - this is what its likeReceiving weekly allowance for a -year-old, one young reporter ended up with just £ a day to spend on food, heating and travelShareCommentsByAlex GroveBen Weich:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror incoming video what-is-universal-credit-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,swipeNavigation:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe Governments controversial Universal Credit scheme has rarely been out of the headlines during its troubled roll-out across the country.Stories abound of claimants having to turn to food banks, and the programme was recently revealed to have the lowest satisfaction score of any welfare benefit.But what is it actually like to live on Universal Credit  Keen to demonstrate the adversities faced by those on the scheme, Hull Live reporter Alex Grove volunteered to live solely on a weekly benefits allowance, based on calculations made by the Citizens Advice Bureau. As a -year-old man living in private rented shared accommodation, with no disabilities or children, he received pound. for the month – or roughly pound. per week. But even that was quickly chipped away at by deductions, with Hull City Council tax taking pound. a week, and a further pound was set aside for gas and electric.   Alex was left with scarcely more than pound per week – not taking into account water rates, his mobile phone contract, car insurance or road tax. The most he was offered to go towards his rent was pound. a week, with any shortfall coming out of his own pocket. He said: That left me with pound a day, and I quickly realised some of my typical outgoings during the week would have to be signicantly reduced. With a limited amount of money to spend, I soon realised just how much money I waste during the week, particularly during my days at work. Takeaways were also a no-go. Lazily, I do sometimes find myself having a scroll through Deliveroo and picking out a meal or heading over to McDonalds – particularly when I’m hungover. But having a takeaway even just once a week would completely wipe out my budget, so I had no choice but to make the most of my weekly food shops and resist indulging on junk food.   It soon dawned on Alex that even Tesco meal deals – priced at pound, or half his daily allowance – would have to fall by the wayside, too. Alex added: I am a sucker for a Tesco meal deal which sets me back pound a day and although it’s a great offer, it costs me almost half of my daily budget. I knew I had to change my ways so every night I made sandwiches to take into work and bought multipacks of crisps instead of wasting money buying inidual packs as part of a meal deal. Universal Credit, dubbed a “six-in-one” payment, has been labelled a “shambles” by critical MPs. Earlier this month, the Works and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd announced a string of changes to save Universal Credit from further disaster, but maintains it will be fully implemented by . Margaret Greenwood, Labours shadow Work and Pensions Secretary, has called for it to be halted entirely, claiming that it has been used as a vehicle for cuts to social security.   Reporting in Hull Live, Alex said he found that there was no room for me to be able to afford what most would constitute as a respectable social le. He wrote: Couple of pints down the pub with your mates  No chance. A meal out at a restaurant  In your dreams. On the budget I had, there just wasn’t enough money to go towards typical social activities for a man of my age. I like a tipple sometimes after a day at work, but this was something I just could not financially manage given the limited budget I had at my disposal.   Yes, you can buy packs of lager and cider in supermarkets and minimarts but these will still set you back and realistically, alcohol is something you just have to do without. He also described paying for his car to be unrealistic, as fuel prices, road tax and breakdown cover piled up. He was left to fork out for public transport fares to get to his local Jobcentre to sign on. The young reporter concluded that his weekly allowance on Universal Credit was adequate, as long as he managed to resist indulging in alcohol or recreational activities.   He said: I would have been living on the breadline and, although you receive more moneyyou have children and other relatives to look after, ultimately, you have more mouths to feed and that presents dficulties. There is a high possibility, particularly at a time when we are experiencing sub-zero temperatures, that I would have had to endure freezing cold nights and sacriced my warmth in order to get by.

title: woman who searched online ways
story: NewsWoman who searched online for ways to die calls for social networks to be policedInternet giants are being urged to remove disturbing content following the death of Molly RussellShareCommentsByZoe Chamberlain:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsNatasha Benjamin says lives are being put in danger on social media"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA woman who searched online for ways of ending her le has joined calls for social networks to be policed. Campaigner Natasha Benjamin told Birmingham Live that she has written to Instagram bosses calling for disturbing material to be taken down. Five years ago she began trawling the internet for painless ways to die. Thankfully, she found an inspirational website that brought her back from the brink.  But, she says her le could have panned out very dferentlyshed discovered similar material to teenager Molly Russell. The -year-old died in  - and her dad Ian believes Instagram is partly responsible - because he found distressing material about depression and suicide on her account. Natasha, who suffered domestic abuse as a child, said: I’d reached a point where I just felt I couldn’t do this anymore. I began to look up ways to die painlessly because I was in enough pain as it was.   “If I could die painlessly, at least I could say some part of my le wasn’t painful. Then I found a page online that said ‘You’re obviously very down but why not start from scratch again, start a fresh new le  It felt like an awakening for me. Thankfully, I didnt get what I was looking for online. But,Id found what Molly had been looking at, who knows what might have happened. I might not be here talking about this now. Now Health Secretary Matt Hancock has written to Facebook - which owns Instagram, as well as Twitter and Google, telling them they have a duty to act. Read more of Natashas story here Today, Natasha runs Free Your Mind CIC , a child domestic violence and mental heath support, awareness and support service.She meets young people every day who are struggling with what they see on social media.  Another le has been lost and that is horrible, said Natasha, who was once a size  due to comfort eating.When social media was created, this is not what it was meant for - its turned into this monster, and its a real concern.People have access to other people in a way thats not normal. Everyone is contactable in the blink of a text or direct message.  They can post the most hateful, disturbing material and theres no censorship. There are posts on how to starve yourself, how to end your le and they are not taken down. There are actually Instagram posts encouraging people to keep on starving themselves and tips on how to do it. It makes me really annoyed. Thats why we get tragic results like this.Natasha believes social media has a much more powerful effect on young people today than it did when she was at her lowest ebb in . Social media is so much bigger than it was just a few years ago, said Natasha, who now lives in London. Im very glad I made my search then rather than now. I think people are really influenced by what they see. I remember back then a tweet from someone about me would send me reeling. My sister is  and she comes home upset about something but she wont let us do anything about it as she doesnt want any backlash. Anne Longfield, the Children’s Commissioner for England, has called on Facebook , YouTube, Pinterest and Snapchat to back a statutory duty of care to take more responsibility for what children are able to access online.She is also calling for a digital ombudsman to act as an independent arbiter between the s and their users in the wake of the Molly Russell case.Natasha wrote to Instagram saying much the same thing a couple of years ago. I wrote to Instagram a while ago, saying they had a responsibility to these people to take down certain posts and asking what is the process behind that  said Natasha, .  Because they do take down other posts that are much less of a danger so they do monitor whats going on but they leave these damaging posts. It makes no sense. But I didnt get a response. I said it could result in a loss of le and now it has. I should think its happened before but we just dont hear about it. Natasha launched a blog called Free Your Mind in  then wrote a book about her journey, which featured the stories of others too. She has since hosted lots of fundraising events, such as K Free Your Mind runs and #Loveback days when she and her team have pounded the streets of London raising awareness and giving out free hugs. Free Your Mind offers one to one and online support, workshops, school talks and has just launched a support centre. Social media is such a big thing for many young people today, she added.  My sister locks herself away and spends hours just skimming through Instagram. Its just the way a lot of young people are now. Even when a young person is sat talking to me, they find it hard to go cold turkey without their phone for an hour. I see them sneakily grabbing it to have a look under the table, just so they dont miss a trick. This is where everything is for that generation - their friends, music, TV - and it means theyre very much tied to them, living their social lives through their phones. It results in comparison issues. I work really hard to say to young people thatyou are always looking at what other people are doing, you can never be present in your own le. Youll never enjoy your leyoure so busy looking at others peoples. And people always put up their best le on social media - you have to realise there is another le behind that photo. Its hard for some young people to see that because this world is their reality. She added: People like to have lots of friends and followers on social media but thats like going outside to meet all your friends all at once. Its hard to keep up with it. And its not normal. If all your social media friends turned up outside your house youd be horried. Its a really strange reality. Nobodys got time to keep up with that many people. Theres so much pressure. People make and break friends on social media. At work, I see people cry on a daily basis, it shows how much people are holding stuff in. Ill have seen their social media posts and they look happy and smiling, and here they are in my office crying their eyes out. Its not being honest about whats happening and I think theres a lack of being honest with yourself these days just to project that image to other people. It makes no sense.Find out more about Free Your Mind CIC hereIf you need to speak to someone, Samaritans are available   by calling   or by emailing jo@samaritans.org

story: NewsPope Francis arrives in UAE on historic first visit to Arabian PeninsulaThe pontfs three day trip will include a mass in Abu Dhabi set to attract , worshippersShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  FEB NewsPope Francis is making the first papal visit to the Arabian Peninsula "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPope Francis has become the first head of the Catholic church to visit the Arabian Peninsula in a historic visit. title: what lunar new year google
story: NewsWhat is Lunar New Year  Google Doodle celebrating Chinese festival revealedLunar New Year begins on February  and is the Chinese festival celebrating the beginning of a new yearShareCommentsByRobyn DarbyshireAudience Writer:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe Lunar New Year is also known as Chinese New Year"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMillions of people are getting ready to celebrate the Lunar New Year next week, which will welcome the Year of the Pig. Chinese New Year or Lunar New Year is the Chinese festival that celebrates the beginning of a new year - and Google has unveiled its pig-themed Doodle marking the special occasion. The Chinese calendar works a little dferently to the one we use in the UK, and is influenced by the moon cycles. The Lunar New Year begins on February and is often referred to as the Spring festival in mainland China. It is one of several Lunar New Years in Asia.Its traditionally observed from the evening preceding the first day of the year to the Lantern Festival, held on the th day of the year.  The first day of Chinese New Year begins on the new moon that appears between January  and February  - so this year its on February .The Lunar New Year is one of the worlds most celebrated festivals - and is a major holiday in China. The associated festivities typically run for two weeks, and in China, people are usually given a week’s public holiday to observe tradition - its equally signicant for many communities across the globe too. While you might not be given any time off here in the UK, major cities are putting on celebrations to ring in the Year of the Pig,in London, Birmingham, Manchester, Liverpool, Newcastle and more.  Traditional celebrations include impressive fireworks displays, parades and delicious foods.In London, the biggest celebrations will take place on Sunday February  in Trafalgar Square, Chinatown and across the West End. Free to attend, expect lively activities and foodie treats in Chinatown, family-friendly entertainment in Leicester Square and stage performances in Trafalgar Square. Meanwhile Manchester City Centre is hosting four days of fun, food, fireworks and good fortune this February to celebrate Chinese New Year. Andyou fancy staying in to celebrate, Marks  Spencer has launched a bargain pound meal deal to mark the occasion.

title: dundee united loan signing charlie seaman wants to return to bournemouth with medal
story: Dundee United loan signing Charlie Seaman has come to Dundee United to develop as a player and get first-team experience.And he also aims to be heading back to parent club Bournemouth this summer with a Scottish Championship medal in his pocket.In capturing the -year-old full-back from one of the surprise success stories of the English Premier League over the past few seasons, Tangerines boss Robbie Neilson stressed the deal was exactly what it said on the tin – a loan.The end of the season will see Seaman head back to the south coast and be expected to challenge for a top-team place with the Cherries.However, while his time in Scotland will be a learning experience, the former West Ham youth wants success as well.“Hopefully, coming here and learning dferent things will help me for when I go back for next season,” he said.“I can learn dferent styles here so I am really happy to be in Scotland with United.“The boys here love to play football and that’s good because it’s that way down at Bournemouth.“Every side of the game, though, on the ball, off the ball I am trying to learn, it’s what I’m here for. Defensively I am trying to be better and I want to be better offensively as well.“I came here to get experience of first-team football. I was waiting for my chance at Bournemouth but I felt I could get it here sooner, get some games for the rest of the season. Hopefully I will be more readyI get the opportunity when I go back, or wherever it may be.“There is a job to do for the team as well and our goal at Dundee United is to win this league. Yes, it would be nice to be finishing the season with a medal for that.”Seaman’s time north of the border hardly got off to the perfect start and, within hours of his arrival, he was tasting defeat as United went down to Ayr.His temporary manager was disappointed with the team performance at Somerset Park but did make a point of saying the new arrival had put in some good work.The young full-back took encouragement from that but has admitted he did not necessarily agree with Robbie’s assessment.“I was happy to make my debut last week, obviously disappointed with the loss, but it was good to get out there and experience something dferent,” he added.“I didn’t think I started the game too well but I thought I grew into it. Still, personally, I don’t think it was one of my better games by any stretch.“It was my first game at the club, my first playing a dferent style of football and my first playing in dferent weather conditions and stuff like that.“It was all a learning curve, something to take from that game into future games.“I came up Thursday night, so I only had a day here before the game but I have high expectations and I like to set high standards.“When I don’t reach them, I’m disappointed.”The aim now is to show up well as he makes his home debut as Morton visit Tannadice and United try to get back to winning ways to keep in touch with leaders Ross County.And Seaman does admit this week has given him more time to do his homework on the opposition, saying: “Before Ayr the gaffer gave me a lot of clips of Ayr to watch so I had a fair idea of what they were going to do.“I was relatively ready for the game in a tactical aspect but I did only come up on Thursday night.“For this game against Morton we have been getting information throughout the week. So I’ve an idea of what to expect and I am looking forward to playing in front of our own fans.”

title: dundee uniteds nicky clark says we are making life very hard for ourselves
story: Nicky Clark admits Dundee United are “making it very hard for ourselves” as their bid for promotion to the Premiership stumbles yet again.The Tangerines fell six points behind leaders Ross County and three behind Ayr United after losing to the Honest Men - last Friday.With  matches remaining in the Championship race, Clark admits the Tangerines need to pick up three points more often than not between now and the end of the campaign.And that starts this weekend at home to Greenock Morton.The striker said: “We’re still up there, still round about it but we know we need to pick up now.“The next game is massive for us now, we need three points because we are making it really hard for ourselves but we need to just concentrate on our own matches and it’s important we pick up three points from most games between now and the end of the season.“There is still plenty of time, especially in this league because everybody seems to beat everybody, but it’s games like Friday you need to go and winyou want to win titles.“Friday we didn’t manage that so we only have ourselves to blame.“However, we have Morton this weekend and we can galvanise ourselves and get three points.“Saturday will be tough – it’s all good teams in this league so we need to prepare ourselves this week. The gaffer will get us ready for it and we need to make sure we go and do the business.”The performance at Somerset Park was a bitter disappointment for the  United fans who made the long trip on a Friday night.And Clark admits it wasn’t good enough from the Tangerines.He added: “We went down to Ayr with full intentions of winning the game.“We gave ourselves a chance a couple of weeks ago against Dunfermline when we won and got ourselves up the league but we let ourselves and the fans down on Friday.“The weather meant it was never going to be a pretty game and they got a chance early on and took it.“I think we only had one real chance with Aidan towards the end where the goalie was out quick and made a good save.“All in all it was a very frustrating night and we were very disappointed.”Strong winds made le dficult for all the players but it was clear Ian McCall’s men coped far better with the conditions than United.The home side dominated the opening period and got their goal through Craig Moore early on but the expected response from the Tangerines with the wind in their favour in the second half never really materialised.Clark added: “It was dficult conditions but we’ve all played in wind like that before, we all know what it’s like.“We had a game plan – I don’t knowwe didn’t stick to it but it never happened for us.“We’re disappointed because that’s nine points we’ve given Ayr this season and we’re making it very hard for ourselves.”It’s been a stop-start first season at the club for Clark with a series of injuries curtailing his first-team opportunities.Now, though, he says he’s back to % and ready to help United get back on track.“It’s been very frustrating for me, I’ve missed a lot of games with daft wee injuries here and there where you can’t actually treat them, you just have to leave them until they get better.“It’s been frustrating but I’m back and feeling good now so, hopefully, I can kick on now and help the team get where we want to be.”

title: final tour brian poole to return to dundee with the tremeloes for his homecoming
story: When Brian Poole s to Dundee with The Tremeloes this spring, it will be like a “homecoming” for the -year-old star of the iconic ’s band.The Tremeloes are taking part in the Solid Silver s Show at the Caird Hall on March .Brian insists the city feels like a second home after so many performances. vw, px"  He said: “I love Dundee and I’m really looking forward to coming back to the city. Coming to play here always feels like coming home.“I’ve played in Dundee many times over the years, including almost once a year for the past  years.“I’ve been coming so often it feels like my second home and I feel like an adopted Dundonian.“I’ve watched the city change dramatically over the years.“I remember staying in the Hilton Hotel quite a few years ago now and walking across the flyover to get to the Caird Hall.“Now the Waterfront area is all change, not least with the fantastic VA.“I’ve seen so many changes in the city over the years it will be great to see how it looks now – very dferent to when I first started playing gigs.”Brian revealed that about  years ago he was asked to donate one of his original s suits to the VA in London.He’s hoping the Dundee museum may ask him for a similar donation as he prepares to embark on his final tour.Brian said: “It was a suit I wore on Top of the Pops in the s. It would be brilliantthe VA in Dundee approached me to ask about exhibiting another of my suits.“Time is catching up with me and it’s now time to give up touring.“I’ll continue to do s festivals but my touring days are coming to an end.“I started out in the business in  so I’m now into my sixth decade performing.“I remember I had just sat my A levels and was waiting for the results when I did my first gig with The Tremeloes.“I was  and we were performing at Butlins at Ayr. I met people from Dundee there and came to perform in the Caird Hall not that long after.”Brian and The Tremeloes went their separate ways in  after six years of hits.They got back together briefly in  for a one-off charity fundraising gig for the victims of the Asian tsunami.Brian confirmed all the old favourites would be on the setlist when they take to the stage in Dundee in March.He said: “All the old songs will be played in Dundee.“The audiences in Scotland are always very enthusiastic, especially in Dundee and we love playing up here.”Regarded as an institution on the circuit, the Solid Silver s Show features classic hits performed by the original artists.This year, as well as The Tremeloes, other stars taking part include Peter Noone and Dave Berry with Vanity Fare.Brian said: “We all have a fabulous time and it’s going to be great to get together with Peter and Dave.“We are all great friends and we will be meeting up with other family and friends for a fantastic gig in Dundee.“My son-in-law comes from Glasgow so members of our family have promised they will come to Dundee for our gig here, making it a real family affair for us.”

story: Highland Adventure Fest is expected to take place in Inverness Leisure Centre on Sunday, March .And the event is expected to feature presentations and entertainment from outdoor enthusiasts, as well as demonstrations and live music.The event is being advertised to those who have an interest in outdoor activities such as mountain biking, hiking, and kayaking among others.Festival-goers will be able to try out kit, buy new clothing and equipment, book activities and meet new people with similar interests while enjoying presentations and entertainment on the main stage.The mini festival is being planned by Inverness-based event organisers PLANIT Scotland and will be sponsored by the Glenmore Lodge in Aviemore.Katie Masheter, from PLANIT Scotland, said: ldquoWe are organising the event because the Highlands are quite often seen as a bit of an adventure playground.Miss Masheter went on to say that although they are expecting mostly local people at the event they welcome tourists to come along also, she said: ldquoVisitScotlandrsquos recent tourism conference was placing emphasis on getting the country set-up for an influx of tourists looking for adventure, so what we thought would be great is to pull together an event which brings everyone under one roof.The event is open to all.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Clachnacuddin FC pays tribute to superfan from Yorkshire
story: Bronwyn Wain , who lived in Huddersfield, was described as a ldquolovely lady and ldquoreal character by club figures.Despite living in Yorkshire, her unlikely association with the club began in  when she got in touch with the Lilywhites out of curiosity about the clubrsquos name and history.The links grew from there and she became a true Lily when she visited Grant Street as club guest in . Just ordinary folk who took the club to their hearts and they became well-known to many of our players, directors and fans, said Billy Corbett, a former director of the club. ldquoIt was the name Clachnacuddin that attracted her attention. Its a Gaelic word and means lsquothe stone of the tubrsquo. She sent money every month to one of our fans to buy her ticket in the Lily Lotto.
