title: DJ marathon charity event in Inverness aims to be a money spinner
story: Several local DJs will take to the decks during the Caledonian V Cancer event this Saturday in aid of CLIC Sargent.The music starts at pm and finishes at am on Sunday, and the sound selectors will include DJs Terry Fire, Lady Beats, Andy Innis, CKaz and Richard Lewis.The event has been organised in memory of Michael Murphy who succumbed to cancer last year aged .Michaelrsquos uncle Sean , of Dalneigh, is a regular in the bar.Sean has already organised several fundraising events across Inverness, and so far he has raised more than pound for the charity.Sean said he was really grateful to the Caledonian and all the DJs for their support, adding: ldquoMichael first became unwell in  and he had two forms of leukaemia and sadly died last September.ldquoCLIC Sargent really helped us through some hard times so I became involved in the fundraising.Michael was involved in last yearrsquos Stand Up To Cancer campaign on Channel  having been filmed for the national fundraiser prior to his death.The former factory worker and McDonaldrsquos crew member lived in Forres before moving to Inverness.Mark Glendinning, general manager of the Caledonian, said: ldquoWe try to support as many local events as possible, but this one is particularly special as Sean is both a friend and regular customer.ldquoCLIC Sargent is a wonderful charity that supports cancer patients and their families during incredibly dficult times.ldquoThey were particularly helpful to Michaelrsquos we Shannon and young daughter Sophia after he passed away, so we want to help Sean raise funds for them to give something back.CLIC Sargent supports children and young people with cancer and leukaemia and the Caledonian event will be held ahead of World Cancer Day on Monday.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland air traffic controllers to be balloted over strike action
story: The Prospect Union has already notied Highlands and Islands Airports Ltdthat it will be asking air traffic controllers to cast a vote regarding a strike. An indicative ballot in October gained overwhelming support.The dispute centres on the controllers at Inverness and where being paid much less than their counterparts further south, which the union maintains is unfair.An innovative centralised air traffic control system that many fear could lead to job losses in years to come has also added to the bitterness in the dispute, though it is not part of the current move.Before Christmas both Prospect and HIAL agreed to an evidence-based business case that set out the pay gap between HIAL and the rest of the industry in an attempt to resolve the dispute.Prospect believesHIAL cannot attract and retain controllers through pay issues, this has and will continue to cause staff shortages and pose a risk to maintaining service provision.According to the union it has no choice but to move towards industrial action after Scottish Ministers rejected the business case earlier this week without explanation and with no additional funding offered.Prospect negotiation officer David Avery said: ldquoScottish Ministers have been promising pay restoration for public sector workers but their policy fails to deliver.ldquoThere is a global shortage of air traffic controllers which is driving wages up across the industry - at the same time HIAL staff have received below inflation pay awards.ldquoIt is unfair that a HIAL air traffic controller, providing an essential service for the Highlands and Islands, is being paid half as much their counterpart in London ndash enough is enough.ldquoOur members have tried every other means to resolve this dispute but by rejecting a fair and reasonable proposal to resolve the dispute ministers have left them with no option but to pursue strike action.HIAL HR director Andrea Sillars, said: ldquoHIAL note the position taken by the Ministers. We are disappointed that Prospect have decided to ballot their members on strike action. We remain committed to continuing constructive discussions to help resolve the dispute and are open to holding further talks with Prospect on a recruitment and retention allowance for Air Traffic Control staff. We await the outcome of the ballot.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland MPs scathing after Prime Minister vows to reopen Brexit backstop negotiations
story: The - vote victory came after Speaker John Bercow selected seven amendments that iously sought to extend the date of departure, make a lsquono-dealrsquo impossible, place the Brexit process in the hands of parliament, and find an alternative to the Northern Ireland back-stop.All were defeated except the Brady Amendment ndash seeking a renegotiated backstop - and a non-binding motion calling for an economically damaging lsquono-dealrsquo to be ruled out.But Theresa May looks set to face a struggle reopening the Withdrawl Agreement negotiated with the EU after European Council president, Donald Tusk, immediately shot down the proposals, stating: "The backstop is part of the Withdrawal Agreement, and the Withdrawal Agreement is not open for re-negotiation."The SNPrsquos Westminster leader Ian Blackford, who is also MP for Ross, Skye and Lochaber, had earlier submitted an amendment noting how the Scottish and Welsh assemblies voted against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal, calling for an extension of article  ndash which would delay the UKrsquos EU departure - and for no deal to be removed as an option. It was defeated by  votes to .He warned that the development means Number  has brought the country closer to a no-deal Brexit and undermined the Good Friday Agreement that brought peace to Northern Ireland.ldquoBy throwing her weight behind an impossible demand from the hard Brexit wing of the Conservative Party the Prime Minister today demonstrated beyond doubt she is now prepared to take Scotland and the UK over the Brexit clf-edge.ldquoTheresa May could have worked across parties to protect jobs and living standards but she chose to side with the Brexit extremists in her own party.ldquoOnce again Scotland has been silenced, sidelined and shafted by Westminster, and we are paying a heavy price for a chaotic Tory government that Scotland did not vote for. And today the Tories ripped apart the Good Friday agreement, an international treaty the UK had signed up to."His SNP colleague Drew Hendry, who represents Inverness,Nairn,Badenoch and Strathspey, added: ldquoWith her Brexit deal in tatters after its record-breaking defeat in the House of Commons, Theresa Mays focus remains on appeasing her Tory colleagues, rather than on delivering a plan to protect jobs and the economy.ldquoShe knows this fudge on the Irish backstop cannot be delivered in any meaningful way, yet she continues to waste what valuable time is left. It is little wonder the EU  are so bemused by her behaviour.ldquoAs ever, it is the public who will pay the price for this shambles. The Prime Minister has made no attempt to recognise the views of the Scottish electorate, and the damage Brexit will cause to the Scottish economy.ldquoLabour has shown they are also not to be trusted, leaving us facing the prospect of being hauled out of the EU and made to endure all the damage that brings. It is clear Westminster is not working for Scotland and its time to take ownership of our own future.The Liberal Democrats voted in favour of the Labour MP Yvette Cooperrsquos amendment which was defeated by  votes to . It sought more to allow parliament more time to figure out how to break the deadlock.When this failed Liberal Democrat MP Jamie Stone, who represents Caithness, Sutherland and Easter Ross,argued for a Peoplersquos Vote because crashing out with no-deal would, he said, be a disaster for those in the far north.ldquoJobs, infrastructure, health care in my constituency all rely on EU citizens to fill vital roles and on EU funding," he explained.ldquoMPs who voted in favour of Bradyrsquos amendment were knowingly voting for a no deal Brexit. The EU had made it very clear to all involved that they would not reopen negotiations. These MPs are running after a fantasy and itrsquos British people who will pay the price.ldquoAll Theresa May has done is kick the can down the road and run the clock down even further. She is gambling with time we just donrsquot have.Mr Stone also sought to underline the importance of the non-binding Spelman amendment which stated the UK will not leave the EU without a deal.ldquoLabour MPs who sat on their hands have once again facilitated Theresa May and the European Research Groupin their pursuit of a no deal Brexit.ldquoA win for amendment ldquoI means the government has once again been told that there is no majority in the house for a no deal Brexit. The PM needs to take no deal off the table - as she should have done months ago - and recognise that people are not in favour of a hard Brexit which will damage our country.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Intake cap at seven Inverness schools
story: SEVEN Inverness schools will have their rolls capped in - academic session.The move was triggered by high demand for places at each school.The primary schools affected by the cap are Holm, Lochardil, Kinmylies and Milton of Leys while three secondary schools ndash Charleston, Culloden and Millburn Academies ndash will also have the first year intake limited.The local authority said it will do its best to accommodate all pupils in their preferred choice of school but warned that they would be subject to criteria.Pupils must be within the Highland area and within the geographical catchment of the school concerned or  certied medical reasons or additional support needs best be served by a specic school are needed.If pupils had siblings at a particular school that would also help their case while religious belief for denominational schools would also be a factor.Educational courses unavailable at one school or pupils living within the catchment area of a secondary school that is not subject to capping might impact where a child can go as would proximity to home to school and road safety or ease of travel.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: New bridge over the River Nairn is on track for summer
story: TEMPORARY weight restrictions on a busy rural road could be scrapped by the summer.Work to build a new crossing over the River Nairn to replace the ageing White Bridge is ldquoprogressing well and on track for completion by early summer, Highland Council has confirmed.The road bridge, which dates back to the th century and is category A listed, spans the river on the B route between Clephanton and Cawdor.It has been struggling to cope with heavy modern traffic and a weight limit of  tonnes has been in operation while a new bridge is built and the road realigned. The weight restriction has caused disruption for farmers, forestry vehicles and tour buses, which have been unable to use the existing bridge in the interim.The pound. million project is being handled by Dingwall-based RJ McLeod .Confirming that work is on track, Highland Council said that construction of the abutments for the new crossing beams was now complete and the beams were successfully hoisted into place this week.Now that the four beams are in place, contractor RJ McLeod will proceed with decking out between beams in preparation for concrete casting.Highland councillors in the Nairn and Cawdor ward, and Culloden and Ardersier wards ndash whose boundaries are spanned by the new crossing ndash have welcomed the progress being made.During the works the existing route has remained open to drivers, however all road users have been reminded about the -tonne weight restriction.Any vehicles which weigh more than this limit should use the ersion route, which goes via the A, A and B roads.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: One man campaign to safeguard cyclists
story: Allie Middletonfrom Balnakyle Road is concerned about the visibility of a cycle path which cuts through trees and merges with the east junction with Lochy Road and he is urging locals to campaign for improved awareness and traffic calming measures.ldquoI just happen to live opposite the cycle track. I would never be able to forgive myselfsomething happened and I hadnrsquot done something about it, said Mr Middleton.He is particularly concerned that many drivers do not know the cycle track is there because it is set back roughly  metres from the road, through the garden of the Green Drive Hall.Mr Middleton said when the cycle path was upgraded three years ago, a barrier was removed which had separated the path clearly from the road.There is now a sign at the end of the path before it meets the road, warning cyclists to dismount. But Mr Middleton said that the sign was being ignored and there was a danger at the bend where cyclists meet traffic.Speed reducing tables have been installed at the site, but Mr Middleton said: ldquoCars are going over the raised tables at mph and then drivers are putting the foot down in between them.He has reported his concerns to the council who carried out a survey in May last year. It revealed the average speed in the mph zone at the busiest time in the morning is .mph.He is now urging the council to instal signs to alert the drivers to the oncoming cyclists or a speed indicating devicewhich will show road users their speed.The path is used by pupils from Lochardil Primary, Inverness Royal Academy Holm Primary and the Gaelic school.Mr Middleton fears young people on the path may not be seen by fast moving vehicles: ldquoWe have crossed this road many times andin the company of two or four of my grandchildren this is more dficult, the main reason for this is in estimating the speed of accelerating vehicles since the tables were installed said Mr Middleton.A Highland Council spokeswoman said: ldquoA mph zone was recently installed in the Culduthel Lochardil area at the request of the community council. The scheme which encompasses Balnakyle Road includes appropriate signage and associated traffic calming features. Highland Council are monitoring speeds and will be making the police awarea persistent speeding problem is demonstrated. The concerns... will be investigated.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Site for Inverness homes not acceptable
story: Councillor Ken Gowans hit out at the application by agent Bracewell-Stirling for DMPM Services.He said the site was not zoned for housing and would pile pressure on local school rolls which are already well over  per cent capacity.ldquoWhile we need more affordable houses, any development must be part of the local plan, and this development is not.ldquoThis is likely to generate more unacceptable pressures on infrastructure which is already struggling to cope at the moment.ldquoWhile developers pay contributions towards education, it doesnrsquot change the fact that local schools are beyond full, and the councilrsquos school roll projections indicate these will worsen in the short to medium term, he said.Highlands MSP and road safety campaigner David Stewart also expressed some concern: ldquoI am mindful that the dual A will be at one side of this site and the rural B road will extend along another side of the site.ldquoAs it stands, this particular road has no pavement for pedestrians and this would be an issue that would cause me concern.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: aberdeen artist sets out to create large mosaic in aid of charity
story: A north-east artist has begun to collect mosaic pieces for an upcoming installation – and artwork has already been pledged from as far away as New Zealand.Maggie Patience, who owns Aboyne-based studio Pretty Rubbish Mosaics, creates a centrepiece for the North East Open Studiosevent each year.All the money raised goes towards supporting the Aberdeen-based Gathimba Edwards Foundation, which helps disadvantaged children in Kenya.This year, Maggie, , created a project called Art for the Heart, which aims to cover an ivy heart outside her studio in mosaics of birds and flowers.Since announcing the project on social media she has received items from as far afield as the USA and New Zealand.Maggie, who has owned her studio in Royal Deeside for the past  years, got involved with Gathimba Edwards after a friend went on the charity’s annual house-building trips to the African country.As well as constructing homes for families, the charity also supports children through accommodation, shelter, clothing and sustainable food.She said: “There’s people who have been working to improve lives in Kenya and I’m privileged to be a part of it.“They do amazing work and I can see where every penny is going.“I have no idea how many people will send things in but I’ve got at least  who have made or are making flowers or birds.“In previous years I’ve knitted flowers. I just had a lightbulb moment where I thought ‘why not have little mosaic flowers ’.Money raised over the past four years has gone towards ious projects run by Gathimba Edwards, even helping to purchase two cows, called Tinky Winky and Princess Henrietta, after Maggie’s pets who have passed away.Maggie said: “I’m just so grateful. I love sharing my passions. My workshops are informal and fun and my garden is full of wonderful, quirky items that people can come and see.“We give up a lot of time showing them around, an hour or so, so we askpeople can give a charity donation.“It’s the fourth time that I’m taking part in North East Open Studios.”Pieces can be submitted to the project any time between now and August, although the sooner they arrive, the better.They should be no bigger than cm and only decorated on one side, with a hole in them so they can be hung.For more information on what is required, and to contact Maggie, visit her website prettyrubbishmosaics. She can be contacted via Facebook at her page Pretty Rubbish Mosaic Art.

In this book she has more than one eye on the future, asking pertinent questions about the potential for land use and communities as Scotland#s looks ahead.Having been one of the driving forces behind the creation of the #Here We Are# community enterprise at Clachan, Cairndow, she practices what she preaches. Now a store for a wealth of local memory and knowledge, Here We Are # situated beside the Tree Shop # hosts a post office and much more besides. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: ayr united 2 inverness 3
story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. It’s a dficult one to take to get beat.They’re a big strong team and at times we didn’t cope with that.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrAyr NewsAyr United FC

title: bob shields national trust who
story: NewsBob Shields: National Trust owe an apology over asking people for donations to restore Burns CottageShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsBurns Cottage needs restoration"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailI’m trying to imagine the back-slapping and glad-handing at the National Trust For Scotland’s Hermiston Quay headquarters when someone came up with a spfing ‘Save Burns Cottage’ wheeze. “Let’s send out a begging letter to all those with Burns Cottage closest to their hearts – the people of Ayr . . .” “Wonderful idea!” “We could arrange for it to land on their doorsteps on Burns birthday – January  . . .” “That’s genius!” “Throw in some pictures of cracked walls and the dodgy thatched roof . . . “ “Fantastic!” “Use phrases like “before it’s too late” – or “damaged beyond repair” . . . “It’s heartbreaking!” “That’s Burns Cottage sorted then! Gin and tonic anyone ” “Large ones all round!” To be serious though – I still can’t decide what made me angrier. The crass begging bowl letter – hoping to cash in on the biggest Burns day of the year  Or the fact that Burns Cottage has been allowed to fall into such a state that phrases like “damaged beyond repair” are even necessary  If we’re talking man’s insensitivity to man here – then last Friday’s NTS letter takes the bannock! Its contents have upset dozens of people I know – and judging by the reaction on social media, hundreds more that I don’t know. Nicky Cotter wrote: “NTS . . . put your hands in your pockets and get it fixed. If you can spend pound, on a wooden tree house at Culzean Castle – you can stump up pound, to fix one of the most historically and culturally signicant buildings in Scotland”. Spot on, sir. The NTS letter tells us that “time and Scotland’s wet winters have taken their toll”. Yes – that’ll be the  winters since Burns father William Burness built the cottage on . And during that period, it’s been thatched more times than Wayne Rooney’s balding napper. If the current thatch “has signicant tears and has worn away”, you have to askthe last thatching work was in some way inferior - orthe cottage needed re-thatched several years ago and the work was never undertaken  You then start wondering how the auld clay biggin’ managed to survive the  wet Scottish winters between the cottage being built and the National Trust for Scotland’s formation back in   The answer is fairly obvious. Back then – people looked after it! And you only have to look at the recent row over the deteriorating Burns Monument to start wonderingthe NTS is the right custodian of our Burns heritage  Burns Cottage is everything Mr Cotter said earlier . .. and more. It’s the most important building in Ayrshire – by a lang Scots mile. Every nook, cranny - and twig of its roof - should be the subject of a fingertip, annual inspection. And whatever work is required – at whatever cost – should be sanctioned immediately. In fact, I imagine that’s what ‘most people’ thought was already happening. But then we had last Friday’s mail . . . when ‘most people’ discovered to their horror that the north-west gable is starting to pull away from the rest of the cottage! If admission fees don’t cover the cost of Burns Cottage – then put them up! The last figures I have show , visitors in . Charging them an extra p would have reached the pound, required – with enough left over to putty the windows as well. So, I’m sorry, NTS. But this was the wrong letter . . . to the wrong people . . . on the wrong day. You owe a lot of honest men and a lot of bonnie lassies an apology!Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr

title: brave mcdonalds worker hailed hero
story: NewsBrave McDonalds worker hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from fireLewis Macdonald, , battled back flames and thick smoke to save the le of Nan MarshallShareByAbi Smillie:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLewis saved the le of Nan Marshall. "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA brave McDonald’s worker has been hailed a hero after rescuing a gran from a burning home. Lewis Macdonald, , battled flames and thick smoke to save the le of granny-of-three Nan Marshall from a blaze which broke out in her living room. The sht manager was driving past -year-old Nan’s home on Castlehill Road in the early hours of New Year’s Eve when he saw flames flickering in the window. A Las Vegas neon sign – which Nan popped on for the festivities – had caught alight. Quick-thinking Lewis, along with pal Lauren Kennedy, sounded the alarm, got Nan to safety and dampened the fire with towels before the fire brigade arrived at the scene.Lewis told the Ayrshire Post : “The whole night was a blur.“We were driving back from work and I saw a fire in the window. “I was chapping on the door and ringing the doorbell. “The full house was covered in black smoke. “I couldn’t see anything. “I didn’t know how long the firemen were going to take and the house was still on fire so I thought I needed to do something. “Nan was shook up about it. “I was trying to get into the kitchen because Nan said there were towels at the washing machine. “They were pretty damp so I just threw them over it. “After we put the fire out, we sat on the wall and waited for thefiremen. They had a big extractor fan and they were trying to get all the smoke out.“It had even got upstairs, the firefighters said.” Nan was upstairs sleeping at the time unaware as to what was going on. She said: “I wondered what it was. “I could hear the doorbell and by this time the smoke alarm kicked in. “Luckily I woke and came down the stairs and there was my hero at the door. “Buthe hadn’t of been here I would’ve been a goner with the smoke alone. “Even now, anything you touch you’re covered in black soot. “I was in a state of shock. “The table caught fire and the windowsill. “I had to go to the doctor two or three days later because I kept wheezing.” Daughter Lesley Watson, , added: “It could’ve been so much worse –Lewis just caught it in time. “If that young man hadn’t been passing, she wouldn’t be here today.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyr NewsAyr

title: driver who sped 70mph through
story: NewsDriver who sped at mph through streets of Troon is jailed for  monthsMark Kirkby almost killed his passenger when he finally crashed into a wall following the high speed chase.ShareByAyrshire Post:,  FEB NewsMark Kirkby was jailed for the reckless driving"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who drove like a maniac through the streets of Troon has been jailed for  months, writes Edwin Lawrence. Mark Kirkby, , almost killed passenger Kerrie Anne Monaghan when he finally crashed into a wall. Miss Monaghan was in Ayr Sherf Court on crutches to hear the sentence on her partner, who she is standing by. The court heard Kirkby did not even have a driving licence and Sherf John Montgomery banned him from holding one for four years. Depute fiscal Lindsay Bain told the court police spotted a silver Volvo being driven erratically from Barassie Street into Portland Street. The police car’s blue lights went on and Kirkby initially slowed down before increasing speed. He was hitting mph in Templehill before heading into Harbour Road. And Kirkby’s car was said to have taken off as he drove across a mini roundabout into Port Ranald Drive. He hit mph in North Shore Road, eventually crashing into a wall at the Beach Road Kilmarnock Road junction in Barassie. During the whole episode, which began around .am on October  last year, Kirkby drove dangerously through junctions and swerved round corners.  When the crash occurred the car’s airbags were deployed but this did not prevent Ms Monaghan’s horric injuries. She had to be cut out of the car by firefighters and suffered numerous fractures to her face, head, body and limbs. “Kerrie Anne Monaghan is very lucky to be alive,” said fiscal Ms Bain. The court also heard of offences committed by Kirkbywhose address was given as Barlinnie Prison, on June . This time he was in a grey Ford Mondeo around .am when police spotted the car stationary on the A near the Pennyburn Roundabout. Kirkby was unsteady on his feet and slurring his speech, although a breath test proved negative. A a blood test found substances identied as cocaine and benzocaine. Defence lawyer Hugh Duncan said Kirkby’s relationship with Ms Monaghan was still ongoing. “He accepts full responsibility,” said the lawyer. “He comes across as remorseful to the injuries his partner suffered and to potential harm he could have done to others.” Mr Duncan said Kirkby had been remanded in custody since October , had undergone a detox programme, and had come to a realisation of his mental health issues. Sherf John Montgomery told Kirkby: “You drove dangerously at high speed for an extended period. I see no option but a custodial sentence.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnHMP BarlinnieVolvoAyrCourtsJusticeTroon

title: elliots prestwick evolve rebrand vics
story: NewsElliots in Prestwick to "evolve" with rebrand as Vics  The VineBosses at Buzzworks say the bar and restaurant must "evolve" as part of its transformation.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  FEB NewsBuzzworks managing director, Kenny Blair, is promising bold changes at Elliots "Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of Ayrshire’s biggest hospitality venues has closed for a “complete transformation”. Elliots in Prestwick will be given a new brand and feature live sport and entertainment seven days a week. The bar and restaurant shut its doors on Sunday, with bosses planning to reopen at Easter as Vic’s  The Vine. Buzzworks, who have operated Elliots as their flagship in the town, say the rebrand will be split into two halves. Managing director Kenny Blair said: “It’s essential to evolve within the hospitality industry and look at innovative ways to create new and exciting concepts for our customers. “Our work to reincarnate Elliots is part of our wider growth strategy, both benefiting the local community and Scotland’s hospitality industry.” Vic’s  The Vine will feature a -cover restaurant called The Vine serving food from breakfast until late. The bar will be called Vic’s and will be a “modern take on a traditional bar”, featuring sport and entertainment. Weekend opening hours will remain at .am.  Designer Jim Hamilton is leading the project, which will include a new glass roof in part of the bar. A new kitchen boasting a churrasco BBQ pit is also planned. Bosses say Vic’s will be the first venue in Ayrshire to serve fresh, unpasteurised tank beer straight from the brewery. Kenny added: “We’ve seen an appetite in the industry for more cool and modern pubs and, similarly to our T-Bar in Ayr, Vic’s will be a traditional bar with a twist. “This will both suit the local market and sit alongside our excellent new restaurant offering in Prestwick. “Our vision is to create the best day-to-night venue in Scotland and we are confident Vic’s  The Vine will match those expectations.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnAyrPrestwickAyr News

title: former royal hotel ayr sold
story: NewsFormer Royal Hotel in Ayr is sold at auctionBuilding is branded the most dangerous in the townShareByGary Fanning:,  FEB NewsRoyal Hotel Ayr"Get daily updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe former Royal Hotel, which has been described as the most dangerous building in Ayr, has been sold at auction. The iconic property, near Ayr Central, went under the hammer last Thursday. Wilsons Auctions Land and property sales executive, Lorren Mullen were managing the auction of the ex hotel. The three and a half storey building, which has lain empty for more than  years, consists of two commercial shop units on the ground floor and sandstone units above is located on Kyle Street. It had a guide price of pound,. A spokesman for Wilsons Auctions Land  Property Sales, said: “Unfortunately we cannot disclose any further detail on this property in terms of the identity of the purchaser or the sale price . “However this figure will be disclosed by the Registers of Scotland and the Ei Group in the coming months.” In May, the Post reported how plans to knock it down and turn it into a gym were rejected by councillors. Builders Dawn Developments wanted to build a new block in its place to home a gym and shops. But the plan was cut short as council planners want the hotel preserved or refurbished instead. And the sale happened after concerns about the safety of the former hotel were discussed at this month’s Fort, Seafield, and Wallacetown Community Council held at Ayr Town Hall. One community councillor said: “It is the most dangerous building in Ayr. ” It wasn’t the only empty building t discussed at the meeting. The meeting heard how young people were putting themselves in danger by gaining access to Belleisle House One said: ”If we can show concern then the council can take action and step in..” And the meeting was told how youngsters were “masquerading around” Strathdoon House.
