story: Our front page article about Karen Thomson Hickson#s journey through bone marrow donation, is eye-opening and inspirational.Karen gave her donation in  not knowing the identity of the recipient or even where in the world he lived.Almost five years later, she learned that her actions directly saved the le of a man from Canada, suffering from an acute form of leukemia.The recipient would undoubtedly not be alive today without her bone marrow donation but is now living a normal, healthy le.There are constant appeals from families desperate for donors to join registers in the chance they may be a match with sick relatives.Just this week the family of nine-year-old Chloe Purvis from Fort William,  diagnosed with a rare form of cancer, appealed for people to join registers such as DKMS.Most people would accept these donations, so why are so few willing to give them

title: letter kintyre needs a modern connectivity system
story: The Scottish Government is seeking views on the proposed future Glasgow to Campbeltown air service prior to it being retendered.I have discussed this specic issue with friends and we have concerns about the current unreliable ferry, air services and road link.We believe we should receive at the very least the same air service as provided to the island of Islay.We have the following thoughts on improvements to encourage new businesses to locate here and to promote tourism.We would like a larger Saab  or equivalent aircraft that can land in more adverse weather conditions # we understand the economies of scale and suggest a service that can fly to Campbeltown and then on to Islay, back to Campbeltown and ing to Glasgow, or vice versa.We would like the reinstatement of the radar system to assist landings in adverse weather conditions.As there is a separate service between Islay and Edinburgh we suggest that Campbeltown should be included as we also have key tourist attractions such as distilleries and three fantastic -hole golf courses and high-standard accommodation.We would like to see the service continue with a timetable with low ticket prices to allow the full day in Glasgow for NHS appointments, business and shopping trips and the reinstatement of seven days a week flights to enhance business and tourism.In addition, we want national advertising campaigns inclusive of timetables to promote the area for increased passenger numbers, including weekend breaks.These aspirations are very much in keeping with the council’s Community Plan Single Outcome Agreement   in particular relating to National Policy Priorities i.e. economic recovery, growth and employment.We are also very much aware of organisations which have worked hard to promote the long-term outcomes in the Community Plan.The communities of Kintyre need a modern connectivity system, fit for purpose,this area is to have any credibility in the big wide world.Decent flight connections to the major hubs of Glasgow and Edinburgh would be a start.I have confirmed the Scottish Government is collecting views andyou would like to help improve our air service and have additional comments or suggestions, I urge you to email them to: Michael.Bratcher@transport. gov.scotAndrew Hemmings,

title: more options for senior students at cgs
story: Parents of young people at Campbeltown Grammar Schoolhad their say on proposals to give senior pupils the opportunity to study a wider choice of subjects.At an open information evening last week, head teacher David Fyfe updated parents on the progress the school has made since its HM inspection last year, and spoke about plans to increase the number of subjects currently on offer, as suggested by inspectors.In order to provide six subjects in the senior phase, the school is considering increasing the number of periods in the week to seven a day.Consultation with pupils and staff began in August last year, and Mr Fyfe emphasised how much the opinions of parents are valued in the process.The school is looking at a choice of two new timetable models: Monday to Friday with seven periods, giving  periods a week or three days a week with seven periods and two days a week with six, giving  periods a week.At the moment, there are  periods a week.In addition to the timetable change, S and S students will maximise their time in school instead of being able to #sign out#.Pupils will be encouraged to study additional subjects, assist junior students in class, and volunteer in the community to gain Saltire Awards.Special arrangements will still be possible to enable other wider achievements such as gaining a driving licence.Mr Fyfe said: #We want our young people to make the best use of their time at school and gain valuable experiences which will benefit them when they leave.#S and S pupils will soon be required to give their initial option choices to allow the school to judge demand for each subject, although these will not be final.Mr Fyfe also shared the results of a parents and partners survey on the school#s visions and values and #rights respecting schools# charter.He said: #So far we have had  responses but there is still time for you to let us hear your views.#We really value input from parents so it is vital that as many people as possible come forward and make their opinions known.#The survey showed that . per cent of parents felt that the school#s aims, outlined in last week#s Courier, either fully capture what is important to the school, or capture it well.The survey also found, however, that . per cent of those who responded felt that they had #not been involved at all# with the development of the school#s vision and values, while . per cent felt they had not been involved in the development of the new curriculum.#That is what these consultations are about,# Mr Fyfe said, #these figures can certainly be improved but onlymore people take part.#The survey on changes to the structure of the curriculum and school day is open until February  and people are urged to take part by visiting https:bit.ly title: pupils scottish tribute in honour of burns
story: The school was packed with visitors for an afternoon of entertainment and refreshments last Thursday in honour of Scotland#s national bard.Despite there being less than  children involved in the production, the school hall was packed.The pupils, ranging from pre-five to P, recited Burns poetry, performed songs and even put on a mini pantomime.George, in P, sported a tartan shirt as he carried the haggis into the room but later, after a change of clothes, was transformed into the bard himself to give an extensive and humorous immortal memory off by heart.Another stand-out performance came from P Ashley, who seemed destined for the stage during her performance of My Hoggie, while Taylor in P not only performed the address to the haggis with no prompts but also displayed her footwork in the sword dance.The afternoon culminated in a performance of The Three Wee Pigs, a Scottish twist on the classic The Three Little Pigs tale with the added edition of Wee Reid Ridin# Hood, also known as Little Red Riding Hood.After a demonstration, the youngsters invited their family, friends and members of the public to join them in dancing the Dashing White Sergeant.Everybody linked arms and sang Auld Lang Syne to bring the afternoon to a traditional close.

title: thought for the week february 1 2019
story: February  marks the midpoint of winter, half way between the shortest day and the spring equinox.For Christians it has a particularly special meaning as it was  days after the birth of Jesus and the day when, according to Jewish custom, his grateful parents took him to the temple to give thanks to God.We believe that Jesus is the light of the world who will guide us through our own dark times.Many customs have grown around Candlemas and one of the most interesting came from Scotland.In the olden days, Candlemas was the day when children brought candles to school so that the classrooms would have light on dull days.As time went on, gas lighting took over from candlelight and the children brought money to school with which the teacher was supposed to buy sweets for the children.The child who brought in the most money was declared Candlemas King or Queen and they ruled for six weeks.They had the power to make one whole afternoon a week a playtime and to excuse anyone they wished from any form of punishment.I don#t think this will catch on in Argyll!I think it is a lovely custom to take a child to church or temple for a blessing and to give thanks to God for their birth.I have the privilege of being chaplain to two primary schools and while I cannot take the children physically to church or temple, I take each one of them to God every day in my prayers to give thanks for them and ask God#s blessing upon them.

title: wee toon dancer is set for the stage
story: A Campbeltown woman who took her first steps into the world of dance with Footnotes Dance Company will perform in her first professional show at Glasgow Royal Concert Hall.Morgan Irwin, , who is in the final year of her BADance course at Performing Art Studio Scotland , will join three West End stars in the fth annual Movies to Musicals production on Friday February .Morgan will dance, act and sing in her role in the musical theatre cast, supporting stars Kerry Ellis, John Owen Jones and Lucy Kay in the Glasgow Philharmonia Orchestra production.After leaving Campbeltown Grammar School and Footnotes behind, Morgan moved to Glasgow where she gained NC, HNC and HND qualications, before moving to Edinburgh to study at PASS, one of the only places in Scotland to teach dance to degree level.She studies ballet, jazz and contemporary dance, as well as choreography, teaching and dance science.Despite never professionally singing, a friend convinced her to audition for the Movies to Musicals role.#I was apprehensive as I had to prepare a song as part of the audition,# Morgan said. #I have always just danced and done bits of acting but never singing, but I went along anyway and was successful.#When she s to Campbeltown, Morgan holds dance classes for nursery, primary and secondary school children.She said: #The classes aren’t one set style, I change it up every time. They’re mostly jazz funk where I do fun dance games, introduction to the basic technique of dance, as well as learning routines and basic gymnastics skills.#Morgan says that after she graduates in June, her #perfect scenario# would be to start a professional dance contract in September, somewhere like India or on a cruise ship, adding: #As long as I’m dancing or teaching dance I’ll be living my dream job!#Morgan Irwin will perform in the fth annual #Movies to Musicals#. title: landslip-forces-closure-of-section-of-popular-john-muir-way-path
story: The John Muir Way, which links Dunbar to Helensburgh on Scotlandrsquos west coast, was opened in April .However, a section of it in Dunbar has been closed following the landslip, which is believed to have been caused by a burst pipe, with East Lothian Council now looking to carry out repairs.The section of the walk affected is from the townrsquos swimming pool to the war memorial, with walkers urged instead to head along Bayswell Park, rather than following the clftop trail.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed they were aware of the issue.She said: "Specialist engineers will be coming out to make an assessment and to see what can be done."They will then give us an idea of costings and whether it could be done sooner or later."Until the engineers carry out their assessment, there is no timescale on when the path could be re-opened.

title: plan-to-ban-lorries-from-section-of-a1-in-high-winds
story: Amey, which maintains the road network for Transport Scotland, has confirmed it is drawing up plans to introduceweather-related ersions for HGVs and high-sided vehicles between Dunbar and Haddington.The move follows a string of incidents in which lorries have been blown over as they cross the exposed Tyne Bridge, near East Linton, in high winds.Chief Inspector Steven Duncan, police commander for East Lothian, said he raised concerns after two such incidents last year.The section of the A has seen several incidents during bad weather when lorries have been blown on to their sides, leading to the route being closed and ersions introduced from Thistly Cross Roundabout at Dunbar to Haddington.Under the new proposals, that ersion, which uses the old A and the A, would be automatically brought into force when winds were recorded at above mph.It would take lorries on a near-parallel single-carriage route which is the sameas the .-mile section of A they are being erted from.The chief inspector told a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos Police and Fire Community Safety Committee he had made tackling the dangers on the route a priority.He said: ldquoThere is a wind management plan in place. I have been concerned that two vehicles were blown over last year at the Tyne Bridge.ldquoWe have identied a nice, easy ersion to implement and are looking to have a plan in place to drive that forward.Transport Scotland said it had asked Amey to look into the proposals, which could see permanentsigns in place to advise lorry drivers when they should use the ersion.A spokesperson for Amey said: ldquoThe Tyne Wind Management Plan is being developed following a number of incidents of high-sided vehicles being blown over near to the Tyne Bridge. The development of this plan has been prioritised after discussion with police.ldquoAs a vulnerable location, the plan proposes implementing a ersion for HGVs and other high-sided vehicles when wind gusts are in excess of mph.ldquoThe route being used is a standard agreed ersion, using the A and the old A, which runs parallel to the A expressway.Last year, an HGV lorry driver was disqualied from driving for two years and fined pound, after he ignored a ban on high-sided vehicles crossing the Forth Road Bridge during gales and his vehicle was blown over, blocking it for  hours.

title: plans-to-build-houses-near-to-prestonpans-railway-station
story: LAR Housing Trust is aiming to create the new properties, which could be in place by spring next year, in a similar style to their recently-completed development in nearby Cockenzie.The development, which is being considered by East Lothian Council, would be created on the site of the former Lothian Coated Fabrics building and next to the eastbound  at the neighbouring railway station.LAR Housing Trust, which is an affordable housing provider, plans to create affordable housing on the site, which it will operate as  per cent affordable mid-market rent.Plans with the local authorityrsquos planning department note that the scheme would be ldquosimilar to the  flats at the Boatyard, Cockenzie Harbour.Dunfermline-based LAR Housing Trust said that the existing development had ldquoproven to be successful and well received by East Lothian Council, the local community and new residents.The design and access statement, which makes up part of the new planning application for the Prestonpans proposal, reads: ldquoThe Cockenzie Harbour site required high-quality design with traditional features and local character, linking into the surrounding area and conservation area.ldquoThese details fit equally well at this site in Prestonpans, bringing character in keeping with the traditional features of the railway station and adjacent housing.Nineteen of the flats, title: wallyford-primary-school-open-day-hailed-a-resounding-success
story: Alister Hadden praised the parent council, which organised the event on Saturday, as everyone enjoyed a trip down memory lane.School photographs from the s to the present day were on display at the Salters Road school as staff and pupils prepare to move into a new pound. million facility being built to cope with the influx of new housing in the area.Mr Hadden said that visitors of all ages queued for the opening of the school doors at .am, adding: ldquoThere was a constant steady flow of people and families, along with former teachers, to see the vast amount of photos that were on display.The photos also featured the former Crookston School, which closed in  .Mr Hadden, a former Crookston pupil, added: ldquoOn display were also trophies with many of the former pupilsrsquo names on them.ldquoPeople got the opportunity to take a trip around the school to see their old classroom, in some cases for the first time in  years. Visitors also enjoyed coffee, soft drinks, cake and biscuits served by members of the parent council.ldquoThe open day gave dozens of people the opportunity to meet classmates they had not seen for numerous years.ldquoThey all thoroughly enjoyed catching up with each other and many iniduals took along their own photos of their memories at Wallyford over the decades.The open day was also supported by local councillors and keen photographer Angus Bathgate, from Wallyford, who caught the event on camera for posterity.Mr Hadden said: ldquoAll the organisers and those who contributed with memorabilia are to be congratulated for all their hard work, time and effort in bringing this event together.ldquoThanks also to everyone who came and supported this Wallyford Primary School open day, making it such a memorable, successful occasion before its doors close.Pauline Clark, parent council representative, said: ldquoWhat a day it was. There were so many stories and so many happy people. It was a great success.Ward councillor Kenny McLeod added: ldquoI attended P at Wallyford Primary School as I stayed on Salters Road before moving to Tranent.ldquoI played in the grounds of the school as I grew up and kept being chased by the janitor whose house looked on to the school. The children and teachers of Wallyford Primary will be super excited and looking forward to the attending the new school.The existing school will soon close and move to the new building, which is nearing completion on the outskirts of the village on Futurersquos Way at the St Clements Wells development.The Wallyford school project has received a pound. million grant from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Schools for the Future scheme.The new school comes amid the construction of , new houses in the Wallyford area, while the council is minded to grant planning permission for another  homes at Dolphingstone to the east of the existing site, subject to conclusion of the relevant legal agreements.

title: fundraisers-set-to-climb-mount-kilimanjaro-in-memory-of-vera-cameron
story: Nine men and women jet off to Tanzania todayas they bid to raise thousands of pounds for Cancer Research UK in memory of Macmerryrsquos Vera Cameron.Among the fundraisers getting ready to climb Mount Kilimanjaro are her husband Dougie and daughter Laura-Jane.Dougie said: ldquoWersquove spoken about doing Kilimanjaro for years so wersquore really excited to finally be able to take on the challenge. I would also like to thank the team for taking part year after year, covering costs themselves and giving up their weekends to train.Dougie, who is site attendant at Kinwegar Recycling Centre, by Wallyford, will be joined by seven colleagues from East Lothian Council, where Vera worked as senior administrator in transportation at the local authority.Ray Montgomery , Paul Ritchie , Lorraine Faulds , William Kelley , Stuart Baxter , Rachael Cormackand Vanessa Sanalare also taking on the challenge. The team will attempt to reach the summit and descend the near-,-metre peak in just seven days. As well as the climb and adjusting to the altitude, the fundraisers will also have to deal with extreme temperatures, ranging from degC to -degC.Vera was  when she died from cancer in August . She attended the villagersquos primary school before studying at Ross High School, Tranent, and later joined East Lothian District Council.Following her death, fundraisers have been held each year in aid of Maggiersquos Centres, Macmillan Cancer Support and Cancer Research UK.In previous years, fundraisers have completed other gruelling challenges, including the West Highland Way, which stretches from Milngavie to Fort William , and climbed the highest peaks in Scotland, England and Wales ndash Ben Nevis, Scafell Pike and Snowdon.Along the way, they have raised pound,, with pound, now the target.Donate at justgiving fundraising vera-kilimanjaro

title: union-calls-east-lothian-councils-severe-weather-policy-disgraceful
story: East Lothian Council reviewed its adverse weather policy following criticism of its advice in the wake of last yearrsquos lsquoBeast from the Eastrsquo snow storm.However, its new policy insists the council ndash which has , employees ndash will continue to dock the pay of workers who cannot get to workstorms hit.And it suggests those living in rural areas ldquomay wish to consider holding back some of their annual leave for events such as adverse weather.Councillor Jeremy Findlay , North Berwick Coastal ward, told a meeting of the councilrsquos cabinet on Tuesday: ldquoI have a moral problem with someone who lives in the rural county where roads are under two feet of snow being adversely affected when they are being told by police they should not travel and, as a result, their wages will be docked.While Raising his concerns about the revised policy, Mr Findlay said: ldquoI have a moral problem with someone who lives in the rural county where roads are under two feet of snow being adversely affected when they are being told by police they should not travel and as a result their wages will be docked.Gillian McKay, Unite regional industrial officer, said: ldquoThe decision by East Lothian Council is disgraceful.ldquoThe Scottish Government has issued guidance on this for all employers advising there should not be any compromise on the health, safety and wellbeing of workers.ldquoEvery allowance should be made for workers who cannot make work due to severe weather conditions. This includes working from home and flexible working practices to ensure that nobody should lose pay or holidays.ldquoThe move by East Lothian appears to be nothing other than an exercise in saving money and will not go unchallenged.At Tuesdayrsquos meeting in Haddington, the councilrsquos chief executive Angela Leitch told councillors thatstaff could not fulfil their contract, the council ldquocould not pay them.Anger over the way the council handled last yearrsquos severe snow storms led councillors to overturn a long-standing policy on absences and agree to pay workers who had been unable to get into work.Many workers were stunned to be told that, while police were warning people to stay at home, the council was continuing with its established policy advising them they would have to take time in lieu or unpaid leave to cover the time they were unable to work.While other local authorities, including City of Edinburgh Council, took to social media to assure staff they would be paidthey were unable to work during the Wednesday and Thursday of the red weather warnings last March, East Lothian Council repeated its advice that workers should report to workit was ldquosafe to do so, or attend the nearest council office or suitable premises, or work from home or other suitable locations.Following a review, wages were reinstated for those who missed work during red weather warnings and the policy was reviewed.Councillor Willie Innes , council leader, said he expected that, should another Beast from the East hit the county, councillors would once again step in to ensure wages were not docked.He said: ldquoIt is impossible to have a policy that pleases everyone. Last year, members took the decision to pay staff ndash I would hopeit happened again we would consider making similar commitments.South of Scotland list MSP Michelle Ballantynecondemned the policy, saying: ldquoIt is completely unacceptable for East Lothian Council to tell their employees to save their holiday time in case of bad weather. It beggars belief that any employer would be this unreasonable. I will be writing to Willie Innes about how deeply unfair his cabinet have been to hardworking council staff.A statement issued on Wednesday by Ms Leitch, the councilrsquos chief executive, said: ldquoThe policy has been refreshed following last yearrsquos severe wintry weather.ldquoThe updated policy reflects feedback following staff consultation, and is consistent with the approach taken by many other public sector organisations.ldquoIt reflects the councilrsquos commitment to protecting the health and safety of all employees, while minimising disruption and maintaining key public services where possible.ldquoIt recognises that employees may periodically face dficulties in attending work during periods of severe weather, or some other adverse event. The policy makes it clear that staff should only travelit is safe to do so.ldquoThe updated policy contains additional advice for staff on what to do in such unusual circumstances.ldquoThe key aspect of the updated policy is to stress the importance of Business Continuity Plans for each council service which advise on what employees should do in any adverse event ndash including potential alternative working arrangements for employeesthey canrsquot get to their normal place of work.ldquoThis includes working remotely or being deployed near to where they live as an alternative.

title: tims-tales-through-the-keyhole
story: RECENTLY a friend and fellow storyteller with his family took me and my family on a simple but stunning walk along the shoreline of Dunbar. It was a cold day but my friend, who is skilled in bushcraft, had brought his portable fire pit with him.We searched for drtwood and sat by the fire, roasting marshmallows and warming our hands. It was a short walk but dramatic rock formations loomed above us, making it feel like a real adventure. The kids climbed them and explored the rocky beach, where once there had been an open-air bathing pool.On our , we went through a small tunnel-like arch. I stopped for a moment, suddenly taken by the view. The ruins of Dunbar Castle were beautully framed by the archway. Locals call this archway the keyhole and I reflected that the term is a perfect name.When we look through a keyhole, our vision is narrowly focussed. Such was the effect here. It cast a visual spotlight on what is left of what was once a mighty fortress.The kids trundled on before me, noticing smaller wonders: a frozen worm on the path, a sea shell and interesting-looking stones. But I stood for some moments, taking in the view beyond and thinking of what stories those old stones of the castle could tell.Many people pass this way every day, both locals and visitors. Itrsquos a section of the John Muir Way. I have often been with my family to Dunbar Leisure Pool and the harbour and town. But somehow I had missed this short but spectacular nearby walk until this day.Dunbar Castle is now but a fallen-down ruin. Indeed, itrsquos dficult to imagine what it once was. But the weathered sandstone castles on the shoreline built by nature still stand defiant, somehow reminding us of their greater permanence in the face of human transience. But as I stood looking at the ruins, the keyhole focussed my thoughts as well as my vision.History is also viewed through a keyhole, a very narrow one. The lives and events of the castle were lived in most part unrecorded by it. The spotlight of history has illuminated only brief moments, and even then the characters have been only those deemed lsquoimportantrsquo.There are moments where the view through the narrow keyhole of history has included insights to untold stories. The bravery of Black Agnes, as she defied the siege in , is one of those. With her husband away, she was in charge of this important fortress during war with England. She refused to give up the castle, even in the face of bombardment and attempts to starve her small garrison into submission. Her mocking of her besiegers by dusting down the battlements with her maids after a bombardment is an image seared in legend.But itrsquos a chink of light on a huge untold story we are led to believe by historyrsquos silence that women were insignicant players in events. For sure they were oppressed and put down by a system that centred on male power, but they are half of humanity and at least half the story.As the actions of Black Agnes reveal, even with such constraints put on them, women were there, part of events and often refusing to accept their assigned role.The le of Mary Queen of Scots has always been for me an example of this. Yes, she was privileged and powerful by birth, but because of this history took notice of her.Despite all the political and religious challenges she faced, it was her womanhood which men deemed her main failing. And so she was judged by dferent standards. Had she behaved with the morals of her father she would not have lasted five minutes in power. But no one raised an eyebrow because he was a man.But more than this, even though Mary was the monarch, her royal authority was deemed diluted and even less legitimate merely because she was a woman.So she understood she needed to find a husband to bring her royal authority to full strength in a country full of powerful and bullying misogynist men.She chose the dashing young Darnley, and the fact that he turned out to be dross was not, in my opinion, Maryrsquos fault. How easy it is to blame a woman for a manrsquos failings. She was taken in by him it was he who was the failure, not her.Thatrsquos what Irsquove always maintained, despite the protestations of my tutors at university. And her third husband Bothwell, well he was a disappointment as well.It is the stones of Dunbar,they could speak, who could tell us of the truth of his forced union with Mary. She had been taken there by him in April . The circumstances of this still remain debated. Was she abducted by him as later claimed, or did she go willingly It was also claimed she was raped and forced to marry Bothwell soon afterwards to save her honour . This idea has been disputed by some because Mary is said to have miscarried with twins while imprisoned at Lochleven Castle some months after, suggesting a relationship with Bothwell even before Darnleyrsquos murder. So a woman cannot be abused by a man she has had a relationship with  Really If they could talk, the stones of Dunbar would whisper the truths of those events in , and the despair and desperation of a strong and clever woman whose destiny was stolen mainly because of her sex.These were my thoughts as I stood looking through the keyhole towards Dunbar Castle. Suddenly, my daughter Manja broke my trance by wiggling the frozen worm in front of me. I smiled and thought to myself that thankfully times have changed since the days when the castle was a fortress.But sometimes, I fear, not as much as we think they have.

title: new-fidra-gin-hoping-for-east-lothian-base
story: Fidra Gin is the brainchild of Emma Bouglet and Jo Brydie and is currently based at Ballencrieff and Aviemore.The duo came together to create the juniper berry-based drink and have already enjoyed immediate success, with the product already available in a number of Edinburgh restaurants.Now they are hoping to make it  per cent based in the county, with plans under way to find suitable premises.Emma said: ldquoWe pick all the botanicals in East Lothian and, at the moment, we use a still in Aviemore.ldquoA friend has lent us his still for the time being so we can get enough momentum behind us and bring the whole operation to East Lothian.ldquoWe have potentially secured a premise in East Lothian. We are hoping to purchase a couple of stills so the whole operation is based in East Lothian.ldquoWe have had health and safety out and given it the go-ahead but there are a few bits and pieces to be sorted.The duo aim to have the new distillery open before the end of the year.Before Christmas, Emma and Jo, , were in the process of getting more than  bottles ready.Emma was delighted to say that had proven a great success, with the bottles selling out within a matter of hours after they were launched.Since then, more than  bottles have been produced and sold.Emma said their Scottish dry gin was ldquovery botanical and added: ldquoIt is quite a smooth gin, with a hint of sea buckthorn.The move into the gin business is something of a departure from their day jobs, with the duo aiming to make it their full-time business.Emma used to work as an investment banker before switching to becoming a childminder, while Jo runs her freelance podiatry from Longniddry, occasionally working in the local clinic, and before then she worked at Musselburgh Racecourse.Emma, , said: ldquoMe and Jo have known each other for years. title: well-known-late-haddington-resident-to-be-honoured-with-street-name
story: Vera Ingle ndash who passed away in  ndash was well-known in Haddington for her fundraising efforts for good causes.Now, East Lothian Council has confirmed that Vera Ingle Grove will make up part of the townrsquos new Letham Mains development.Her son Charles felt his mum was a very worthy choice.He said: ldquoWe are delighted, absolutely delighted.ldquoI had an indication it would be Vera Ingle Grove sometime ago and I know the idea was put forward by the community council, who have done a great job.ldquoThe response has been quite overwhelming and it has been lovely to see a lot of what has been said on social media.More than  new homes are being built on the townrsquos western edge as part of the development, which will also include a new primary school.Mr Ingle, a former Haddington councillor, said: ldquoThe reality is a lot of people knew my mother. She was a community person and that is quite important to a lot of people.ldquoSometimes we forget about community or scoff at it, but a lot of people still think it is important.ldquoShe to some extent exemplied the good qualities associated with that and the work she did within the town for local and national charities.Vera, who had six children,  grandchildren and four great-granddaughters, was most associated with raising funds for the poppy appeal.However, she also helped raise money for the day centre, Haddington Pipe Band, Red Cross and to fight multiple sclerosis among others.Previously, Mr Ingle said: ldquoThere is not a charity in the town, from the day centre to any other, that did not benefit from her.John Hamilton, treasurer of the community council, previously asked members of the public for key figures in Haddingtonrsquos history who could have streets named after them.He said: ldquoVera was one of lersquos endearing characters, known by many with her time in the Corn Exchange and her charity fundraising with her collection box out on the streets. Irsquom sure her family, friends and everyone  who knew her will be proud of this recognition.Ward councillor Tom Trotter was similarly pleased with the announcement.He said: ldquoIf we are going to be naming streets after people, real people who made a dference in the community, then she certainly did that on numerous occasions.ldquoShe was a bit of a character and it is fantastic that she will be recognised in this manner.ldquoI think it is only right we remember people from the past but also it is right to celebrate people that made a dference presently.Provost John McMillan added: ldquoMany people in Haddington will have fond memories of Vera and her extensive charity fundraising efforts and involvement in many of the townrsquos clubs and organisations.ldquoNaming new streets in recognition of former residents offers some continuity in the growing town and will hopefully inspire some of our newer residents to find out more of Haddingtonrsquos history and community le.

title: great-grandmother-who-ran-drem-post-office-pens-her-life-story
story: May Fairbairn, who was born in Orkney but went to school in Morham, decided to write the story of her le to ensure her great grandchildren knew all about her.The -year-old spent three months putting together Neeps, Horses and Parcels, which is available to buy at Kesleyrsquos bookshop, Haddington.She said: ldquoWhat inspired me was I had thought about doing it for about  years.ldquoI now have four great-grandchildren and I am .ldquoIt was to have something left for my great grandchildren.ldquoMy great grandmother ndash I would have loved to have known what she did. It has really taken off beyond what I ever thought it would.Mrs Fairbairnrsquos family are originally from Orkney however, they moved to the mainland when she was four with her father John Robson finding work in Midlothian and then moving to East Lothian.Despite her long time away from Orkney, Mrs Fairbairn, who ran the Post Office in Drem for more than  years, where she now stays, felt the islands and East Lothian were very much home.Away from the Post Office, she also taught at The Compass School in Haddington, and volunteered at the townrsquos Roodlands Hospital, as well as at Appin Equestrian Centre, near Drem, which is run by her daughter Anne.She said: ldquoI have a lot of self-belief in myself and a lot of determination, which I inherited from my father. I was just looking for the next opportunity.Already, the autobiography has proven popular with family members, including daughters Anne and Fiona.Throughout writing the book, May kept it a secret from her family but was pleased to say it had met with a positive reception.May added her family were ldquovery proud and said: ldquoThey have been very, very supportive and my grandson and everyone, they have all been behind me.ldquoThey thought it was a marvellous surprise to them all.However, it was after retiring from running the Post Office that May decided tolsquohomersquo and to visit Orkney.She said: ldquoWhen I go up there, I feel Orkney is home.ldquoThere is just something that tells me thatI had not been widowed, I would certainly be up running a bed and breakfast.

title: woman-left-shaken-after-being-flashed-at-by-three-youths-in-underpass
story: Police are appealing for witnesses following the incident at about .pm on the A underpass, near Meadowmill Sports Centre, which left the victim "very shaken".The woman was walking towards Prestonpans from the Tranent area when she came across a group of about  youths - both males and females - aged between  and  years old.As she continued to walk through the underpass, three youths approached her and exposedthemselves at her.The victim was uninjured and fled from the scene. Officers are now appealing for witnesses and anyone with information is asked to come forward.Inspector Kevin Sinclair from Dalkeith Police Station said: ldquoThis has been a frightening experience for the victim who was thankfully uninjured but understandably very shaken by the ordeal.ldquoThis sort of behaviour is completely unacceptable. I would ask anyone who witnessed the group of youths in this area last night, or the incident in the underpass, to come forward to help with our investigation.ldquoAnyone who may be able to identy those involved, or have any information to help us trace them, should call us as soon as possible.The first suspect is described as white, ft ins tall, about  years old, of medium build with blond hair that had curls at the front. He was wearing black tracksuit bottoms, trainers and a black hoodie.The second is described as a white male, of slim build, with dark brown hair and was wearing black jogging bottoms, a black scarf over his mouth and a black hoodiewith writing on the front, possibly lsquoNorth Face.rsquoThe third suspect is described as a white male, smaller and younger than the others involved, wearing grey jogging bottoms and a black hoodie.Anyone with information shouldcontact Police Scotland on , quoting incident number  of  January, or Crimestoppers anonymously on   .

title: cold-weather-makes-it-harder-for-us-to-get-out-of-bed-says-survey
story: Weneed an extra  minutes in bed each morning during winter before wefeel brave enough to face the cold, according to a new survey.Of those surveyed who are currently employed,  per cent thought they were more likely to be late for work in the winter months because they found it harder to get up in the morning.Andof that %,the average worker will be late for work seven times in the course of an average winter because they overslept.One in five have been so cosy they have pulled a sickie to have a duvet day instead.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, which commissioned the study, said: ldquoDarker, colder mornings can make waking up in winter months more challenging than any other time of the year.ldquoAnd while an additional quarter of an hour snoozing each day doesnrsquot seem like a big sacrice, over the course of the winter we lose an entire day to those few extra minutes in bed.Regionally, Scots are the quickest to get up and face the day when the weather turns, spending  minutes extra in bed, while those living in Yorkshire are fondest of their covers, resisting the cold until theyrsquove had  extra minutes dozing.One in two Brits find it harder to get themselves out of bed in winter more than any other time of year, and a third think they are more likely to hit the snooze button when the mornings are dark and cold.And seven in  said a few more minutes with their duvet is too tempting when the weather outside looks chilly.To read the full results of the study, visitandrews-sykes blog.Three in five of those questioned make it tougher to leave their beds by taking actions to make their set-up as warm and comfortable as possible.Of these,  per cent will buy a thicker duvet when the weather begins to turn, and  per cent will put an extra blanket on the bed to keep the cold away.More than seven in  even have the foresight to set their heating to come on before they wake up so their home is warm when they wake, clicking on  minutes before they stir.One in five of those surveyed have been so attached to their bedspread they have been late for a meet-up with friends or loved ones - and will also cancel six gatherings entirely over a typical winter because its too cold.Nearly one in two Brits are unable to shake their hibernation instincts when the temperature plummets and spend more time in bed during the winter than any other time of year.Three in  find themselves going to bed earlier as the evenings draw in sooner, and one in eight set their morning alarms later than they usually would to grab a few extra minutes before feeling the chill.A spokesperson for Andrews Heat for Hire, who comissioned the survey, said: ldquoWith a cold snap predicted over the coming weeks,duvets are only going to become even more inviting. At least Brits are taking measures to reduce the struggle, by planning ahead and setting their heating to come on before their alarm.

title: musselburgh-swimming-pool-shut-all-evening-after-faecal-incident
story: A spokeswoman for enjoyleisure, which manages the facility, said: "Regrettably we had to close the pool at Musselburgh Sports Centre on Monday at short notice around .pm."This was following a faecal accident."In line with our protocols and health and safety requirements, the pool was closed in order to complete a full treatment cycle."We fully appreciate the frustration and disappointment this closure caused however we also know that patrons will understand and accept this approach is necessary in such circumstances."The spokeswoman said that the pool reopened at am today .A post from Musselburgh Amateur Swimming Club on Twitter said: "Session cancelled ndash tonights session is unfortunately not running today due to an issue at the pool. We apologise for the short notice but this is outwith our control. We look forward to seeing everyone on Wednesday."

title: tranent-teenager-recovering-well-after-horror-skiing-accident
story: An air ambulance brought Nicholas Guest back from Sion on Monday, with the teenager now in Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.Older sister Lizzy was delighted her brother was one step closer to being able to come home.She told the Courier: ldquoHe is a lot happier for being back in Scotland. There is a big change in his presentation.ldquoWe are all glad he is back and just along the road now instead of travelling hundreds of miles.Nicholas, , of Tranentrsquos Lawson Way, was placed in a coma following an accident while skiing in the resort of Saas-Fee, near the Italian border, earlier this month.The teenager bumped his head on the ground after going over a jump and underwent surgery, with doctors monitoring his condition.On Monday evening, he arrived back in Scotland and Lizzy, who lives in Haddington, said: ldquoHe is improving little bits all the time.ldquoHe has progressed quite a lot in the last two weeks considering how severe his injuries were.ldquoHe is awake for longer and he speaks a little bit more. He still has issues with his mobility but has been referred onto eye specialists, speech and language, and physiotherapy. He struggles on focusing his eyes a bit.ldquoBeing back in Scotland has made a massive dference just in terms of his mental health.ldquoAs well as his physical health improving, we are trying to encourage him to do as much as he can and we are trying to stimulate him to the maximum and get him recovering quicker.Nicholas plays rugby for Preston Lodge RFCrsquos under-s and was visited by a group from the rugby team in the hospital.A GoFundMe page was set up by Lizzyrsquos fianceacute, Daniel Hunter, to help cover the costs of the family going to visit Nicholas in Switzerland.An initial goal of pound, was quickly surpassed, with more than pound, now collected as the community rallies round.Lizzy said: ldquoWe are pretty amazed.ldquoIrsquom shocked, to be honest obviously we changed the goal when we realised quite a lot of people had donated.ldquoWe thought maybe people would help cover the expenses and it has been incredible.ldquoThat was really helpful and Nicholas appreciates it as well.ldquoIt has been great ndash even people we donrsquot know, friends of friends, that want to help. We donrsquot even know who they are and we are just really grateful they want to help us.Nicholas, who is in S at Preston Lodge High School, Prestonpans, faces a y recovery and rehabilitation period. It remains unclear when he will be able tohome, although Lizzy said her brother wanted to be home within three months.She added: ldquoNow we are going to be focusing on being there for Nicholas.ldquoWe have got our daily lives and jobs to go to but as a family we are all within a reasonable distance.ldquoWe can co-ordinate ourselves to be there at dferent times so he has always got someone with him.Lizzy and Nicholasrsquo mum Marian added: ldquoA great thank you to all who have supported us over the last couple of weeks and those who continue to do so. Nicholas knows about the support and it has had a huge impact on his recovery and wersquore very grateful for this.ldquoI also want to express thanks to all who help and support our family.ldquoThanks to the excellent staff at the Swiss hospital, air ambulance team, and staff at the Western General.To help support Nicholas, go to gofundme support-for-nicolas

title: musselburgh-racecourse-abandons-cheltenham-trials-weekend
story: The racecourses premier jumps weekend fixture had been set to take place this Saturday and Sunday but sub-zero temperatures have put paid to the event, it was announced today.**The @bet Scottish Cheltenham Trials Weekend has been ABANDONED**Unfortunately, due to a frozen track  low temperatures this weekendrsquos Scottish Cheltenham Trials Racemeeting has been abandoned.We are looking to reschedule  more information will follow. pic alVcaiijHarriet Graham, clerk of the course, said: ldquoVery sadly we have had to abandon our Scottish Cheltenham Trials weekend because of frozen ground.ldquoWe have tried really hard to get this meeting on, putting fleeces on the whole course, but unfortunately with temperatures as low as - last night and the night before, the frost has got underneath the fleece and there is no prospect of temperatures rising enough over the next few days for us to get racing on Saturday or Sunday.ldquoIt is such a great shame as we had a very exciting weekend ahead of us, but we just canrsquot beat the weather I am afraid.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse general manager, added: ldquoMusselburgh will seek the opportunity to stage an extra fixture which will meet the needs of horses that would otherwise have raced at our bet Scottish Cheltenham Trials weekend.Refunds will be made available and the racecourse will be in contact with all race-goers who have purchased advance admission tickets.For more information, visit the racecourse website and social media feeds.

title: big-backlog-of-500-street-lights-needing-fixed-in-east-lothian
story: Complaints about lights are logged on an interactive map on East Lothian Councilrsquos website, which shows that some were reported as not working as far back as October last year, with the fault still classed as ldquounveried.A senior officer at East Lothian Council confirmed the backlog as he responded to a complaint about lights being left unfixed outside a school.He said that budget cuts had ldquorun down our establishment and the council was unable to recruit enough electricians because it could not compete with private sector salaries.In an email, the senior lighting officer said: ldquoThe council currently has a backlog of some  lighting faults. We are also suffering from a shortage of staff to address the issue.ldquoBudget cuts have run down the establishment and further recruitment has proved unsuccessful, with electricians outwith local government enjoying much higher levels of remuneration than we can offer.Councillor Norman Hampshire, the council administrationrsquos spokesperson for the environment, insisted that the number of faults equated to ldquoless than three per cent of the , lights the local authority operated in the county.And he said that more than half the lights in East Lothian had been converted to LED, requiring far less maintenance.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoIn the meantime, we are continuing to inspect reported faults as quickly as possible and, where a fault is a matter for ScottishPower, we are making sure this is dealt with as soon as possible.ldquoWhere repairs are our responsibility, we have used electrical contractors to assist with repairing lighting faults and we plan to use this resource again when the need arises.Mr Hampshire added that some lights in new housing developments remained the responsibility of developers until they were transferred to the council.The senior officer was responding to a complaint about lights being left unfixed outside Dunbar Primary Schoolrsquos John Muir campus. He confirmed that the council had used contractors in the past but said: ldquoThe high costs involved mean any long-term engagement is unsustainable.Mr Hampshire added: ldquoIn relation to recruitment, East Lothian Council is experiencing the same challenges as other local authorities are as a result of UK growth and we are seeking to mitigate this impact.Among the street lights currently out of action are some at Robertson Drive and Lindores Drive in Tranent due to a faulty cable, with ScottishPower stating work is due to be carried out late next month.Check your street lights on the local authorityrsquos interactive map here.

title: retiring-golf-club-starter-recalls-meeting-neil-armstrong-and-movie-stars
story: A GOLF club starter who once welcomed the first man on the moon to the fairways has called it a day.North Berwick Golf Club bid farewell to starter Sam Fox this week, as he retired after  years of service to the club.As a starter, it was Samrsquos job to set the pace of play on the course, as well as offering his knowledge about both the coursersquos history and hints and tips on how to play it.Sam, originally from Wales, moved to Scotland as a youngster and attended Dalkeith High School he eventually joined the police, working in Musselburgh and then later in North Berwick.Retiring after  years on the force, a friend of his let him know about a vacancy at North Berwick Golf Club.ldquoI started there as a ranger, said Sam, ldquoand pretty quickly they askedI wanted to be their starter.Over his two decades at the West Links, Sam has seen many changes.ldquoThere have been  captains while Irsquove been there, and they seem to be getting younger and younger, he said.ldquoIrsquove worked through the introduction of high-tech computerised systems, elite golf equipment and the golf outfits getting more and more colourful!With North Berwick Golf Club being hailed as one of the best and oldest in the world, Sam has seen his fair share of high-profile golfers and famous celebs.ldquoThe most important customer that I had was the next one who would play ndash everyone gets treated the same, but saying that, I have met some pretty famous people, he said.ldquoI remember Neil Armstrong, the first man on the moon, coming in.ldquoI didnrsquot recognise him at first, and so asked him what he did for a living. He said he was a pilot and I asked himhe flew with Virgin, or one of the big companies. He replied that he usually flew a little higher up than that. It was only then I realised who he was!ldquoIrsquove met Michael Douglas, Sean Connery, and Irsquove recommended good local pubs to Jack Nicholson.ldquoIf someone high profile is coming round, we usually get the call a few days ahead of time. Theyrsquoll make up a name for them so we never know who it is until they arrive. Theyrsquoll say lsquoMr Brown is helicoptering in to Archerfield and will be with you at such and such a timersquo.ldquoThatrsquos when you know itrsquos somebody famous.Sam has been receiving cards and letters from people all over the world at the news of his retirement, thanking him for making their experience at North Berwick memorable.But he said: ldquoI was only doing my job. People pay a lot of money to play at the course and sometimes have booked years in advance and saved up to do so, so itrsquos important to make their time with us as special as possible. We do everything we can to accommodate.ldquoEvenwersquore having to tell people they canrsquot play, maybe because the weather is too bad or theyrsquore not experienced enough, oritrsquos a stag do who are too drunk and have fallen over trying to put the tee down, we do what we can to still make a good experience for them.As for his retirement plans, Sam said: ldquoMy we has a list of things needing doing around the house, so Irsquoll be spending a lot of time at the DIY shop I think! But Irsquove had many invites from golf courses over Scotland to play there, so itrsquoll be nice to have the time to take them up on their offer.Samrsquos we Andrea also works at North Berwick Golf Club in the accounts office and they have been married for  years.Elaine McBride, general manager of the club, said of Sam: ldquoWhat a great servant to the club, who has been synonymous with our visitor experience at North Berwick Golf Club for over two decades. Sam will be missed by staff, members and visitors alike.Sam has been praised on social media, including by Andy Bower, who said on Twitter: ldquoMyself and seven other golfers played a few years ago and before we teed off Sam spent  minutes thanking us for choosing to play North Berwick. Sent us all on our way with a smile on our face.A drinks reception for members and staff to mark Samrsquos retirement takes place at the club at pm on Monday.North Berwick Golf Club is in the process of recruiting a new starter.

title: scottish-seabird-centre-shut-for-refurbishment
story: The Seabird Centre is closed from todayuntil the start of April.The exact re-opening date will be confirmed next month after the eight-week internal refurbishment has been completed.The refurbishment is focusing on reorganising the upstairs of the centre to allow more space and a clear line of sight to the Discovery Centre.The refurbishment includes the addition of exhibits to the Discovery Centre, as well as an internal wall removed and retail and cafe space relocated.The retail area, cafe and toilets will also be redecorated.

title: plan-to-revitalise-dunbars-east-beach-revealed
story: Huge amounts of sand have been lost to the sea in recent years at Dunbarrsquos East Beach ndashwith an unsightly mix of seaweed and rock now dominating the shore.Residents have long called for action to combat the beach erosion and now plans for groynes, a breakwater and rock armour have been drawn up in a bid to reverse the trend.The proposed works, which have been formulated by East Lothian Council, include repairing or replacing an existing groyne on the south of the site that has fallen into disrepair.A rock groyne would be created at the northern end of the beach, opposite the junction with The Vennel, with a concrete groyne towards the south, while a rock breakwater would also be included.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoIt is hoped, by reducing the wave conditions at the beach combined with the refurbished groyne, the bay will retain more sediment and in the long term provide improved protection to the existing sea defence wall and regain the amenity value that has been lost in recent years.The work is split into four sections, with the refurbishment of the existing groyne acting to retain beach level in the area as it is currently.Secondly, the breakwater, in addition to providing direction protection to a limited section of the defence, will allow an assessment of capacity for a natural beach to be developed. It will also advise on any further, long-term solution to the issues at the beach.The groyne at the northern end of the beach will provide protection over part of the northern section of the seawall, with the potential to develop a higher beach in front of the wall.Finally, armour stones will be put in place along Lamer Street to protect the seawall.Discussions on how to revitalise the East Beach, which was once a popular tourist attraction, have been ongoing for more than five years.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the townrsquos community council, has been heavily involved in the talks to find a solution.She was hopeful the latest measure would help and told community councillors: ldquoThe rock breakwater, the design has been worked on for more than two years.ldquoIt is now the preferred design solution and is the subject of a planning application.ldquoThere has been a lot of chatter about the East Beach and I wanted you all to be aware of what is going on and to be able to speak with some authority.Stones weighing anywhere between three and six tonnes will be used as part of the project, with work expected to take place throughout the summer and into the autumn.Mrs Swan was expecting heavy machinery to be on the site and said: ldquoIt will require big machines, at least -tonne trucks, moving these rocks around.ldquoThe East Beach will be the site of quite a lot of activity over the summer and we are bound to get some negative comments. But, hopefully, people will recognise this is an endeavour to protect the sea wall, which has failed three times in the last year.Ward councillor Norman Hampshire was also at the meeting and was pleased to see steps being taken in a bid to revitalise the beach.He said: ldquoExperts have said this is the best option to accumulate sand in this area but nobody can give any guarantees. It is nature we are playing with and it is whether sand is brought into the area.ldquoThere has been talk about importing sand but the costs are huge and it could be washed away the next day.

title: asbo-issued-to-haddington-woman
story: Natalie Breslin was given an anti-social behaviour order , which will remain in place for two years.The Brown Street resident is prohibited from shouting, swearing, using aggressive, abusive or intimidating language or behaviour within her property or on nearby High Street.Ms Breslin is also prohibited from shouting, swearing, or using threatening, intimidating, aggressive or abusive language or behaviour at a property on the townrsquos Riverside Drive, and of behaving in a manner that would cause or be likely to cause alarm or distress to residents or visitors of the street.Ms Breslin, , is similarly prohibited from behaving in an anti-social manner within North Berwickrsquos Glenburn Road and Lochbridge Road.A council spokeswoman said: ldquoEast Lothian Council will take the appropriate legal action against those who persistently behave in a way that causes alarm and distress to others.ldquoIn this case, our Safer Communities Team worked closely with Police Scotland in collating the evidence used to inform the application to court.ldquoI would ask anyone affected by anti-social behaviour to call the councilrsquos dedicated  hours a day helpline on   .

title: strikes-imminent-at-queen-margaret-university
story: The industrial action is scheduled for next Thursday , next Mondayand next Wednesday .The strikes follow a ballot of University and College UnionScotland members in which  per cent of those who voted supported industrial action on a turnout of  per cent.Those set to strike work in academic and academic-related positions, including the library and student support.The union says the row centres on cuts that would put more than  jobs at risk.It argues that alternatives to the current plans ndash including resource sharing, management savings and extending the period of restructuring ndash have not been sufficiently explored. The local branch is considering its next steps.The university employs  staff.A spokesperson from Queen Margaret University said: ldquoWe are still actively in discussions with both unions, with meetings scheduled for next week, and are hopeful that we can make sufficient progress at these talks to avoid industrial action.ldquoAs always, we will make every effort to minimise the impact of any strike action on our studentssuch action takes place.Mary Senior, UCU Scotland official, previously said that strike action was always a ldquolast resort, adding: ldquoUCU members at Queen Margaret University have made it absolutely clear that they have no confidence in the universityrsquos plans.ldquoThe ballot result is a clear mandate for industrial action and to oppose plans for compulsory redundancies.ldquoAxing  per cent of the workforce would have a huge impact on the student experience and on the universityrsquos reputation.The QMU spokesperson earlier said: ldquoThe university has not declared compulsory redundancies, committing itself to seeking to achieve the required reductions in staff costs voluntarily, and is making good progress on achieving this.ldquoAlong with the rest of the higher education sector, QMU faces financial challenges, with grant funding falling in real terms over recent years and rising costs such as pension and National Insurance contributions.ldquoDespite a positive growth trajectory overall at QMU, with costs increasing faster than our income, we have had to take action to reset the balance and thus ensure we can continue to lead in providing relevant teaching and research.

title: pressure-on-scottish-ministers-to-release-cockenzie-site-report
story: The Scottish Government called in a planning application to build a substation on the former Cockenzie Power Station site last March after the land was bought by East Lothian Council.Now, Scottish Conservatives are demanding the findings of the investigation be made public after they were sent to Ministers in private.South of Scotland MSP Michelle Ballantyne said the decision, which came after months of public hearings and representation, ldquobeggars belief, while ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said people were left wondering what the Scottish Government was doing ldquobehind closed doors.East Lothian Labour MSP Iain Gray has already tabled a motion at the Scottish Parliament demanding a public update on the decision as offshore windfarm company Inch Cape, which put in the planning application to build the substation, begins eight weeks of ldquoinvestigative work there.And East Lothian Council has said it is also considering writing to the Scottish Government, adding: ldquoThe council believes it is important for there to be transparency in the decision-making process.The decision on the application by Inch Cape, which is owned by Chinese state-owned company Red Rock, was taken away from council planners as First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was on an official visit to China last March.Inch Capersquos plans to bring energy from an offshore windfarm onto land at Cockenzie have been criticised by the council and communities for potentially sterilising a large area of land which has the potential to bring over , jobs to the county.The Scottish Government reporter scrutinised hundreds of documents from all sides and oversaw a public hearing in Cockenzie late last year.Her findings have been passed to Scottish Minister but are not being made public at this stage.The Scottish Government said: ldquoAn independent planning reporter was appointed to consider this case, produce a report and make recommendations in order for the final decision to be taken by Scottish Ministers.ldquoThe reporter has submitted her report and recommendations on the proposal and a decision will be made in due course.A council spokesperson said: ldquoWe understand that the reporterrsquos findings are now with Scottish Ministers, who will now determine the Inch Cape planning application, and that the contents of the report will be made public when that decision is announced.ldquoThe council believes it is important for there to be transparency in the decision-making process. We are considering possible correspondence with the Scottish Government on this matter. The leader of the council has also indicated that he will be writing to express similar concern to the minister.Mr Gray said the decision on the future of the site should never have been taken away from the council in the first place. He said: ldquoIt is of such great importance to the communities affected and the whole of East Lothian that it should have been determined by East Lothian Council and local people.ldquoThe community needs to know what is happening and what the Scottish Governmentrsquos decision will be, which is why I have tabled a question in Parliament asking Ministers to provide an urgent update.Conservative councillor Mr Bruce said: ldquoThe Scottish Government denied the local authorityrsquos right to make a decision on this application in the first place, making the whole process unfair and open to proper local scrutiny.ldquoThe fact that the report still hasnrsquot been released continues to shroud this whole saga in mystery and will leave many local people wondering what the Scottish Government is doing behind closed doors.And MsBallantyne added:ldquoItrsquos incumbent on the Scottish Government to be open and transparent over their decision-making process.ldquoDuring the formation of the report, the public engaged heavily by taking part in public hearings and contributing towards the report. Local stakeholders deserve to know the outcome of the report and, quite frankly, it beggars belief that the Scottish Government have chosen to keep this secret.

title: events-held-in-memory-of-much-missed-footballer-craig-fairgrieve
story: Craig Fairgrieve was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukaemiain  and passed away in July last year.Now, two fundraising events are taking place to raise funds for Ward  at Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital.The first fundraiser takes place at Dalkeith Miners Club, with a second event at Cockenzie and Port Seton Royal British Legion just over a fortnight later.Craigrsquos sister Lynsay is among those planning the event in Dalkeith on February .She said: ldquoCraig was a friend to everybody.ldquoHe was very laid back ndashhe was more laid back he would be horizontal.ldquoIf somebody tooted at him in the street he would wave and he liked a bit of banter.ldquoHe was notorious for lines out of films and he was a cheeky chappy and a guy with a smile on his face.Craig, of Prestonpans, played football for Tranent Juniors under-s after growing up in Macmerry and going to Ross High School in Tranent.He began to feel unwell towards the end of .His we Amy said: ldquoIt all started with tiredness. Craig was going to work and coming home absolutely exhausted.ldquoWe thought this was not normal and he got sent for blood tests.ldquoThat was when we discovered it was leukaemia and he started treatment at the Western General Hospital.Craig, who was just  when he passed away, underwent chemotherapy and a stem cell transplant as part of his treatment.Positively, he was told the condition was in remission and he was released from hospital, getting engaged in October .However, the leukaemia ed and Craig and Amy tied the knot in the Capitalrsquos hospital on July .Amy said: ldquoHis final wish was to get married.ldquoThe ward was really, really good and got it together. I was given a wedding dress from one of the nurses they were brilliant.A raffle and auction will be held at the first fundraiser, with prizes ranging from football tickets and golf vouchers to hair and beauty and bootcamp vouchers all up for grabs.Music will be supplied on the night by a DJ and Lynsay, , explained why the event was taking place outwith East Lothian. She said: ldquoA lot of the East Lothian venues were just too small.ldquoWe tried to keep it in East Lothian but we are looking for  tickets to be sold.ldquoThe tickets are out there and we are pretty much down to the last  or .Money raised on the night will go to the haematology wardat the hospital.Ahead of the event, more than pound, has already been raised. Meanwhile, the second fundraiser, on March , is a drag queen evening and disco.Amy said: ldquoThat is the sort of person Craig was ndash he was always up for a laugh and all about a good time.For ticketsto the fundraiser in Dalkeith, contact Kayleigh Szymanski or Dave Forsyth, and for tickets to the fundraiser in Cockenzie call Charles Brown on  .To make a donation, go to justgiving crowdfunding craig-fairgrieve

title: port-at-old-power-station-site-could-cost-same-as-new-school
story: A conference hosted by Prestonpans Community Council heard that building a cruise port could prove cost effective for East Lothian Council, which owns the land,it were then leased to port operators.Transport consultant Roy Pedersen, from Port of Copenhagen, told a gathering of councillors, officials and interested parties that a similar project in his homeland had been successfully introduced at a cost of pound million.And he said that the cruise ship terminal at Visby was built by its local authority and then leased to a private company for  years in a move which would repay most of the capital cost.Prestonpans Community Council, which is promoting the idea of a cruise ship port at the former Cockenzie Power Station site, said the Copenhagen example showed how it could work.Urging East Lothian Council to take the idea forward and investigate its potential, they said in a statement: ldquoSuch a capital cost does not seem so very dferent from the cost of building a school and would repay for itself over time under a lease arrangement with the public sector retaining ownership.The conference wasaddressed by community councillor Calum Miller, who told the invited audience: ldquoThere is a huge untapped potential for businesses across East Lothian, the creation of a hospitality college, re-stocking ships with local goods and produce, as well as the income that could be generated for the council from port fees.The meeting, in Prestonpans last Friday, had been criticised by some members of neighbouring Cockenzie and Port Seton community who oppose the port.It is understood at least one resident wrote to the local authorityrsquos chief executive expressing concern that officials would be attending the meeting and calling it ldquoa grave mistake to do so.A council spokesperson said: ldquoIt was entirely appropriate for council members and officers to take up invitations to attend. The seminar event consisted of presentations around cruise and port potential for the site.East Lothian Council produced its own masterplan for the site, which is described as a vision document, but plans are on hold as the outcome of a planning application to build a substation on the land is decided by Scottish Ministers.The council said a series of spring lsquoengagement eventsrsquo were planned for local communities to discuss the future of the site.

title: north-berwick-artists-exhibition-based-on-medication
story: NORTH Berwick artist Andrew Guest is displaying his medicinal artwork in his local pharmacy for a week to make a statement about peoplersquos relationship with tablets and medicine.A series of clay pots cast from the box of every piece of medication that Andrew took between  and , including everyday tablets such as paracetamol and ibuprofen, as well as the first types of tablets he took after being diagnosed with Parkinsonrsquos disease, are displayed in the window of Smithrsquos Pharmacy on High Street.The -year-old moved to North Berwick in  and, after a career as an exhibition officer putting on displays of other peoplersquos art, decided to make his own, completing courses in ceramics at Gateshead before studying pottery in Edinburgh.ldquoIrsquove always been interested in recycling and waste materials, especially pill packaging, he said.ldquoI just started making each box in clay, one for each pot, and it started there really. Itrsquos fascinating, and so much fun plasting and casting objects.ldquoI find a real beauty in the ordinary. I canrsquot paint some unique and beautul scene, but I can create something that people see everyday, and give them a chance to see it in a new light. It is also a picture of one personrsquos dependency on this method of treatment.Sheila Pearson, sales supervisor at Smithrsquos Pharmacy said: ldquoItrsquos generated some interest. People are stopping and looking and taking notice. It seems to be a positive reaction so far.The exhibition is on show at the pharmacy until Sunday.

title: female-founded-new-businesses-get-1p-for-every-1-of-venture-capital-investment
story: Start-ups with all-female founder teams get less than % of available capital compared with % invested in all-male founders, according to the British Business Bank. Mixed gender teams make up the remaining %.It means businesswomen could be missing out on billions of pounds in funding, as companies with no women on their founding teams hoover up an estimated pound billion a year.Chief Secretary to the Treasury Liz Truss described the figures as ldquoshocking, but said women need to be less ldquosqueamish about making money.The research, undertaken with Diversity VC and the British Venture Capital Association , will inform ongoing Government work to boost untapped potential of businesses which are facing barriers.The findings indicate that at current rates of change, it will take more than  years for all-female teams to receive p for every pound of UK venture capital investment.Speaking to the Daily , Ms Truss said the funding process had to be ldquomore open, more transparent and more meritocratic.ldquoIt is shocking that in  virtually % of all funding is going to all-male teams. Itrsquos not even going to mixed teams. For anyone looking in, it looks like men have a monopoly on getting that funding.However the minister said that women need to be ldquoless squeamish about making money.She told the paper: ldquoThe culture is it is a bit vulgar to talk about money or to say you want to make a profit, but actually itrsquos a huge benefit to society and a huge benefit to yourself.The research was originally commissioned by Philip Hammond during his  Budget. It identies specic barriers faced by female-led firms in accessing venture capital.Alice Hu Wagner, managing director of strategy and economics at the British Business Bank, said ldquoseemingly simple solutions had proven to be flawed because ldquomandating female decision-makers risks tokenism while earmarking women-only money does not address ldquounderlying closed networks and experience gaps.ldquoWe need new approaches to addressing these issues and this report is just a first step, she added.Ms Truss echoed the concern, telling the : ldquoNobody wants for their business to be funded because theyrsquore a woman.ldquoThey want to be judged on the basis of how good their ideas are, how hardworking they are, not the colour of their skin or their gender.

title: pentagon-sending-another-3750-troops-to-mexico-border
story: The additions will bring the total number of active-duty troops on the border to ,.The announcement is in line with what Acting Defence Secretary Pat Shanahan had said on Tuesday when he provided estimates for the next phase of a military mission that has grown in size and .Critics have derided it as a political ploy by the White House as President Donald Trump seeks billions to build a border wall.Mr Shanahan said on Tuesday that several thousand more troops would be sent mainly to install additional wire barriers and provide a large new system of mobile surveillance and monitoring of the border area.Sundayrsquos announcement said the mobile surveillance mission would last until September .Members of Congress have question whether the border mission is distracting troops from their main work of fighting extremists abroad and training for combat.The first active-duty troops were sent to the border on October  for a mission that was to end on December . It has since been extended twice.ldquoWhat impact does it have to readiness to send several thousand troops down to the Southern border  It interrupts their training. It interrupts their dwell time, Representative Adam Smith, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said at a hearing on Tuesday.With Caravans marching through Mexico and toward our Country, Republicans must be prepared to do whatever is necessary for STRONG Border Security. Dems do nothing. If there is no Wall, there is no Security. Human Trafficking, Drugs and Criminals of all dimensions ndash KEEP OUT!mdash Donald J. TrumpFebruary , Vice Admiral Mike Gilday, the director of operations for the Joint Staff, told the  that he does not believe military readiness has been signicantly affected.He said some units have missed training opportunities because of the deployment and others have seen less time at home between deployments than the military likes to provide.But he said there is an effort to rotate service members in and out of the mission every six to eight weeks in order to minimise any impact.

title: ryanair-reports-20m-euro-third-quarter-loss-amid-weaker-air-fares
