story: Ryanair has reported a  million euro loss for the third quarter of , citing weaker-than-expected air fares among its challenges.The airline said it flew . million customers in the quarter, an increase of %, and recorded revenue of . billion euros ndash up nearly %.However excess winter capacity in Europe saw a % decline in average fares, while the airline also had to content with higher costs from fuel, staff and compensation claims.Ryanair said the loss did not take into account the . million euro it spent on purchasing the remaining % of budget airline Laudamotion.Chief executive Michael OrsquoLeary said: ldquoWhile a  million euro loss in Q was disappointing, we take comfort that this was entirely due to weaker-than-expected air fares so our customers are enjoying record low prices, which is good for current and future traffic growth.ldquoWhile ancillary revenues performed strongly, up % in Q, this was offset by higher fuel, staff and EUcosts..push,i[r].l*new Dateas, ms[]a.asynca.srcgmga ga ga ga ga ga ga ga ga ga, title: Ryanair reports m euro third-quarter loss amid weaker air fares

title: glasgow-airport-rail-link-to-be-ditched-for-rapid-shuttle-pod-to-paisley
story: A Personal Rapid Transit shuttle pod between Glasgow Airport and Paisley Gilmour Street has emerged as the likely alternative to a full tram-train rail link.Following a meeting between Glasgow and Renfrewshire council leaders, the Transport Secretary and Glasgow Airport yesterday, it has been agreed to work on a business case for the Personal Rapid Transit system.It would see passengers board the pods like ones used at Heathrow Airport to take them to the station at Paisley where they would catch existing services to Glasgow and where.AYE OR NAW, MICHAEL :Our message to transport secretary amid fresh fears over airport rail linkThe final choice will be between the tram-train option and the Personal Rapid Transit pod.It is, however, likely that the rapid transit option will be the preferred one and the option taken forward.The tram-train link hit problems following a study that said it would impact negatively on other services in the West of Scotland and on Central Station which is at capacity.The Evening Times message to the transport secretary earlier this monthSusan Aitken, leader of Glasgow City Council, said: ldquoImproved connectivity to Glasgow Airport is a key priority. However, the advice from officers and consultants is that signicant questions remain about the deliverability of the current tram-train option, particularly in relation to capacity at Central Station.ldquoAs a result, the Executive Steering Group has agreed additional work should be done to establish an alternative Outline Business Case for a Personal Rapid Transitoption.ldquoThis work was not advanced by the previous City Deal Cabinet, but it is now crucial in order to allow us to make a fully-informed choice about which of the options in front of us should be progressed.:Glasgow Airport rail link saga has dragged on for far too longldquoI remain committed to a solution that delivers improved public transport connectivity to Glasgow Airport - but I am determined it should also provide value for money for the city, and deliver the widest possible inclusive economic benefits.ldquoIrsquom confident we have made signicant progress towards that outcome today.Glasgow Airport said congestion on the M means action is needed and ldquodoing nothing is not an option.Mark Johnston, managing director at Glasgow Airport, said: ldquoWe were informed that, due to issues around rail capacity, the project partners are developing an alternative option.: Half a million to go on addressing airport rail link fearsldquoThis will be evaluated and we will, of course, work with the partners to promote the delivery of an effective solution within the agreed timescale.It has been understood that transport officials were not keen on progressing the tram-train link from Glasgow Central to the airport.Michael Matheson, Transport Secretary, said: ldquoItrsquos crucial that improving access to Glasgow Airport is balanced with the needs of the regionrsquos existing transport network.ldquoThe Personal Rapid Transit system option potentially meets this aim, and I look forward to seeing the revised business case once itrsquos completed.

title: glasgow-gateway-to-scotland-the-best-film-locations-within-90-minutes
story: Known affectionately as ldquocinema city, in the s it had more cinemas per head of population than anywhere  in the UK. These days it regularly tops box office attendance figures outside of London.It has also produced a plethora of fine directors over the years, including Alexander Mackendrick, Bill Forsyth, Lynne Ramsey and David Mackenzie.This love affair with film is a two-way thing, however, and the city has starred in many great movies over the years, spanning every budget and genre. And while it often plays itself, some of Glasgowrsquos most famous appearances on screen have been playing somewhere .Scotlandrsquos stunning scenery and history have always been a draw for filmmakers, of course, not least over the last few years, with the likes of Outlaw King and phenomenally popular TV show Outlander re-introducing the country to a younger global audience. Indeed the Scots star of Outlander, Sam Heughan, spoke recently about how much he relishes filming in his home country.ldquoScotland is undoubtedly the star of our show, the Glasgow-based actor said in a magazine interview. ldquoIrsquom so proud of the country and all is had to offer. Irsquove learnt so much about where Irsquom from and fallen in love with it even more. Each location we go to lends itself to whatever is happening in the script or the story line. We are so lucky to have this right on our doorstep.The best whisky and Burns within  minutes of GlasgowIndeed we are, and with this in mind wersquove set ourselves a fitting challenge: the best filming locations to visit within  minutes of Glasgow city centre.World War ZThe  zombie thriller, starring Brad Pitt, was partially shot in Glasgow, with the city centre getting a clever makeover to stand in for Philadelphia. George Square took a starring role in one of the most dramatic and memorable scenes in the movie, the zombie invasion, which saw hundreds of extras run screaming through the square, which was all dressed up with Philadelphian street signs and American cars for authenticity.While filming in Glasgow, architecture buff Pitt spent time visiting Charles Rennie Mackintosh buildings with his then-we Angelina Jolie and their children, including a trip to Hill House in Helensburgh. The actor is a huge fan of Glasgowrsquos most famous architect and designer, having visited the city on a number of occasions to see his work.House of MirthGlasgow was transformed into New York for this  film version of Edith Whartonrsquos  novel, which stars Gillian Anderson and Dan Ackroyd. Much of the movie was filmed in Glasgow, with city landmarks such as Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum, the City Chambers, Kelvingrove Park, Devonshire Terrace and the Theatre Royal perfectly recreating opulent early th century New York.Cloud AtlasGlasgow stood in for yet another US city in this  production: San Francisco. Both cities are known for their steep hills and location managers made good use of Montrose Street, in the Merchant City, and Douglas Street, in the west of the city centre, dressing them with period cars and signs to create a distinct s vibe. Blythswood Square also features in the film. Halle Berry filmed in the cityand was also given a s look for her role in author David Mitchells dystopian time travel tale.The Fast and the FuriousThe long, wide streets around George Square doubled for London and were used for a number of stunt sequences in the latest spin-off of the globally popular action movie franchise, called Hobbs and Shaw, which is due for release later this year. Idris Elba filmed a number of scenes - dressed in full motorbike leathers - as onlookers were treated to a plethora of fast and furious car and bike chases through the city centre.The best whisky and Burns within  minutes of GlasgowThe WeMuch of this quietly powerful movie, which stars Glenn Close - nominated for an Oscar for her role - and Jonathan Price, was filmed in Scotland. Glasgowrsquos grand Hutcheson Hall, in the Merchant City, takes on the role of Stockholm in one of the filmrsquos key scenes, while the in-flight storyline was shot aboard the Concorde that is exhibited at National Museum of Flight in East Lothian. Beautul Dumfries and Galloway also features prominently in this story of a woman who takes control of her le and re-assets her worth after her husband is awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature.OutlanderLeading man Heughan was spot on when he said Scotland was the real star of the historical time travel drama, which also stars Caitriona Balfe. The location managers have clearly scoured every inch of the country to find the best castles, harbours, mountains, lochs, hills and heather, and all of these assets are used to stunning effect throughout. Doune Castle - Castle Leoch in the show and also Winterfell in Game of Thrones ndash is just  minutes from Glasgow, while a host of other key locations, including Hopetoun House, Drummond Castle and the Fe village of Culross, are all within an hour of the city.Beautul Dunure Harbour, just  minutes from Ayr and an hour from Glasgow, featured in the last two seasons of the series. Sam Heughan, who says he spends as much of his spare as possible time cycling, hiking and climbing across Scotland, spoke evocatively last year of filming in the village of Dunure and ldquolooking across to the snow-capped peaks of Arran at sunrise.Outlaw KingGlasgow features signicantly in David Mackenziersquos brutal film about the rise to power of Robert the Bruce. Glasgow Universityrsquos gothic cloistersput in an appearance, while the main building briefly doubles as Westminster. Glasgow Cathedral can also be seen in the film, as can Linthligow Palace, birthplace of Mary Queen of Scots, just  minutes along the M.The beach scene at the end of the film, where Bruce is seen bring reunited with his we, was shot at beautul Seaclf sands in East Lothian,  minutes from Glasgow. Stunning Tantallon Castle is perched above and offers some of the most stunning views on the east coast.The best whisky and Burns within  minutes of GlasgowMary Queen of ScotsSeaclf beach also features in Josie Rourkersquos recent film, which stars Saoirse Ronan as Mary Stuart, and Scot Jack Lowden as Lord Darnley. Blackness Castle in West Lothian stands in for Holyrood Palace Edinburgh, and both royal residences are just an hourrsquos drive from Glasgow. Loch Leven Castle, the fascinating and scenic island ruin where Mary was imprisoned and escaped from in , is also just an hour away.The Da Vinci CodeRon Howardrsquos hugely popular film version of Dan Brownrsquos bestselling thriller was shot in locations across Europe, but the movie comes to a climax in Scotland, at beautul Rosslyn Chapel in Midlothian. In interviews, Brown said he always knew his bookrsquos finale would take place at Rosslyn, which he describes as ldquothe most mysterious and magical chapel on earth.The filmrsquos star, Tom Hanks, flew into Scotland in September  to shoot extensive scenes at the th century site, which is just an hourrsquos drive from Glasgow. He wrote afterwards: ldquoFew locations on a film are more delightful and few destinations live up to their billing, so to speak, but Rosslyn was all that one could imagine or hope for.The chapel, which is overflowing with strange, interesting and unexplained symbols and carvings, has been flummoxing historians and visitors alike for centuries. Due to its connections with the mysterious Knights Templar, some believe the Holy Grail is buried underneath the chapel . Whether or not that is true, it remains one of the most beautul, bizarre and evocative places in Scotland.Glasgow, Gateway to Scotland a partnership between People Make Glasgow and Glasgow Airport, in association with The Herald, aims to attract more US visitors and capitalise on a recent growth in overseas tourists by highlighting the cityrsquos position as both a must-see destination in itself, and the ideal base for accessing Scotlandrsquos landscapes, history and culture.Delta flies direct to Glasgow from JFK www.delta.United fliesdirectfrom Newark www.united.

title: snp-heavyweight-forms-polling-group-to-help-prepare-case-for-independence
story: Progress Scotland, headed by Angus Robertson, will commission polls, focus groups and research funded by subscriptions and donations.Robertson was an SNP MP for sixteen years from  before losing his Moray seat to the Conservatives.He led the SNP group in the House of Commons and was his partyrsquos depute leader for around  months. Robertson was also in charge of the SNPrsquos Holyrood election campaigns in  and .He is opening a new chapter in his le by preparing to launch Progress Scotland, which will examine public opinion in the wake of the referenda on independence and Brexit.Mark Dfley, who was the lead pollster for the UK Government in the run-up to the independence referendum, will be conducting the polling and research.Speaking ahead of the launch, Robertson said: ldquoProgress Scotland aims to help prepare the case for Scotland to progress towards independence, keeping pace with the views of the people who make their lives here. With the help and support of subscribers we will research the opinion of people in Scotland and test their appetite to emulate the most successful small countries in the world. We will provide insight and analysis on what is needed to persuade people on the case for Scotland to make progress."Dfley explained his involvement in the project:ldquoScotland has been my home for nearly  years and I have witnessed how the country has changed and continues to change. We are at a time when it has never been so important to listen to the people of Scotland and understand what the public is thinking."I am going to conduct the polls and research for lsquoProgress Scotlandrsquo and I am very excited to see what we will find. With so much going on with Brexit and the debate about Scotlandrsquos future now is the right time to ask people about their opinions, how they are changing and why. It makes sense to try and understand peoplersquos hopes and concerns especially at this time of change.However, Tory MSP Murdo Fraser queried the basis of the new organisation. ldquoYou would have thought by now that Angus Robertson would have learnt the lesson of the  general election, where he and his colleagues lost their seats to the Conservatives. The majority of Scots have no interest in independence and even less interest in a rerun.ldquoThis may be a good business opportunity for him, but I fear he is wasting his and everyone rsquos time.Ahead of the launch, Progress Scotland released a series of interviews with iniduals who are now backing independence. Chris Wilson, a politics student and young Liberal Democrat member from Lanarkshire said: ldquoLib Dems like me will have to make a choice sooner or later about which Union we prefer. I choose for Scotland to set its own path as a progressive, socially democratic society within the European Union, not as part of an increasingly right wing intolerant United Kingdom.ldquoWhile I was a lsquoNorsquo supporter in  I have changed my mind since, and I would vote lsquoYesrsquo today for Scottish independence in Europe, for the sake of my generation and the ones that will follow.Youth activist Erin Mwembo, who recently left school, said:ldquoAt the time of the independence referendum I was too young to vote, but having looked at the issues I would probably have voted lsquoNorsquo. Since then however, my views have changed and like most young people in Scotland I now support independence.ldquoBeing responsible for our own future and making better decisions closer to home is definitely the best future for Scotland and everyone who lives here. Looking at the Brexit mess at Westminster Irsquom convinced we can do better, and protect our place in Europe. I know that many people, like me, have been changing their views on independence. And I think many more will do the same.

title: mercury-plunges-as-uk-could-see-coldest-night-in-nearly-a-decade
story: The mercury had plunged to minus .Cat Braemar in the Scottish Highlands just before midnight, while most of the UK had dipped below freezing.Forecasters said there was the potential for a low of minus Cto be seen in eastern Scotland overnight following a blast of cold weather than brought severe disruption to large parts of the country.Several weather warnings have been issued for Sunday and Monday mornings, although some respite is expected with milder conditions moving in at the start of the week.Outbreaks of rain, sleet and #snow will spread east across western #Scotland on Sunday morning ndash Stay #weatheraware ## pic ebgbiFyIgmdash Met OfficeFebruary , Icy stretches will continue to be a hazard in parts of southern England and East Anglia into Sunday morning and a yellow warning is in place until am.Meanwhile there is a warning in place for snow and ice for a swathe of western Scotland reaching from Inverness in the north to the outskirts of Glasgow in the south.ldquoMuch of the UKrsquos dry, but across the north-west and west of Scotland there are some snow showers, Met Office meteorologist Greg Dewhurst said.ldquoThere is a weather warning that will be in place from am onward as that band pushes eastwards.ldquoIt will be a cold, frosty start for many and then there is the risk of some more rain, sleet and snow coming into western Scotland by the end of the night into Monday morning.

title: joanna-blythman-reviews-el-cartel-in-edinburgh
story: Now I wasa fan of Edinburghrsquos original El Cartel in Thistle Street. I marvelled at the food that came out through that impossibly cramped serving place on the ground floor and envisaged a kitchen hotter than Tabasco, either behind or below, filled with world travellers who knew genuine Mexican food and were capable of serving up a respectful representation of it.Now the second El Cartel in Teviot Place, haunt of students, has left me wondering was the original El Cartel actually not as good as I remember, or is this one letting it down  A quick straw poll of those who accompanied me on El Cartel trips suggests the latter.Where the original El Cartel was electric, exciting, this one is monotonous, mundane. Itrsquos asits vivacity has been replaced by a tick box exercise, the dutul copying of the inspiring original dishes, gradually losing most of its sparkle in the process. Like Chinese Whispers, El Cartelrsquos founding message has become distorted somewhat in the telling.Guacamole, I used to think it quite special at El Cartel, is missing several tricks. Its greenness has an unpleasantly all-pervasive onion undertow, and is, by my standards, underpowered on lime, coriander and chilli. By the way, no need to order it as a dish because it turns up over and over again in other dishes, as does tedious shredded Chinese cabbage.Our pick of the daily specials, a vegetarian taco based on squash, sets the tone. The sweet vegetable is partnered with eye-wateringly vinegary pickled onions mixed with a brown salsa that might possibly have a connection with chocolate, but with bossy cinnamon in overdrive and enough chilli- and I like a lot of chilli- to ride rampantly over other flavours and reduce them to mere textures. Itrsquos one of those peppery chillis that sets up residence on the back of your tongue. I take a big slug of my rather medicinal lime Margarita and am grateful for it, even though it leaves freezer burn on my lips.Al Pastor pork ribs manage to be dull, with a lingering taste I associate with reheating. Theyrsquore in ldquocumin, garlic and pineapple glaze, a furiously fiery, fruity coating that makes us sweat and clocks in too high up the sweetness scale, but yet it canrsquot quite cover an underlying bitterness that Irsquom not actively relishing. Cashew and cabbage slaw accompanies it, but its dressing is also too sweet.We fancy a clean, refreshing ceviche, but the only fish getting this treatment is salmon, presumably farmed, which I never eat on environmental grounds. So itrsquos more meat, this time carne asado, flash-grilled flat iron steak, slicked with a salsa of grassy, slightly acidic Arbol chillis, avocado, spring onion.The tacos here are flexibly flabby, irregularly formed, hand pressed in-house daily using proper Masa Harina corn meal. Theyrsquore one of the best things about El Cartel. Duck carnitas are probably the star dish, fatty, crisp-skinned mouthfuls lightened with pineapple, brightened by hot Jalapentildeo chillis, everything calmed down by an emollient pecan salsa.On paper, this second El Cartel definitely outshines the original one. More space, an eye-catching giant mural, which looks like an Aztec wrestling an armadillo, bottles back-lit and lined up behind three stain glass windows that echo the Gothic architecture of the old medical school opposite. It takes bookings. But cramped and cobbled together as it is, I miss the original El Cartel. I leave this one sticky-fingered, with my mouth on fire. Irsquom not getting the same buzz as before, that subtlety of flavour. Itrsquos asthe impresario left before the apprentices learned all the tricks.El Cartel, - Teviot Place, Edinburgh   Food:  Decor:  Service:  Value:

title: power-plant-whats-behind-the-irresistible-rise-of-veganism
story: Power plant: what#s behind the irresistible rise of veganism The Hug and PintThese days taking the pledge means something a little dferent. Starting your day with a bowl of cardamom and peach quinoa porridge instead of a bacon roll, or ending it with a curried tofu wrap in place of mince and tatties and cheesy beans.Thatrsquos because these days ndash and in particular this time of year ndash the pledge involves abstaining from meat, fish, dairy and eggs, and buying into a movement gaining fast in popularity: Veganuary, the month in which everyone from unabashed carnivores to pescatarians, vegetarians and reducetariansare asked to try going vegan. For a whole  days. Or  mealsyou want it in terms your stomach can understand.Founded by Jane Land and Matthew Glover in , Veganuary launched in  with  pledgers and that number has at least doubled every year. Last year , people took part and to date there have been a quarter of a million participants in  countries. Pointing to a poll by IPSOS Mori about actual take-up, the organisers have also identied what they call ldquothe Veganuary Effect, which suggests that around  times that number take part without signing the pledge.The core principles turn on animal welfare and always have. As well as campaigning against killing animals and fish, vegan organisations, pressure groups and activists have long fought to shine a light on the more unsavoury practices of the dairy and egg-production industries.Those issues remain valid but increasingly veganism is becoming an attractive proposition for those concerned with other subjects, from the environment and ecological sustainability to allergies, food additives and gut microbes. Itrsquos that which in large part is accounting for the rise in veganism. Moreover, while discussions of veganism have always taken in theology, philosophy and politics therersquos now a feminist angleand pop culture is coming around, too. Alert vegans enjoying Oscar-nominated superhero blockbuster Black Panther wonrsquot have missed the line about how the Jabari tribe are vegetarian ndash but those who did because they were too busy looking at the phones probably already know that mega-influencers Ellie Goulding, Miley Cyrus and Ariana Grande, who have a cool  million Instagram followers between them, are vegan.Figures for the number of pledgers singing up to the  Veganuary campaign were announced last week and reveal that , people signed up, making it the most popular ever. Adjusted for the Veganuary Effect that means a cool two and a half million people around the world may have tried veganism for the first time last month.Kay Steven was one of them. A part-time student who lives in Edinburgh and runs a consultancy business, she took the Veganuary pledge. ldquoIt took two friends signing up to Veganuary to give me the push to do it. Irsquove been pleasantly surprised at how easy Irsquove found it and how much support Irsquove had from friends and family.For Rich Hardy, Veganuaryrsquos Head of Campaigns, that sort of testimony shows that veganism has shaken off its reputation as a sort of culinary counter-culture and gone mainstream.ldquolsquoVeganrsquo is now a word we see and hear everywhere ndash in shops and restaurants, in peoplersquos conversations on the streets, and in newspapers and magazines, he says. ldquoItrsquos not hype or a short-term trend. Any movement has to reach critical mass to succeed. We think veganism has reached that point and is firmly on its way to the mainstream.Social media and smartphones have helped spread the message, he adds. ldquoAll of us can view footage of an undercover animal rights exposeacutewe so choose. With material like that so available, itrsquos helped get more people questioning whatrsquos been hidden from them.The mainstream has certainly taken notice. Last month restaurant chain TGI Fridays launched its ldquobleeding vegan burger. Not in the best taste, perhaps, but the oozing blood came from the addition of beetroot and the rest of the burger was formed from a mixture of coconut oil, mushrooms, herbs and spices. Last week, pizza chain Papa Johnrsquos launched three new pizzas featuring Sheese, a vegan cheese manufactured by Rothesays Bute Island Foods. And even McDonalds has muscled in with a Spicy Veggie Patty and a vegan-friendly Happy Meal.Therersquos no doubting the pace of change. Research by The Vegan Society in  found that just over half a million Britons described themselves as vegan and research two years later found the number had surged to three and a half million. In Scotland, according to  figures, there are , vegans, about twice the population of Dundee.No doubt some of them even live there, but itrsquos Edinburgh and Glasgow that are at the centre of the scene here. Edinburgh punches well above its weight. A list of the most vegan-friendly cities in Europe by pressure group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animalsput the capital third after Amsterdam and Berlin, well ahead of London.Scan a UK list such as the one published by magazine Vegan Le in  and you find Glasgow and Edinburgh safely in the top five.Scientists: red meat and sugar consumption must halve by  to save planetGlasgow has had popular vegan cafeacute-bars for over  years, notably city institutions such as Mono and its offshoot Stereo. A relative newcomer at just four years of age is The Hug And Pint on Great Western Road, and like those two it offers a vegan menu and doubles as a gig venue. With three other new vegan cafes operating just a couple of minutesrsquo walk from the Hug, as itrsquos known, co-owner and co-founder Colin Campbell is in no doubt the cityrsquos vegan scene is thriving. Itrsquos doing so in part because there are more vegans, but also because there are more non-vegans who are happy to eat vegan food ndash especiallyalso includes live music.ldquoYou can look at reviews online and actually a great number of our reviews start with lsquoIrsquom not vegan but helliprsquo and theyrsquore five star reviews, he says. ldquo[So] we have a lot of people coming in who arenrsquot vegan.As proof of that growing popularity and acceptance, Campbell and his head chef Jake Martell have launched a three-month residency at Glad Cafeacute in Glasgowrsquos Southside. They already run a brunch service there but now evening diners can enjoy dishes such as Jackfruit Curry or Sweet Soy and Coconut Tempeh. Theyrsquore also in the process of writing a Hug And Pint vegan cook book.Leaving aside the issue of morality and animal welfare, one complaint against veganism is that the palette of available foodstuffs is necessarily limited. But Campbell flips that idea on its head. To him, those arenrsquot limitations at all. The beauty of vegan fare, he thinks, is that ldquoitrsquos food thatrsquos suitable for everyone. Itrsquos the widest, most accessible menu we can do. If yoursquore a meat eater you can eat it,yoursquore vegetarian you can eat it,yoursquore vegan you can eat it.So why does he think the popularity of veganism is on the rise  ldquoI think itrsquos linked into a wider discussion, he says. ldquoItrsquos about things like the environment, thatrsquos a big thing for me and a big thing for people who arenrsquot maybe fully vegan or fully vegetarian but who are reducetarian.Vicky Allan: We build this future on sausage rolls Remember that word. Championed by the US-based Reducetarian Foundation, it promotes eating less meat, dairy and eggs but values pragmatism over an all-or-nothing approach. In other words you can still have full fat milk in your tea and, yes, the occasional bacon roll or plate of mince and tatties. The Foundation hosts at annual Reducetarian Summit , publishes a cookbook and like Veganuary asks potential converts to take a pledge. Options ranging from going meat-free on Mondays to becoming vegetarian for a month.Edinburgh has a less vibrant vegan cafeacute-bar scene than Glasgow, but it does have two of Scotlandrsquos oldest and most venerable vegetarian eateries in Hendersons, established in , and David Bann, founded in the mid-s.David Bann started out with a baked potato shop in the early s and his eponymous restaurant has been in St Maryrsquos Street in the Old Town since . Veganism ldquodoes seem to have gone mainstream, he says. ldquoWe get a lot more enquiries for it than we used to. Wersquove always had vegan options on our menu but recently wersquove been getting a lot more enquiries from vegan customers, so wersquore putting a little bit more emphasis on that. Desserts are dficult to make vegan, but wersquove managed to get a couple of good desserts on.His tofu chocolate ice cream has proved popular. But, he adds, ldquoI donrsquot like to put food on that only vegans will like. Itrsquos important to me that everyone will enjoy it. The important thing is for the food to have mainstream appeal. ldquoPeople who would normally eat meat have to enjoy what they have here and itrsquos exactly the same with vegan food.Bann is vegetarian and has been serving vegetarian and vegan food to Edinburghers for a quarter of a century. But even he thinks itrsquos too early to saythe rise in veganism and the increased awareness around environmental sustainability, animal welfare and food production are a short-live trend or show a cultural and societal sht.ldquoThe recent upsurge might be a fad, but I would like to think itrsquos a direction of travel, he says. ldquoI think it would be a healthy way to go. A lot of people are not going totally vegan but theyrsquore looking for more vegan options. Most of our customers are not even vegetarian but theyrsquore eating less meat and they want to try dferent things. And I think the same thing is happening with vegan food: people are more open to it.Bannrsquos restaurant manager, Ruben Iglesias, came to Scotland from Spain  years ago and became vegan two years after arriving. He has seen veganism move from the fringes to commonplace lestyle choice. He agrees that social media and the internet has much to do with the increase in and acceptance of veganism, and like Bann he has seen the proof of it in the number of vegans coming into the restaurant.When Iglesias started at the restaurant in , vegan customers were uncommon. ldquoYou might get two or three an evening, he says. ldquoNow Irsquod say at least  per cent of our customers are vegan. Wersquove always been able to adapt the menu to be vegan but at some points last year  per cent of our menu was vegan, or we could adapt it to be vegan.Heres the big question, though: how many of those who sign up to Veganuary will still be off meat, fish, eggs and dairy come Shrove Tuesday which, as the pancake lovers among you will know, falls on March  this year ldquoWersquoll need a few yearsrsquo more data to get a better feel about the longer term conversion rates of people taking the pledge and remaining vegan, says Simon Winch, Veganuaryrsquos CEO. ldquoBut the signs are very encouraging that the campaign is really effective at helping people stay vegan for the long term.For her part, Kay Steven is aiming to at least make it to Pancake Day. ldquoIt feels lovely to have made the leap and Irsquom planning on keeping going for at least another few months, but to be honest I canrsquot imagine going back. Irsquom definitely feeling healthier and not deprived in the slightest.So is the future vegan ndash or will it only look like it every time Veganuary rolls around ldquoI wouldnrsquot go as far as to say itrsquos the future, says David Bann. ldquoBut I think it is another cuisine that is opening peoplersquos minds a little bit to what is available, and it just gives people another option so they can steer away from meat for a while. Irsquove never had the idea of changing the world, I just want to give people the option of something dferent from what they were brought up with or what theyrsquore used to. So I donrsquot knowitrsquos a whole new world ndash but itrsquos to be welcomed, I think, and not to be feared or dismissed.The Hug And Pintrsquos Mushroom Cashew CurryCashew nuts blitzed with water and oil into a smooth lsquobutterrsquo are the key to the richness of this dish which can stand up to any curry rich with ghee, cream, or animal fat. The comforting creaminess of cashews is countered with sharp and fiery sambal oelek and balanced with the freshness of peas and coriander. Inspired by classic Indo-British cuisine, this curry has widespread appeal and is one of our most enduring and popular dishes, appearing fairly consistently on our rotating menu.Serves Serve with: rice and or flatbreadIngredientsg cashew nuts g button mushrooms dried shiitake mushroomsml vegetable oilg frozen peasA small handful coriander leaves  medium brown onion  green chillies  cloves of garlic  thumb of ginger  tablespoon of palm sugar or brown sugar teaspoon ground coriander teaspoon ground turmeric teaspoon ground cuminA pinch of ground cardamomA pinch of ground fenugreek tablespoon of salt fresh curry leaves  tablespoon sambal oelek The juice of  limeMethodIn a bowl, cover the dried shiitake in ml of hot water and leave to soak for one hour. Meanwhile, in a food processor or a large pestle and mortar, blitz the onions, garlic, chillies and ginger, adding a little of the oil to achieve a thick paste consistency. Heat the majority of the rest of the oil in a large saucepan. When hot but not smoking, add the paste and cook, stirring often, for  minutes until it softens and gets some colour. In a frying pan or wok, heat a glug of oil and fry the button mushrooms in two batches until each batch is well coloured all over. It helps to keep the mushrooms a similar size, so cut any larger ones in half, keeping the smaller ones whole. When the mushrooms are cooked, using the same pan cook half of the cashews over a medium heat until brown, being careful not to burn them. In a food processor blitz the remaining uncooked cashews with ml of water and ml of vegetable oil into a smooth, white butter and set aside. Add the spices, sugar and salt to the onion garlic paste and cook for another  minutes, adding oilit seems dry. Remove the shiitake from the soaking water and reserve the liquid. Remove stalks and discard, roughly chop caps and add to the cooking paste. Add the soaking water, cashew butter and sambal oelek to the cooking paste and stir. Allow the curry to simmer for half an hourthen remove from the heat and stir in the peas, coriander and lime juice. Check seasoning and serve with rice or flatbread.

title: scotlands-drink-industry-can-it-be-called-a-world-superpower
story: But in , with the Scottish drink industry at the height of its powers, there is so much to celebrate ... and so much to miss. Whisky and beer, of course, gin ndash a relatively new product thats gaining a global reputation ndash and then theres the cider, and the vodka, and the wine. And, just when you think youre getting a bit too spoilt for choice, Scottish rum rears its head.Its enough to make your head spin.In , the Scottish drinks industry has never been in a better place, racking up a string of record-breaking successes in the last decade.The brewing sector has increased by % since , according to a paper published in October by the Scottish Parliament Information Centre . This boost was mainly driven by micro-breweries, which represent % of Scotlands brewing business base.The same survey found that distilling-related ventures have grown by % since  and now number . The growth doesnt seem to be slowing either, with new distilleries apparently popping up like mushrooms after a rain shower.Leading the boom both at home and abroad is, unsurprisingly, the king of them all ndash whisky. According to the Scotch Whisky Association, in  the value of exports reached a record pound. billion, representing % of all UK food and drink exports.The main Scotch whisky export destinations by value are the USA , France , Singapore , Germany and Spain. India is in the top three in terms of volume of product imported, after France and the USA.It might surprise you to know that the United Kingdom wins is the worldrsquos largest exporter of spirit ... and % of that success is due to Scotch whisky.And one of the by-products of that success is now developing a global reputation in its own right.Over the past few years, a string new whisky distilleries have opened, keen to cash in on the earning power of Scotch whisky. There was only one problem ndash the spirit must me aged in oak casks for at least three years before it can even be called whisky, and most fans wont even look at it until its  or  years old.This creates some obvious cash-flow problems for the new ventures so, to keep the money coming in while they waited, many began producing gin, which can be bottled and sold on the day it is distilled. Many of these brands have gone global ndash think Harris gin and Eden Mill - and have added an extra impressive bow to Scotlands drink credentials.Although England holds a higher count of gin distilleries, it is estimated that around two-thirds of UK gin is made in Scotland, and there are around  gin distilleries north of the Border.To put that into perspective, there are  whisky distilleries.This golden period for Scotlands drink industry may have its roots in the traditions of whisky and beer, but as its expertise expands into other areas it is developing a reputation to rival global drinks giants such as the US or other European countries, in a way that only a few years ago could never have been imagined.But can Scotland be considered a superpower on the international drinking scene Distill gameScotlands whisky industry boasts some of the best-loved drinks brands in the world, and new distilleries are at ious stages of growth all over the country.For instance, later this year, Ardnahoe ndash the latest distillery on Islay ndash is expected to begin production. Glasgow distillery, which released its first single malt last June, should complete a further expansion plan by the end of the year, and crowdfunding has just started for a new distillery on Barra.However, while traditional whisky is, as ever, leading the way, innovation and experimentation are driving a new wave of growth. Aqua Vitae and the Lindores Abbey distillery is a case in point.In Edinburgh, Port of Leith Distillery is ringing the changes with more than its alcohol. Its Lind  Lime Gin is being made at its Tower Street Stillhouse ndash the first vertical distillery which wants to become a centre for research, innovation and learning.ldquoOur country is very lucky right now to have Scotch whisky. Its the worldrsquos premium spirit but there is no reason to suppose that this will continue for decades to come," said Port of Leith co-founder, Ian Stirling.ldquoOther countries are stealing a march in terms of exciting products that are being created. We think that itrsquos for everyonersquos benefit for the industry that Scotland remains an exciting place and, yes, we have a wonderful heritage to back look upon, but we need continue innovating to create excitement and for the eyes to look back at Scotland for something new and exciting.According to Ian, the Scotch whisky industry, however successful, faces a ldquogenerational sht and has to pace up with realities around the world:ldquoGoing back  years, when Paddy and I were first engaged with whisky, everything that was exciting in the whisky world was happening outside of Scotland. Some distillers here were doing interesting things, but the majority of excitement was in America, South East Asia, Australia.ldquoWhat we need is to see the same vibrance in Scotch whisky as we see in the other sectors, which is a huge challenge.The distillery received funding to create a Knowledge Transfer Partnership with world-renowned Heriot-Watt International Centre for Brewing and Distillingto develop a research scheme that will focus on fermentation and yeasts, but that will also allow the transfer of knowledge to students from the institute and, at the same time, nurturing and having access to skilled workforce on their doorstep.Sharing the knowledgeScotland has traditionally been a hub for people seeking to learn more about the national drink, in turn expanding the scope of Scottish influence abroad in the drinks industry. One notable example is the fathers of Japanese whisky, Mazataka Taketsuru and Shijiro Torii.The tradition lives on and Edinburgh is home to one of the industrys most important education centres worldwide ndash the ICBD at Heriot-Watt University. Providing the worldrsquos only degree in brewing and distilling , it attracts students from all over the world ndash especially for its postgraduate courses, also available as distance learning.Javin Chia, , from Singapore is a third-year undergraduate student in brewing and distilling. He was a home brewer and worked for the industry in his home country before moving to Scotland for study.ldquoHeriot-Watt was recommended to me by one of the guys who used to brew beer back in Singapore. He told me that it was a really good course: from the moment he graduated he was never out of the job, as this degree is highly regarded.ldquoThere are many people in the brewing and whisky industry who have done this particular course. I once met Shinji Fukuyo, master blender for Suntory [a Japanese drinks giant], and he told me he graduated from it, which really surprised me. This shows you the reputability it has.Javin has experienced the effect of the Scottish alcohol industry surge: ldquoSingapore had one of the highest growths in whisky imports in the last few years, and not because everyone drinks ndash Singapore is quite a small country, but it has become one of the most important distribution spots for South-East Asia. We have a lot of good specialist bars and people who are really passionate about whisky.ldquoGin is becoming very popular as well, brands like the Botanist are well known ndash and Brewdog, for craft beers. They are the ones who converted me to craft beer!High HopsBeyond distillation, Scotland excels on a global scale in the production of beer, and the intention is for it to grow even further. In December, Scotland Food and Drink published an industry strategy that aims to make Scottish brewing a pound billion industry by , allowing the creation of new jobs all over the country.Hilary Jones, chair of the Brewing Industry Leadership Group ndash in charge of the research on which the report is based ndash explained: ldquoIf you look back to less than two centuries ago, Scotland was one of the few great brewing nations. We were inventive, bringing technologists and chemists into our breweries."We created new beer types and brewed Porters, Stouts, IPAs and small batch beers, added botanicals and flavourings. We exported to the USA, Asia, Australia and Africa. Scotland now has over  operating breweries supporting over , jobs."Even though we have an unrivalled track record producing great beer and centuries of history behind us, the rising popularity of global craft beer means that Scotland needs to sharpen its gameit is to remain an international leader.Scotland has had a number of global brewing successes, especially in the realm of craft beers. Innis  Gunn and Stewart Brewing boast Scottish products that appear all over the world.However, the company that truly brought Scotland to the world stage in craft brewing is Brewdog. Founded in  in Ellon by James Watt and Martin Dickies, itrsquos now exported to more than  countries, has premises all over the world and has been listed in the Sunday Times Fast Track  for six years running.Its innovative approach to both production and business expansion has been a role model for the whole craft beer scene in the last few years. In  it started a new adventure with LoneWolf, expanding to the spirits scene ndash launching experimental products with vodkas, gins and whiskies at the core of their production.The futureThe expansion in Scotlands alcohol industry in the last decade has been incredibly fast and erse, and has brought global attention to the quality of production and the quest for innovation. But to stay ahead of the pack, there are many challenges to be addressed.Huge work has been done to give legal protection for the Scottish name and the provenance of its products, and to ensure the highest standards of production are met, but with other countries often throwing away the rule books and fully embraced new ideas, its important sure rules are not too rigid and producers are able to experiment and focus on research.In addition, the image of Scotlands premium products must not be allowed to stagnate. Drinks such as craft beer and gin are attracting younger fans, while Scotch whisky is often seen as a drink for older men.Its price tag ndash often unaffordable for younger drinkers ndash and its image for stuffy tradition can make it feel like the fuddy-duddy older cousin of new products such as gin and craft beer, where experimentation and fun are making the products feel fresh and accessible.There was a day, no so long ago, when beer suffered a similar image problem, but all it took was some creative thinking, some products of serious quality and innovative producers like Brewdog and a global transformation began.There is no doubt that, across the drinks industry in Scotland, the quality is there. Were still a world leader, and pass on our expertise to new generations of brewers and distillers all over the world.While a commitment to tradition will always be essential, whether the Scotland keeps its place at the top table of the global drinks industry will surely depend on whether it can take its own advice and push its own boundaries.

title: government-money-to-help-deliver-eight-new-works-by-eight-scottish-composers
story: AS this yearrsquos excellent Celtic Connections Festival draws to a close, itrsquos timely to reflect on the benefits of such a ied and exciting cultural calendar in Scotland.Festivals and events bring people together. The fusion of cultures, arts and creativity that form our cultural calendar demonstrate Scotlandrsquos reputation as an inclusive and welcoming nation, which is so important during these politically uncertain times.I have many highlights from this yearrsquos Celtic Connections. From speaking at the opening reception, listening to two of the UKrsquos foremost singer songwriters Katrine Polwart and Kris Drever alongside the Scottish Chamber Orchestra, attending the BBC Young Traditional Musician of the Year awards with the brilliant Benedict Morris, whose fiddling was on fire, and finally watching the world premiere of the rising Scottish stars Snuffbox with the excellent Zoe Rahman and trio ndash this yearrsquos festival has been one of the best.Scotland is the proud home of a huge iety of creative events, from folk and traditional music at Celtic Connections to the Edinburgh International Science Festival ndash there is something for everyone, locals and tourists alike.Aside from the social benefits of hosting such a vibrant festival calendar, these events also drive economic growth at both local and national level.Take Celtic Connections, an independent study conducted on their behalf revealed it generated over poundm from visitors in Scotland, providing a benefit of over poundm across Scotland.Since , the Scottish Governmentrsquos Festival Expo Fund has enabled the delivery and expansion of Scotlandrsquos major festivals with a contribution of poundm. The Festival Expo Fund provides an important opportunity to maximise innovation and creativity across the festival calendar and to provide for the international promotion of talented Scottish artists.This is the first year an event outside Edinburgh Festivals has received support from Expo Fund. In recognition of Celtic Connections excellent international reputation, the Festival received pound, from Expo to fund this yearrsquos lsquoAbove the Surfacersquo series of concerts, two of which I have just had the pleasure of attending this past week. Above the Surface promotes new strands of music evolving from the Scottish music scene.Building on the use of Expo funding by the innovative Celtic Connections for lsquoAbove the Surfacersquo this year, Irsquom very pleased to announce the funding they will receive for next yearrsquos edition of the festival.Celtic Connections is to receive pound,, subject to budgetary approval for the coming year, from the Festival Expo Fund for their proposal to deliver eight new works by eight Scottish composers. This work will then be developed by composer Greg Lawson into one Symphonic piece to be performed by the excellent GRIT Orchestra.This piece of work will be entitled lsquoThe Declarationrsquo ndash a reference to the th Anniversary of the Declaration of Arbroath. This musical masterpiece has potential to tour internationally post Celtic Connections , which is essential as we work to project Scottish culture and heritage to the world during these politically turbulent times.Over the past  years, Celtic Connections has grown into one of the worldrsquos largest winter music festivals with positive cultural and economic impacts on Glasgow and the rest of Scotland. The Festival brings talented Scottish artists with those from overseas across a range of genres of music together in a celebration of culture and music that transcends borders. Celtic Connections enables us to enhance our strong cultural relationships with other nations by increasing our understanding of each other through creative expression and traditions.We only need to look at the recent tourism statistics to see, tourists are still flocking to Scotland to see our beautul country.No doubt many of these tourists are engaging with our culture by attending a festival, whether it be warming up at a cosy Celtic Connections folk show in the depths of the Glasgow winter, or dancing through Edinburgh in the summer sun at a silent disco.It is during these uncertain times that the power of culture and the arts illustrate how we can come together and project Scotland as an inclusive and outward looking nation. It is essential that we support these efforts to ensure international visitors continue to choose Scotland as their preferred destination.We all benefit from a thriving cultural calendar that showcases our nation. The UK Governmentsrsquo plan to leave the EU is a threat to our cultural calendar and global reputation as an outward-looking nation. As the UK government insists on hostile immigration and visa policies, we in Scotland must work even harder to ensure our well known hospitality, warmth and welcome projects out to the world, ensuring Scotland remains attractive for both festival goers and performers.

title: calls-for-review-after-couple-sought-help-eight-times-before-north-lanarkshire-man-took-his-own-life
story: Karen McKeowns partner Luke Henderson was found dead in their Bellshill home in December , after the couple had begged for urgent treatment for his mental health dficulties eight times in the previous week.They spoke to  dferent medical professionals at NHS , GP surgeries, AE units and support services around North Lanarkshire before father-of-two Luke killed himself, and were either turned away or referred where.Karen is now calling for a complete review of mental health service provision across the NHS in Scotland and believes a Fatal Accident inquiryshould be held into her partners death.She has been supported by Dundee campaigner Gillian Murray, whose uncle David Ramsay also took his own le after being twice turned away from hospital.David was told to get some fresh air after being refused admittance to the Carseview unit in Dundee in .This week the pairs petition will be launched at the Scottish Parliament, which they hope will help highlight the problems with current services and prevent further ldquounnecessary deaths.It will also call for an automatic FAI into the death of anyone who dies by suicide and has engaged with mental health services in the three months prior to their death.Karen said: ldquoIt has taken a long time to get this far but I am confident this will help to start the conversation and help politicians, and members of the public who dont know about this, see there is something drastically wrong with our mental health services in Scotland.ldquoLuke shouldnt have died. We tried everything we could to get him help and he was still failed.ldquoI wasnt listened to by doctors who kept telling me he was not suicidal. He hadnt slept for days and was behaving abnormally, yet they seemed to think he was fine.ldquoI have to do everything I can to make sure this will not happen to anyone . It needs to change, and people need to be able to access help when they need it, immediately.Karen, , has asked for an inquiry into her partners death, but has been refused by the Crown Office.She has also met the mental health minister Clare Haughey, but said she felt let down by the politicians lack of understanding of the seriousness of the problem facing people across the country.NHS Lanarkshire have previously denied any wrongdoing following a review of the circumstances surrounding Lukes death, and say their staff acted appropriately.Karen, said: ldquoIf we cannot get people the help they need urgently, when they are in the most vulnerable state, then what chance do we have of stopping this happening again  I know this isnt just a problem where I live. It is happening all over Scotland and its about time mental illness is treated the same way as a physical problem.Gillian, , said: ldquoThis petition is vital because it has been apparent that mental health failings are not unique to NHS Tayside . The same failings are happening up and down the country."The culture of secrecy and denial in the NHS needs to stop no lessons will ever truly be learnt until we have genuinely independent and transparent investigations."It is wrong that a prisoner who dies in custody will get an automatic FAI yet those who die in hospital or, in Davidrsquos Ramsay and Luke Hendersonrsquos cases contact with the NHS in the days leading up to their deaths yet were turned away. We have to fight for an FAI to find out why these failings happened "Something needs to change and quickly too many people are dying. There are too many of us saying the same thing for this to be a coincidence.Following the death of fellow campaigner Gillians uncle David, an inquiry was launched into the Carseview unit at Ninewells hospital in Dundee.Relatives of at least  people who have died by suicide claim the deaths could have been avoided.Another man, Dale Thompson also took his own le days after being discharged from Carseview in .His distraught mother previously told MSPs that his son was informed there was ldquonothing wrong with him.The health board admitted in  that Dales ldquocare and treatment fell below the standard.It is the latest in a series of concerns raised about psychiatric facility, which is also at the centre of abuse allegations.

title: eilean-donan-castle-why-iconic-scottish-landmark-is-actually-only-100-years-old
story: But for many years Eilean Donan castle did not look as it does now, and this year marks  years since the fateful battle which left the castle in ruins after destruction by the British during the Jacobite rising.Two hundred years later work began on restoring Eilean Donan to its former glory by John MacRae-Gilstrap of Clan MacRae.Sitting between the three sea lochs of Loch Long, Loch Alsh, and Loch Duich, the castle was used as a stronghold by Spanish invaders during the uprising in a bid to restore James Stuart, son of James IV of Scotland, to the throne.The castle was under heavy bombardment from British naval ships for several days and, eventually, after barrels of gunpowder were set alight, the Eilean Donan was demolished and would not be lived in for over  years.Dr Iain MacInnes is an expert in medieval Scotland from the University of the Highlands and Islands. He spoke about how the castle has had a long history of importance to Scotland:ldquoIt is perhaps its location that makes it special, on the road to Skye, and regularly voted as one of Scotlandrsquos most picturesque castles. There is little doubting its romantic location and its general setting.ldquoThe fact that a castle appears to have existed in some form on this site from the very early middle ages suggests that it was situated at an important strategic location.ldquoIts access to the sea meant it would likely have acted not just as a castle, but also as a harbour for ships connected to the ruling families in the area, from which they could project their sea power over the region.ldquoThis was an important part of lordship in this region, where travel by water was probably more important than travel by land. Its likely th-century origins also relate to providing defence in depth against Scandinavian raids and incursions in a period when Scoto-Norse relations were not good.Dr MacInnes also says that, as with many of Scotlandrsquos Castles, Robert the Bruce may have paid a visit as part of his conquest of Scotland.ldquoClan history suggests that Robert the Bruce stayed at Eilean Donan in - on his flight westwards following his defeat at the battle of Methven, he said.ldquoThere is no corroborative evidence for this, however, and the temptation to be associated with the warrior king is quite a strong one in many clan histories, so this might well come under the heading of myth.ldquoAnd, as with many Scottish castles, there is the ghost of a mysterious lady also associated with it. Scottish folklore has a lot to answer for."There is even a suggestion of a Mathesonbeing able to speak to birds. Make of that what you will.ldquoIts last hurrah in the Jacobite uprising of  is a pretty spectacular way to go out!Between  and , work began on the rebuilding of Eilean Donan by Lieutenant-Colonel John MacRae-Gilstrap. As well as adding the famous footbridge to connect the island to the mainland, the castle itself was restored to stand just as it had done for hundreds of years before its destruction.Now, visitors from all over Scotland and the world come to visit it, take pictures and even marry there, cementing its status as a Scottish cultural icon.Clan Mackenzie, along with Clan Macrae, has a special affinity with the castle, as it was the stronghold of the Clan for many years. A committee member of the Clan Mackenzie Society spoke about the clans long association with the fortress: ldquoIt seems reasonably clear that the Mackenzies had lost control of Eilean Donan in the first half of the th century, they said.ldquoThen, following a long exile on the part of the chief, Murdoch Dubh, he finally seems likely to have recovered the familyrsquos power base in a purported Royal Charter of  ndash which was purported to have been further confirmed in  to his son in a grant from the Exchequer.ldquoBecause of the Mackenzies power-base in this region it was chosen as the landing place for the Jacobite invasion, which was aided by Spanish troops but defeated in the glen near the castle by the English General Wightman.ldquoThe Mackenzie chief, William Dubh , the th Earl and nd Jacobite Marquis of Seaforth, played a heroic role in this rising before being wounded and carried across the mountainsto exile and safety.ldquoThe MacRaes also played an important role in the history of the castle, since they are a local clan who were the traditional bodyguards of the Mackenzie chief and their own chiefs had been the hereditary constables of Eilean Donan and were consequently dubbed lsquoMackenziersquos Shirt-of-Mailrsquo.

title: happy-birthday-facebook-or-is-it
story: The back story is as rich and seemingly as unlikely as a movie script and was the nub of the narrative in the  Oscar-winning film The Social Network.It all began in  when Mark Zuckerberg and friends created an online programme called Facemash in a dorm room in Kirkland House on the Hard campus.It was created as a  to connect students,only to rate each otherrsquos attractiveness, and Zuckerberg almost faced expulsion. There were other online directories but none which cover the entire student body.Overnight successOn February , , the first version of Facebook ndash then known as thefacebook ndash was unveiled for students. It proved a raging, overnight success. There were claims that Zuckerberg had stolen the idea from three other students, and four years later he agreed to settle their law suit with . million shares in the company to each one.What was unique about Facebook was that with a few strokes on the keyboard it united friends, no matter where in the world they lived, whether or not they had recently been in contact, it allowed people to share ideas, memories, photographs, every day thoughts and ambitions. Celebrities clicked on that this was an unspun, unadulterated way of reaching fans. And previous unknowns became newborn stars on Facebook. The  spawned the social media phenomenon.It also quickly became clear that this had a huge advertising potential and as Facebook perfected its research, amassed its data and finessed its algorithms the targeting of people, based on their likes and comments on the .It enabled them to reach into the homes and minds, likes and ambitions of anyone who had signed up. And for only a fraction of conventional advertising. Facebook took off and Zuckerberg was on his way to a personal fortune of somewhere north of  billion.He was canny enough to realise, also, thathe couldnrsquot quash any opposition he could buy it out. Facebook gobbled up Instagram for  billion, and then WhatrsquosApp, but so far the owners of Snapchat have resisted. Zuckerberg, true to form, has adapted Instagram to mimic and embellish his competitorrsquos . While he may be a digital innovator he is an old-school capitalist entrepreneur.Digitalrsquos dark sideFACEBOOK, Instagram and other social media s have been blamed for everything from kne crime to teenage suicide. Last week a parent, Ian Russell, blamed Instagram for the death of his -year-old daughter Molly, who took her own le in November . Her Instagram, account contained horric material about depression and suicide.Russell said: ldquoThe more I looked, the more there was that chill horror that I was getting a glimpse into something that had such profound effects on my lovely daughter.This prompted the Childrenrsquos Commissioner for England to write an open letter to all social media s, accusing them of losing control of the content they carried. Anne Longfield called for the creation of a ldquodigital ombudsman to ensure that companies were protecting young children and the vulnerable and to quicken the removal of disturbing material.UK Health Secretary Matt Hancock also warned that he would use the lawthey donrsquot clean their act.Social media has also been blamed for soaring of kne crime, particularly among young people. politan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick claimed trivial disputes could escalate into violence ldquowithin minutes when rivals goaded each other online.In July last year Facebookrsquos value on the stock market dropped by a record  billion in just two hours. This happened immediately after the company posted its quarterly results, the first full financial report since the Cambridge Analytica scandal broke, and although it was the poor sales results which prompted the fall, the social traumas besetting the company may well have been a contributor.The company dropped in value to around bn and Zuckerberg lost almost bn from his personal holding ndash down to a mere bn.Zuckerbergrsquos purchase of Instagram in  was another masterstroke. He realised Facebook had an ageing demographic and Instagram was a key to the youth market. Before acquisition Facebook had been worth bn, at close of play on Friday, despite last yearrsquos fall, it was still topping bn.Last week Facebook proved the doubters wrong, moving back towards its Teflon-coated status. Its fourth-quarter earnings showed a  per cent growth on  with revenues of almost bn, topping Wall Street estimates by more than m. As he looks back tomorrow -year-old Zuckerberg will have no trepidation about the future.How rumour and suspicion surround data gatheringTHE sheer volume of data Facebook holds, and shares between its other arms, is dficult to comprehend. It logs every action by you and your friends and also substantial offsite browsing through its share button. It also co-ordinates and collates information provided by friends.There have also been repeated claims that the app eavesdrops on your conversations and then targets advertisements tailored to you.One freelance journalist once claimed that after a conversation with her partner about urination devices for their camper-van that next day an ad for them popped up on her timeline.A later discussion about a stabbing brought an ad for a stab-proof vest, she said.Facebook denies spying and ascribes events like this to part of a long-standing conspiracy theory, but therersquos no denying that its apps often include an agreement giving permission to access your camera and microphone because people film video and take pictures for Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp and its Messenger service.Last year Facebook became embroiled in the controversy over the British company Cambridge Analytica and the targeting of political ads during the  US presidential elections and the UK referendum.Facebook shared the data from  million accounts with the company which then used the information to convince potential Trump voters to turn out to vote, and Leavers to do the same.Zuckerberg was asked three times to testy before a UK parliamentary committee investigating the Cambridge data-harvesting scam but refused, nominating deputies in his stead.

title: two-decades-of-glasgay-how-the-legendary-festival-helped-shape-lgbt-scotland
story: Now more than  years since it launched, the Glasgay! Festival may no longer exist, but its legacy remains.Launched just  years after homosexuality was decriminalised in Scotland, Glasgay was the first of its kind and gave mainly lesbian and gay artists a much-needed  to showcase their talents.Later producers expanded the concept to include commissions from LGBT artists including makar Jackie Kay and the late performer Diane Torr.Legendary film maker John Waters, comedian Alan Carr and actor Sir Ian McKellen were also among the line-up.Founded with a backdrop of Section  legislation ndash when UK local authorities were banned from publishing material about, or promoting, homosexuality ndash Glasgay! wasnrsquot without controversy.Articles from the time stated that the ldquoarty farty festival for homosexuals was ldquobeyond a joke while others decried organisers, saying it was a waste of public money.Cordelia Ditton, co-founder of Glasgay!, explained: ldquoIt was kind of bonkers ndash so outlandish.ldquoOne of the articles I remember reading literally talked about lsquothe twilight world of the homosexualrsquo. I thought lsquoyou cannot have a paper like this, talking about gay people like that.ldquoDue to Section  [brought in ] a lot of people were very politicised about lesbian and gay rights and how we were seen.ldquoWhen I moved to Glasgow in  I was amazed as there was very little visibility. There were certainly things going on below the surface and people doing some amazing work, but it was largely invisible. I found it strange and thought there had to be something we could do.ldquoI thought it wasnrsquot fair. We wanted to make the argument that we pay our taxes and we disproportionately contribute to the arts, so itrsquos about time we had something for, and about, us as well.Cordelia teamed up with freelance arts administrator Dominic DrsquoAngelo and put on the first Glasgay! in , with more than  events running between October  and November .However funding, which was a long-running issue for the event over its  years, forced a blackout in  and again in  before the organisers stepped down and a new team took over.Steven Thomson, producer from  until , said his focus was on not only curating a festival but commissioning artists who were under-represented.He said: ldquoIn  we had got this award from an American travel guide which listed Glasgow as the fourth top gay destination in the world. There were people in the world looking at what we were doing and they thought it was great. There was, however, constant backlash on our own doorstep.ldquoWe still had the camp stereotypes of Julian Clarey mincing about on TV or Gimme Gimme Gimme where there was constant boyfriend issues.ldquoI recognised I had to change that. I began to talk about the idea that Glasgay! should commission its own work. There was a wealth of female writers out there, particularly Jackie Kay and Louise Welsh, Zoe Strachan and Stef Smith who were just not getting the chance from the mainstream theatres, which were mainly led by English men.By , LGBT rights in Scotland had changed drastically since the first festival  years earlier.Section  had been repealed, and employment law prohibiting discrimination based onsexuality was introduced in . Civil partnerships for same-sex couples was legalised in , and same-sex marriages were approved in .The TIE campaign, which has successfully campaigned for LGBT issues to be taught in Scottish schools, was just getting off the ground following the Independence Referendum in September .However, with austerity cuts, the festival failed to secure long-term funding in  and was forced to close. The event, which burst on to the scene with such controversy in  fizzled away with an uncharacteristic lack of drama.The decision to keep quiet about what had happened was hard, explained Steven.He said: ldquoWe didnrsquot really make a big deal of it, but when Creative Scotland changed the whole funding process, we applied to be a regularly funded client as we had been before.ldquoIn  we didnrsquot get through.ldquoI had seen many years of people and organisations going down. I witnessed a lot of loss, and the reality is we felt that we could pull Creative Scotland apart for this, but we ultimately wouldnrsquot survive by laundering that in public.Stevensaid he hasnrsquot ldquoruled out bringing the festival back, and will next week launch a retrospective publication featuring photographs and highlights from its  yearsOrganised by Outspoken Arts, the charity which replaced Glasgay organisers Gala Scotland Ltd in , the launch takes place on February  at the Tron Theatre, Glasgow.

title: future-shock-how-daniel-odonnell-revealed-the-secret-truth-of-human-evolution-and-the-viral-nature-of-reality
story: Well, of course it does. Although all things from ants to elephants hear vastly dfering frequencies, the objective reality of sound existed long before sensory organs evolved to detect it. Trees will continue to fall with a crack and thud long after our brief, torrid stewardship of this planet is over.Yet, whatthe person who observed that falling tree lacked the ability to form memories  Certainly, theyrsquod have no frame of reference to comprehend a tree. And without memory, stuck inside an eternal millisecond, that person would also have zero awareness of their own conciousness. Time would simply cease to exist, melting away like a Dali clock. A perceivable reality would simply not exist. Le would be indistinguishable from death. No trees would ever fall.Itrsquos a truth staggering in its obviousness. That each creature on this planet ndash in the universe, perhaps ndash is only able to exist,and evolve due to their brainrsquos ability to store information. And thanks to a revelatory new discovery, many scientists now believe cerebral stickiness didnrsquot actually co-evolve with the brain, as once presumed.It now looks likely that all consciousness is simply the result of an ancient viral infection ndash one we, thankfully, canrsquot shake off. And although this mysterious affliction remains incurable, it is no longer undetectable.Great story, ArcGENETICISTS recently studying lsquoArcrsquondash a gene active within our neurons and understood to be responsible for forming and retaining memory ndash werenrsquot quite prepared for what they discovered. It seems special proteins created by Arc do something astonishing ndash they shape themselves into the unmistakable Hellraiser ldquoPinhead shape of a virus.The genetic evidence strongly suggests this mysterious organism first infected a common ancestor of ours around  million years ago and, apparently, completely altered its primitive brain.By transmitting genetic code through its RNA, the virus actually gave this pre-dinosaur organism and its descendants the same gt I got on Christmas morning  on VHS ndash Total Recall. Over millions of years, this new ability gave rise to consciousness itself. And, eventually, you and I.Itrsquos certainly a disturbing and novel spin on the origin of our acute self-awareness, perhaps confirming once and for all that we are not sospecial as a species. Itrsquos quite likely we are simply durable skin bags, built by nature to safely incubate and transport viruses. If we are indeed just drone mules gted a small degree of universal awareness by the viral occupants of our brains, at least we mutually benefit by such co-dependence by being aware of our three score and ten blink-in-the-eye-of-infinity wee existences.Itrsquos certainly unarguable that the evolutionary advantage of being able to form memories eventually led some curious apes to launch steel phalluses towards the moon ndash and also creating the medium yoursquore reading these words on. It also allowed these apes to work out they were on a spherical rock that was spinning around a nuclear furnace in the middle of infinity.That said, itrsquos possible that human scientic endeavour itself is simply the ancient virus attempting to understand itself by evolving brains of the organisms it has infected. It did come first, after all.An enlightened voiceIF memory is indeed a virus, what does this mean for we egotistical humans who have historically believed ourselves a cut above the rest of the species on this planet  Certainly, many enlightened members of our tribe have tried to tell us over the years that the miracle of memory is key to solving the mysteries of consciousness and the human condition.The first known study of memory was Aristotlersquos treatise ldquoOn The Soul, the title of which might also be the first known instance of irony. The philosopherrsquos then-heretical musings suggested wehumans are simply blank slates, not animated by any magical eternal soul, there was no afterle and we are simply the sum of our experiences. Aristotle wasnrsquot invited to many parties.Although countless philosophers and intellectuals have come and gone since his death  years ago, few humans have advanced Aristotlersquos studious musings on the enigma of memory and true nature of reality more than Irish singer Daniel OrsquoDonnell.Although his work is often dismissed by accepted mainstream perception as offensively featherweight easy-listening, serious academic study of OrsquoDonnellrsquos remarkable oeuvre exposes a rich wealth of philosophical truisms and florid accounts of how memory has the power to set us free yet, ultimately, cages us.On record, the Irishmanrsquos towering intellect and acute sensitivity to the human condition hides in plain sight. Perhaps only upon his passing will be realise we were blessed to exist in the same spacetime as this scientist of the human heart ndash one who dedicated his le to exploring the enigma of memory.ldquoRemember Yoursquore Mine, ldquoRemember Me, ldquoLast Thing On My Mind, ldquoDonrsquot Forget to Remember and the ingenious ldquoI Forgot To Remember To Forget are clearly all evergreen roadmaps for the soul, yet, such an obvious obsession with memory suggests that the Arc gene may be stronger in luminaries such as OrsquoDonnell and Aristotle than the rest of us ndash the virus perhaps using such enlightened vessels to elevate the entire human collective consciousness and evolve us all into transdimensional orbs madeof pure light.Perhaps instead of a tree falling, the classic thought experiment should ask: does a Daniel OrsquoDonnell album make a soundno-one is around to hear it play  And, this time, the answer would certainly be no.For surely, only human ears could ever empathise with the great truths exposed by OrsquoDonnell, whose entire -album body of work exists as one long bittersweet ode to mortality and the imprint of memories upon our finite existence. The singer often falls back upon the truism that wersquore only truly gone when those who remember us die themselves, but therersquos surely room within OrsquoDonnellrsquos defiant optimism to also consider one other possibilty ndash that the immortal virus that granted us conciousness may also be capable of remembering its long lineage of mortal hosts. And thus, we live on forever.And finally ...APPLICATION of the scientic method may not always be immediately apparent within OrsquoDonnellrsquos lyrics, yet repeated listening reveals an abiding obsession with the processes of the natural world. His hymn to the epic scope of geological time, ldquoMy Donegal Shore perfectly illustrates this infatuation, an evocative work inspired by the wealth of ancient bioersity on the western Irish coastline, where the Atlantic has thrown up many exotic fossils, flora and fauna.That OrsquoDonnell has found a meeting point between intellectual prowess and strong religious faith is to his credit.
