Not many believers in ine creation are sympathetic to suggestions that their inner worlds are simply illusions projected by a  million year old virus burrowed deep inside their brains.Yet, mere secular laymen can perhaps never truly understand what quells the contradictions warring within such a unique, quicksilver mind as OrsquoDonnellrsquos.All answers are perhaps found within the work itself, abundant with analogy for OrsquoDonnellrsquos highwire balancing act on the tightrope between faith and science.Certainly, ldquoThe Time That God Sends lends itself better to a chorus than ldquoA Prehistoric Virus Infected Us With A Limited Frequency Of Consciousness Within A Finite Slice Of Spacetime.Follow Bill on Twitter: futureshockbb

title: no-financial-deal-for-scotlands-declining-oil-gas-industry-without-detailed-climate-change-plan-say-mps
story: A report published today by the Scottish Affairs Committee recommends that the poundm industry and government partnership deal should be supported to ensure that Scotlandrsquos oil and gas industry can "navigate the challenges of its future and continue to prosper".The highlight of the deal involves the creation of new centres of excellence, one of which has just opened near Aberdeen. It is believed it would deliver up to pound billion in North Sea revenues between now and .But the committee said that adapting to low carbon was "one of the main challenges" facing the oil and gas sector and that before finalising the sector deal ministers should ensure the industry brings forward "a more detailed proposal" on how this will be achieved.Carbon capture, usage and storage technologycan capture up to % of CO emissions produced from the use of fossil fuels in electricity generation and industrial processes, thereby preventing the carbon dioxide from entering the atmosphere.Professor Corienne Le Quere, memberof the Committee on Climate Change, told the committee that for ldquothe cost-effective path to meet emission targets needs thetechnology of carbon capture and storage.And the MPs say that before the oil and gas sector could be "more ambitious" in this area. And they say that before asector deal is sealed, the industry should bring forward a "more detailed proposal" on how the three centres will support the development of CCUS technology and how their success will be measured.But Friends of the Earth Scotland said the committee had proposed "the weakest possible conditions" for tackling climate change saying that all they have asked for is for operations to become "a bit more efficient"."This industry will make some vague promises and the committee will feel it has achieved something but it is trivial compared to the real problem," warned Dr Richard Dixon director of Friends of the Earth Scotland.ldquoThis is an utterly complacent report which slavishly supports the oil and gas industryrsquos aim of getting every last drop of oil out of the North Sea while assuming that eye-wateringly expensive technology will save the industry from its own carbon emissions.Scottish Development International produced a promotional video last year for Scotlands oil and gas sectorldquoClimate change is an existential crisis for human civilisation and this report could have marked a turning point by acknowledging that we need to leave most of the fossil fuels we know about where they are."Instead it fully sanctions the industry to continue to fry the planet. The oil industry must be laughing all the way to the bank but all of us will feel the climate consequences of this political cowardice."The report is the result of the committees examination of the challenges facing the oil and gas sector and how they can be tackled, and ways to secure the future of oil and gas in Scotland as reserves decline.:North Sea gas discovery hailed as possibly the biggest for  yearsWhile the oil and gas industry has generated some pound billion in revenues since the start of the s, these have been in decline.The committee stressed that the oil and gas industry "urgently needs" the sector deal pointing out that Scotland is at the forefront of the global oil and gas industry, contributing pound.bn to the Scottish economy in  and supports , jobs in Scotland.The MPs argue it is also central to the UKrsquos energy security, with it being forecast that two-thirds of the UKrsquos primary energy needs will be met by oil and gas until at least .The committee said: "Whilst we acknowledge environmental concerns about theMERstrategy, oil and gas looks likely to form a substantial part of the UKrsquos energy mix for at least the next  years. As such, we believe it makes sense to meet as much of this need as possible from domestic sources."But the report acknowledges that this will come at a cost.According to a  study in the scientic journal Nature, an estimated third of oil reserves, half of gas reserves and more than % of known coal reserves should remain unused in order to meet global temperature targets under the Paris Agreement.And Friends of the Earth has recommended they should reassess the MER policy against its legal commitments under the Paris Agreement and the Climate Change Act , and propose an alternative strategy for the UK Continental Shelf which would be in line with it.:Edinburgh oil firm highlights profitability ofNorth SeaproductionThe Governmentrsquos figures for CO emissions by fuel type show total emissions from oil and gas in  were . metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent, accounting for more than % of the UKrsquos total.Oil and Gas UK has argued that ldquoin the foreseeable future, oil and gas is going to play a key part in the energy mix, representing two thirds of primary energy in the UK in  and so "maximising domestic production was important" because it would reduce reliance on fuel imports which can be more carbon intensive.Oil and Gas which is jointly heading the strategy which aims to ldquodouble the productive le of the basin through maximising economic recovery and doubling the UKrsquos share of the global goods and services market says the billions in revenue will benefit companies and the workforce in Scotland.One of the three centres of excellence proposed focuses on developing technology to support an energy transition to a lower carbon economy and would involve the industry and government investing poundm each.An poundm underwater innovation hub would lead on research and development.A third centre in Newburgh, which opened earlier this month, will prioritise cost-effective decommissioning of over  s forecast for removal over the next decade.Scottish affairs committee chairman Pete Wishart said: ldquoScotland should be enormously proud of its globally recognised oil and gas industry. However, the industry is going through a period of immense change as it prepares for a challenging future, and the Government urgently needs to step up and support the industry."My committeersquos report sets out a pathway for the future of the industry a sector deal that would support the industryrsquos past, present and future.ldquoThere is potentially another  years of oil and gas production in the North Sea but itrsquos important the sector uses this time to ensure the sectorrsquos future as production starts to slow.

title: glasgows-landmark-town-and-gown-deal-to-tackle-poverty
story: The new memorandum of understanding will see Glasgow City Council work with partners in higher and further education to ensure policies which seek to tackle poverty are backed by the best available evidence.The partnership will also seek to improve access for young people from disadvantaged areas to get to college or university.The memorandum has been signed by Susan Aitken, leader of the council, and representatives from the universities of Glasgow, Strathclyde and Glasgow Caledonian.It has also been backed by City of Glasgow College, Glasgow Clyde College, Glasgow Kelvin College, the Glasgow School of Art, the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, the Open University and the Glasgow Colleges Regional Board.Mrs Aitken described the signing as a ground-breaking relationship ldquobetween town and gown where partners would work across traditional boundaries.She said: ldquoThis agreement creates a partnership of real depth between town and gown in Glasgow, one which will enhance and enrich the policy-making process.ldquoIt is a historic agreement, bringing us much closer together with the remarkable breadth and depth of Glasgowrsquos academic sector.ldquoThe agreement provides the base for all its signatories to assert our civic commitment, to work across our boundaries to make a better Glasgow, whether at the highest level of building international links and attracting inward investment, or right down to local issues of inclusivity, such as bringing young people from challenged communities into our learning institutions.Professor Neal Juster, a senior vice-principal at Glasgow University, added: ldquoWe are delighted to be working in partnership with the city to ensure policy is based on the best possible evidence and advice.ldquoOur universities and colleges have a fantastic range of expertise which the city can benefit from in areas like innovation, inclusive growth, housing and public health.ldquoAs a university and as a wider sector, we are determined to play a full and active role in the public le of the city, recognising that when the Glasgow prospers, so do our academic institutions.

title: sinn-feins-mcdonald-suggests-westminster-has-no-interest-in-scotland
story: Sinn Feins seven elected MPs do not take their seats in the House of Commons, despite repeated calls to do so during key Brexit votes.On whether Sinn Fein would ever take their seats, Ms McDonald told the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr on Sunday programme that the seven votes would be ineffective and her party was resolute in their stance."I have no business in Westminster, we have no business in your parliament," declared the partyrsquos leader."Westminster, correctly, advances and protects what it regards to be British interests. We have no business interfering in that. I am Irish we have two parliaments and we advance Irish interests.She went on: "I look at the experience of our Scottish colleagues and I see them at Westminster, theres -odd, and they would readily attest that Westminster has no interest in Scotland either. Westminster has never served Irish interests, its not constituted to do that Irish interests are defended in Dublin and Belfast."Ms McDonald added that the Good Friday Agreement would have to be revisited in the event of a hard Brexit on March  and an Irish unity referendum should be held."Put simply,the border in Ireland cannot be mitigated, cannot be managed in the short term, well then you put the question democratically in the hands of the people and allow them to remove the border. Bear in mind the people of Northern Ireland did not consent to Brexit.""The backstop is the bottom line. On the issue of the border poll, theres no point us burying our heads in the sand and wish away a hard Brexit. We prepare for the worst scenario and protect our national interest."Ms McDonald told Marr that anyone gambling with peace on the island of Ireland was acting recklessly."One of the biggest symbols of success of the peace process is that people can travel unimpeded over the border."Any controls or checks or security checks, any question of British soldiers at the border - the Taoiseach has been clear there will be no Irish soldiers on the border- no one will accept the hardening of the border on our island."The peace process is very solid, very robust, we are only going forward and we are not going back, it would be grossly reckless and irresponsible of the Tories to play a game of chicken with that progress."Peace on this island is a precious thing, shame on anybody who would play games with that," added the Sinn Fein leader, who represents Dublin Central in the Irish Parliament.But Labourrsquos Barry Gardiner hit back, saying he was very upset by Ms McDonaldrsquos suggestion that Westminster was only interested in Britain.ldquoThat is absolutely not the case, declared the Scot. ldquoPoliticians in Westminster are working hard to make sure that all parts of the United Kingdom, including Northern Ireland, are considered and respected and upheld.ldquoThe upholding of the Belfast Agreement, the Good Friday Agreement, is one of the central things we are looking to do, insisted the Shadow International Trade Secretary.

title: under-review-princes-vision-for-scots-poundbury-on-hold-for-year
story: The pioneering eco-village, Knockroon, was the dream of Prince Charlesrsquos flagship charitable foundation and touted as a ldquomodel community for Scotland.But eight years after construction began on the effort to build Scotlandrsquos own version of the Princersquos Poundbury sustainable village in Dorset, it has emerged that just  homes out of a planned  have been built.Now, the Princersquos Foundation - which pumped millions of pounds into the East Ayrshire project - has revealed the housing site will be ldquoreviewed and evaluated over the next year.In recent annual accounts published by Companies House, the charity said it was taking time to pause and consider Knockroonrsquos evolution.It states: ldquoThe development company continues to work towards making good defects and developing the infrastructure for the roads and pavements. Over the next year the Knockroon project will be reviewed and evaluated. Following review, a comprehensive plan of development will be presented for consideration before the next phase of work commences.The Prince of Wales acquired land at Knockroon, near Cumnock, in  as part of a wider pound million deal to save the th century Palladian mansion, Dumfries House, for the nation.Some pound million of his own charitable foundationsrsquo cash was put into the project, and Knockroonrsquos blueprint was granted outline planning permission by East Ayrshire Council in .At the time it laid out a vision for  houses,  of which were to have been built by  and the project was endorsed by the ScottishGovernmentas an ldquoambitious and inspiring design example, quickly dubbed Scotlandrsquos rival to Poundbury in Dorset.Plans for the site, between Cumnock and Auchinleck, had been to create ldquoa vibrant, sustainable community.But nearly a decade on from the documents being submitted, just  homes have been built and the future is uncertain.Poundbury, meanwhile, was inspired by Prince Charlesrsquos vision of urban le where roads, schools, health centres, shops and parks blend in with landscaped homes.At the beginning of , approximately , people were living in Poundbury and over , people were working in businesses there.Situated between Cumnock and Auchinleck, the plans for the Scots village grew out of a -acre site secured as part of the rescue package spearheaded by the Prince for Dumfries House.Back in , Prince Charles said: ldquoJust as we are what we eat, I believe we are what we are surrounded by. The art of place-making was all but dead, as was the skill of creating genuine communities rather than rather soulless housing estates, until I determined to revive these timeless skills over  years ago. Although it seems misunderstood, my concern for design is part of a much wider concern about the impact places have on the people who live or work in or around them. My concern is for the built environment as a whole and how that environment affects the way people feel and live.And referring specically to Knockroon, said: ldquoThe aim here is to regenerate the area by creating a vibrant, sustainable community with houses, offices, shops and a school.Professor Alan Dunlop, a fellow of the Royal Incorporation of Architects in Scotland and the Royal Society of Arts, said, though, that ldquoit has not delivered on its vision.He said: ldquoThe original marketing promised heritage-led regeneration and the delivery of both a new community and improved quality of le.ldquoIt has not delivered on these ambitions and its ersatz Georgian and mock Scottish vernacular creations have done little to attract industry or to inspire other volume house builders.ldquoThis area surely cries out for authentic investment in good quality housing, which local people can relate to and can afford. Imported pastiche from past centuries is not the appropriate response.Gordon Neil, deputy executive director of the Princersquos Foundation, said: ldquoThe Princersquos Foundation remains fully committed to realising its vision for Knockroon. A decade has passed since the creation of the masterplan for the site, and much has changed in that time in terms of the local and wider economy.ldquoAs in all long-term construction projects, it is incumbent on us, the developers, to remain flexible and adaptable to changing conditions throughout the build, and we will conduct a review that allows us to ensure we create a development that meets the needs of the community."In line with The Princersquos Foundationrsquos commitment to offering education and training opportunities where possible, modern apprenticeships will be offered across all trades on the development.

title: Marianne Taylor  The moral case for independence is clear  but it s a hard sell economically
story: Mr Robertson lost his Westminster seat at the  general election, but rather than spend time pursuing another, he has sensibly put his energy and talents into something potentially more useful: a think tank.He believes Progress Scotland, just launched with respected pollster Mark Dfney, can build the case for independence by providing insight and analysis on what it will take to persuade the undecided.Think tanks are viewed by many as little more than talking shops. But the work they do in rigorously researching and testing not only how the electorate thinks but, crucially, why it thinks that way, is crucial. Such organisations bring proper depth and understanding to political thinking, paving the way for better policies.Marianne Taylor: Brexit reveals Germanys unrequited love for UKAnd never has Scotland been more in need of rigorous thinking than now. The terrible situation we find ourself in, about to be ripped from the European Union against our will and plunged off the no-deal clf, wilfully ignored by a robotic Prime Minister most focused on keeping her partyrsquos fringe extremists happy, demands action. Or at least options, and independence remains the most obvious.The moral and democratic case for independence gets stronger and clearer by the day as the grim inability of Westminster to deal with the gravity of the situation plays out. On one side of the house you have a Tory party gone rogue, prepared to abandon its own fundamental principles and trash the country economically, socially and culturally in the name of a glorious English past that never was.On the opposition benches, meanwhile, you have a bafflingly ideological and ineffectual Labour party willing to harm the very people it claims to represent by allowing this madness to go unchecked. No wonder the partyrsquos membership in Scotland has noseed by  per cent in the last year.The perfect storm indeed. Some in Scotland - certainly those who shout the loudest on social media - would have you believe it is also the perfect time for another independence referendum. But as the democratic case for Scotland leaving the UK strengthens, the economic arguments are harder than ever to make.If an independent Scotland was a hard sell in  with both sides of the border inside the EU, the possible and probable consequences of the current stalemate are mindboggling. Imagine the economic ramications for an independent Scotland inside the EU, while its next door neighbour and biggest trading partner is outside the customs union, making tarfs necessary on every product or service that crosses what would quite possibly have to be a hard border. Then throw into the mix that they donrsquot use the same currency. All this may be happening to a Scotland and England already economically traumatised by the aftermath of a hard Brexit. Could Scots be persuaded to vote to potentially make themselves poorer in the short-term to achieve longer term prosperity  The Leave campaign persuaded a majority in England and Wales to largely ignore economics in , of course.Marianne Taylor: Brexit reveals Germanys unrequited love for UKThen therersquos the fact that referendums themselves have become the stuff of nightmares for many of us. The last two years of chaos and ision have shown that a close result on independence ndash say - in favour ndash could potentially be just as disastrous. The anger and disgust felt by many, meanwhile, at the Westminster class only highlights the distrust most of us feel towards all politicians. They have betrayed us.One can only imagine, of course, how the newly souped-up, Brexit-ed UK would look to thwart Scotlandrsquos independent ambitions. The arrogance and disrespect with which the UK Government has already dealt with the EU and Holyrood tells you much. And look at what is happening to Northern Ireland ultimately the Tory party has shown itself willing to sacrice peace,thatrsquos what it takes to achieve Brexit. Imagine how it would seek to punish Scotlandit tried to leave the union.When will Scots be ready to even contemplate another political upheaval  It wonrsquot be any time soon,you ask me, and certainly not until we believe there are sensible alternatives on the ballot paper.Marianne Taylor: Brexit reveals Germanys unrequited love for UKIrsquom not saying Scotland shouldnrsquot or wonrsquot be able to choose a dferent future for itself. I believe emphatically that we should get that opportunity, and look forward to it. When, however, depends on so many complex things, none of which are in the gt of Nicola Sturgeon and her party.And thatrsquos exactly why Mr Robertsonrsquos think tank is a positive development, just when we need one so desperately. He is right to point out that Scots need more than hope - we need cogent and pragmatic solutions to very dficult questions.At least Mr Robertson is trying to provide them his opponents, after all, have nothing to offer.

title: bid-to-freeze-out-plague-of-clothes-moths-eating-300-years-of-history
story: But a plague of moths is threatening to harm the historic collection at Newhailes House, near Musselburgh, East Lothian, and conservation charity the National Trust for Scotlandis this week embarking on its biggest ever management programme to rid the property of the insatiable insects.The webbing clothes moths are notorious for feeding on clothing and natural fibres, with the ability to turn keratin ndash a protein of which hair and wool mainly consist of ndash into their food.They are serious pests, particularly keen on carpeting and clothing and, unlike other moths, seem to prefer dark and dim areas.The winged creatures are also known to favour handmade rugs because itrsquos easier for the larvae to crawl underneath and do their damage all of which poses challenging problems for Newhailes, situated in  hectares of th century designed landscape.NTS experts are now to combine a deep clean with a deep freeze, installing two industrial freezers ndash each the size of shipping crates ndash at the property.Over the next two months, the entire textile collection ndash from carpets and curtains to sofas, chairs and clothing ndash will undergo a sub-zero treatment to freeze and destroy the moth eggs and larvae.Items will be wrapped in acid-free tissue paper, then covered in polythene, before being placed in the freezers where temperatures will drop to -degC .Staff will then use specialist back-mounted vacuum cleaners to reach into every nook and crannie of the house to clean away the moths.Owned by NTS, Newhailes House was once home to the influential Dalrymple family, who gave the property its revered library, rococo interiors and admired collections of paintings, ceramics and furniture. The home has strong links to the ldquoScottish Enlightenment, as the Dalrymples were patrons, providing support to scholars who were drawn to the Housersquos library, including philosopher and economist Adam Smith.Highlights include the magnicent dining room, impressive Italian marble fireplaces and th-century trompe lrsquooeil decoration in the Chinese sitting room.But in , staff noticed a sharp rise in the ldquowebbing clothes moth ndash or common clothes moth ndash and have been endeavouring to manage the problem with localised treatment and targeted deep cleaning ever since.However, moth numbers ndash and damage ndash have continued and the organisation is implementing the freeze programme to protect the Newhailes collection.The charity has used freezers to destroy moths at other properties in the past, but on a small scale using chest-sized freezers.The two, ft long freezers that are being deployed at Newhailes represent the organisationrsquos biggest ever attempt to keep moth numbers down.Mel Houston, national preventive conservator at the NTS, said: ldquoThis is the biggest project that the National Trust for Scotland has ever undertaken to tackle a pest problem like this and protect the important collections here at Newhailes.ldquoIn the last year moth numbers at Newhailes have exploded and wersquove seen a four-fold increase in how many wersquore finding.ldquoWersquore lucky to have been able to catch the problem at just the right time, when wersquore able to do something to control the moths before really serious damage is done.ldquoThe deep freeze and deep clean gives us the confidence wersquore killing off as many moths as we can. Wersquoll never get rid of them completely but wersquoll be able to get down to the level where they can be controlled.A team of mothbusting volunteers has now been recruited to work with the Trustrsquos collection and conservation team to undertake the low temperature treatment, deep cleaning of the historic interior and collection movements.During the project, the NTS will also be running tours so the public can learn about the damage the insects have caused and see the moth management programme in action.A spokeswoman said: ldquoThe Moth Project offers visitors a unique opportunity to view the house in a dferent context and understand the conservation work undertaken to preserve the historic collection and interior.ldquoA team of volunteers will be working with our collection and conservation team to undertake the collectionrsquos low temperature treatment, deep cleaning of the historic interior, and collection movements.ldquoOn these public tours you will be able to see the work progress in the House, meet our staff and volunteers, and learn about collections care and integrated pest management.Public tours will run this Wednesday and also on February ,  and  and March  and . More information at: www.nts.org.uk visit events conservation-tour-moth-project

title: word-of-mouth-passes-on-history-of-dunfermline-missed-by-netflix
story: However, beyond its links with Robert the Bruce and Andrew Carnegie itrsquos feared much of Dunfermlinersquos rich history, industrial heritage and cultural legacy have been lost in the mists of time.Perhaps worse, in what would appear to be remarkable examples of civic indference to their value, at least two of its most precious treasures ndash including a rare Neolithic standing stone ndash ended up almost swamped by modern development.Now, however, the Auld Grey Toon is preparing to exploit the attention on it due to the Netflix movie of Brucersquos le, The Outlaw King, and encourage local people to act as ldquotour guides by sharing stories of the figures ndash from royals to rockstars ndash and events that have shaped the town down through the centuries.The move is part of a new three-year heritage project aimed at connecting the townrsquos past with the present, and ensuring its rich history and vibrant cultural heritage aids economic regeneration and delivers a string of educational, social and environmental benefits.Dunfermline is one of nine Scottish towns to receive Heritage Lottery Great Places funding, designed to revive interest and focus attention on their historic, industrial and cultural achievements.The initial phase of the pound, Dunfermline project involved a historical audit of the area and its findings have now been distributed through a range of schemes designed to spark interest among local people and to encourage them to share their knowledge of their townrsquos background.The audit shone a spotlight on the le of St Margaret, the th-century Queen of Scots canonised for her faith and charitable works ndash and whose cave where she went for contemplation was almost lost to a car park.It also highlighted witch trials as well as the townrsquos lesser-known built heritage, including Victorian prison cells inside its city chambers and a perfectly preserved ldquohidden gem ndash a s bathroom built in a grand townhouse for a visit from then prime minister Ramsay MacDonald, and now part of Fe Cultural Trustrsquos offices.Project manager Grant Williams said: ldquoThe Outlaw King is helping to put the Robert the Bruce story on the international stage but there are many other highlights.ldquoNo one is a better advocate for a place than the people who live here. Many already know that Dunfermline has good story to tell when it comes to history. Our job has been to collect the best stories so that itrsquos easier for local residents to tell their friends, family and visitors.ldquoAs well as attracting more visitors and generating income for the local economy we hope that it builds local pride in the exceptional history of this town.Dunfermline was the birthplace of philanthropist and steel magnate Andrew Carnegie, who went on to establish public libraries in towns across the country. Much further back it was the burial site for Scotlandrsquos monarchs, while its more modern cultural heritage spans folk musician Barbara Dickson, The Skids and Stuart Adamsonrsquos Big Country.According to consultant David Hicks, who carried out the history audit, Dunfermline has a clutch of hidden treasures that have fallen off the typical tourist and localsrsquo radar.They include a Neolithic standing stone which is almost hidden by homes in the townrsquos s Pitcorthie housing estate.The .m sandstone block ndash listed as a national monument ndash was surrounded by granite setts in the s and seen as a compromise to the site. Another is St Margaretrsquos Cave, a deep gorge which was the scene for the Scottish queenrsquos private devotions and which at one point was under threat of being lost to a car park development.ldquoIn the s the local council decided it would be the perfect place to build a car park but locals made an enormous fuss, says Hicks. ldquoA compromise was made so the council still got the car park but built a tunnel to allow access to the caves.ldquoSt Margaretrsquos Stone, which is said to have been where the queen rested after coming across the ferry from Edinburgh, now marks the entrance to a business park.The audit has been split into six themes to create a guide which is being distributed around the town in the hope that it will help locals and hotel, shop and restaurant staff share Dunfermlinersquos heritage with visitors, while a new website is being developed to tell the townrsquos story.Plans include a series of cultural activities including a heritage festival.Mr Williams added: ldquoFor tourists and visitors, therersquos no more powerful recommendation than word of mouth by locals.ldquoAs well as attracting more visitors and generating income for the local economy we hope that it builds local pride in the exceptional history of this town.

title: javid-rules-out-dday-election
story: Sajid Javid, the Home Secretary, was responding to reports that Tory HQ had put the party on a war footing for a summer election.Suggestions were made over the weekend that Conservative strategists had block-booked printing plants and tripled the partyrsquos digital advertising revenue under cover of the spring local elections with a view to Theresa May going to the country on June  ndash the th anniversary of the D-Day landings during the Second World War.A poll by Opinium also put the Conservatives seven points ahead of Labour on  per cent. However, in spring , Mrs Mayrsquos party was more than  points ahead of Jeremy Corbynrsquos Labour and went on to lose its Commons majority, which has led to the Prime Minister struggling to push through her desired Brexit package.It was also suggested Sir Mark Sedwill, the Cabinet Secretary, had been contacting permanent secretaries at Whitehall departments, telling them to prepare for a June election.However, when confronted with the prospect of a summer election, Mr Javid insisted Tory HQ was planning for only one set of elections this year ndash the local council ones in May.ldquoThe last thing this country needs is a general election, declared the Home Secretary. ldquoThe people will never forgive us for it."What they want is this parliament to deliver Brexit in an orderly way thatrsquos what theyrsquore looking for.He told the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr Show: ldquoThey want politicians just to get on with the job.Another Government minister suggested talking up an early election was down to ldquosecond-rate staff desperate to keep their jobs, while an ally of Mrs May branded the suggestion ldquoutter madness.Previously, the PM made it clear she would not lead the party into another general election in exchange for Conservative MPs supporting her in Decembers confidence vote.Meanwhile, a No  spokesman made clear there were no plans for a snap general election.

title: wreckage-found-in-search-for-sala-plane
story: Argentinian striker Mr Sala, , and -year-old pilot David Ibbotson were on board the Piper Malibu light aircraft when it disappeared over the Channel on January  after leaving Nantes, in France, for Cardf.An official search operation was called off on January  after Guernseys harbour master, Captain David Barker, said the chances of survival following such a long period were "extremely remote".But a privately-funded search off Guernsey, directed by marine scientist David Mearns on behalf of the Sala family, resumed this morning.A separate search was being carried out by the Air Accident Investigation Branch .Mr Mearns said wreckage from the plane was located by his crew early this morning.He added: "The families of Emiliano Sala and David Ibbotson have been notied by police."Tonight our sole thoughts are with the families and friends of Emiliano and David."A request had been made for the plane to descend before contact with Jersey air traffic control was lost.Mr Sala was signed by English Premier League outfit Cardf City from Nantes for a club record fee of poundmillion during the January transfer window.Fans paid tribute to both Mr Sala and Mr Ibbotson ahead of Cardfs home match with Bournemouth yesterday.

title: bins to be collected once every three weeks in new council strategy
story: Aberdeenshire residents will be encouraged to become recycling champions with the introduction of a controversial three-weekly collection programme.The revised waste strategy for all , properties in the Shire was approved in a - vote by the council’s Infrastructure Services Committee despite an alternative option from Peterhead SNP councillor Stephen Smith who said it was “too much, too soon”.From April next year, households will have weekly kerbside collections for one of three bins including a  litre bin for paper and card and  litre bin for metals, plastics and cartons.However under the new scheme, the existing general residual bin for non-recyclable waste will be signicantly reduced to a  litre capacity.Councillors were told by waste director Philip McKay that while it was a considerable reduction, the service felt it “should be manageable for most households”.He added that while a three-weekly non-recyclable waste collection might feel a bit daunting to residents initially – as did the move from weekly to fortnightly collections in Aberdeenshire a few years ago – experience from other Scottish local authorities showed that it is workable and can lead to a signicant increase in recycling rates.Mr McKay also stressed that given the larger recycling capacity provided in the favoured option, it provided “more flexibility in the future” for the addition of other recyclable materials without the need for additional recycling containers.Councillors were told that the scheme had the potential to save waste services £, per year at the lower end of the scale and even morethere was a higher uptake in recycling.However, Peterhead councillor Stephen Smith said the proposals as they stood were a step too far for North-east communities.In a bid to address concerns about the potential impact of any necessary changes to the waste strategy, he proposed that instead of using a -litre bin for three weekly collections, Aberdeenshire Council instead do what has happened in much of the rest of Scotland and keep the  litre bin for three weekly waste collections, with new  litre bins – which are expected to be funded in large part by ‘Zero Waste Scotland’ – being used for paper and card recycling for a transitional period.Councillor Smith’s proposal – which he claimed would have saved an estimated £, annually – followed confirmation from council officers that such a proposal would be compatible with Zero Waste Scotland’s requirements for helping to fund the cost of the new bins required.But council depute leader Peter Argyle warned against “changing horses” halfway through the programme as it would only lead to confusion.He told the committee that with an imminent landfill ban on biodegradable waste “coming down the tracks” by , it was title: entertainers mark ten years of business
story: Ellon-based company Lisa Lollipop Entertainers is celebrating ten years of business.Lisa Lollipop provides entertainment for children at private parties, nursery schools, hospital and corporate events across the north east.Private parties currently represent the core market for the Lollipop Entertainers business.These parties are held in community centres, sports halls and customers’ homes.The Lollipop team have visited almost every village hall and community centre across Aberdeenshire.They’ve also been welcomed into many families’ homes to celebrate special moments in their lives from celebrating baby’s first birthday, right through to pre-teen and then continuing to mark special family fun birthdays and events.The business has developed over the years and can now entertain party sizes in excess of  children.Party games, face painting, balloon modelling, baby parties, soft play, pre-teen discos and superhero princess characters are offered.Lisa Lollipop employees take on the appearance and persona of the fairy-tale ‘Lollipop’ character and superhero princess characters.Since the business started up in , the Lisa Lollipop character has gained a strong following and achieved high brand recognition.Lisa Lollipop has active social media pages, ‘How to’ balloon modelling films on YouTube, an active newsletter and has entertained at over , parties equating to over , local children having met Lisa Lollipop.Lisa Mann, owner of Lisa Lollipop Entertainers said: “I couldn’t have asked for a more exciting and creative way to spend my time, everyday doing something I have loved from the moment I started, ten years ago.“I certainly didn’t think I would be fortunate enough to have continued with my dream job for this long.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: kintore flats plans raise objections
story: Councillors will next week debate proposals for  new affordable flats in the heart of Kintore which have attracted a host of objections.Langstane Housing Association has tabled plans for four property blocks featuring  one-bed flats and six two-bed flats on vacant waste ground on Forest Road.But  objections have been raised on the grounds of insufficient parking and road safety, increased traffic and congestion on Forest Road and the scale of the development and the adverse impact on the amenity.In a report to Aberdeenshire Council’s Garioch Area Committee which meets on Tuesday, director of infrastructure services Stephen Archer says that “on balance” while the development may have an amenity impact on the neighbouring properties, it will fall within acceptable standards.He says: “The proposal for  affordable flats would make a positive contribution to affordable housing provision in Kintore.“It is accepted that any development on this site will alter the outlook from neighbouring dwellings, however, the use of the site for a flatted development is considered compatible with the infill nature of the site and settlement location.”Councillors will be told that the pre-application consultations and discussions during the determination of the application to reduce the potential impact on the neighbouring properties has resulted in the final layout and design.But in its objection, Kintore Community Council slams the proposal, particularly in terms of inadequate parking spaces.Chair Fiona Cooper states: “The proposed parking for the development of  spaces for  residents is insufficient and would result in overspill parking on the oppositie side of the road which would obviously have a major affect on existing residents.”In terms of the scale of the development, the community council recommends a maximum of two-storeys, with Mrs Cooper adding: “The proposed development by reason of size is out of character and would have an unacceptably adverse impact on the amenities of the properties immediately opposite the site and the surrounding area by reason of overlooking and having a visually overbearing impact.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk title: playgroup donates nativity cash to charity
story: A north east charity has received a welcome cash boost from an Inverurie playgroup.St Andrew’s Church Playgroup held a Nativity show just before Christmas and the event raised more than £.Through kind donations from parents, grandparents and other family members, as well as cash from raffle sales and refreshments, a total of £, was raised.The playgroup decided to donate the money to Spikin Autism and More , a parent peer support group for families or carers that have children with autism or other disabilities.The group provides a welcoming, relaxed environment for parents to not only share experiences, resources and information to help their children, but also to reduce their own feelings of ‘being alone’ and to provide one another with some much needed supportRepresentatives from the charity visited the playgroup on Friday, January  to accept the donation.Speaking to the Herald, Lisa Moir of SAAM said: “The money will go towards organising training sessions that will provide help on topics including dyslexia, speech and language.“We previously receviedfunding from the Garioch Partnership so we will add this money to that.“We want to help give more people the opportunity to have access to help with childcare issues.“The training sessions are open to everyone and we hope to have day and evening workshops.”Spikin Autism and More is based in Alford but started Peer Support Sessions at Homestart Garioch just over a year ago.Lisa created the group following the death of her husband.She added: “After he died I found it quite isolating finding support to raise our son who was three at the time and diagnosed with autism.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: thainstone goes electric
story: ANM Group has installed electric vehicle charging facilities at Thainstone Centre as part of its green strategy and wide-ranging customer service offering.Charging an electric vehicle at the site will be free to all users for the next  months.ANM Group received funding from Transport Scotland, through a programme managed by the Energy Saving Trust private organisations can apply for grant support to install a publicly-available charging points through Transport Scotland’s ChargePlace Scotland project.Home-owners who own or use an electric or plug-in car can also apply for grant support towards the installation of a home charging unit.Grant Rogerson, Chief Executive at ANM Group, said: “We are pleased to partner with Transport Scotland by installing four electric vehicle charge points at Thainstone. “The centre is located just off the A and is a natural choice for the charging points, with a large car park and an award-winning restaurant on site, it has all the necessary amenities for drivers and passengers.“The charge points have the capability of charging up to eight vehicles at one time, and will certainly benefit the local community and those travelling.“The project is in line with our green strategy and supports our business objective of increasing our services to our members, customers and the local community.“We look forward to welcoming all visitors and invite them to see what our centre has to offer.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brian McKandie"  Murder trial jury to consider verdict viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: travelling after brexit how it impacts data roaming and driving abroad
story: It could be you have concerns aboutyour flight will still take off or what you need to doyou are driving in Europe.Travel company First Choice and ABTA, the leading association of travel agents and tour operators, have released details in a bid to help travellers.Will flights still go evena deal isnrsquot reached First Choice said: ldquoWe know that flights taking off in the UK will still be permitted to fly within the European Unionrsquos airspace, even it a deal isnrsquot reached - thatrsquos been confirmed by the European Commission.ldquoEvenwe have a no-deal Brexit, flights between the UK and the EU will still take place as normal. Even when a deal is decided, nothing will happen overnight - wersquoll go into a period of transition for two years up until late .Read more: What will Brexit mean for you and your family  What aboutIm driving while on holiday For those that choose to drive abroad ABTA says that those with a full UK driving licence may need to apply for a relevant International Driving Permit.These cost £. and are available directly from the Post Office - the RAC and AA will not be issuing them from February .There are two IDPs depending on which country you are visiting - drivers travelling between dferent countriesmay need both types.ABTA said: ldquoThe Government is working to extend the network of Post Offices where you can apply for an International Driving Permit, and has plans to roll these out in more branches across the UK from  February .ldquoCheck carefully which permit is required for each country you intend to drive within, as you may need more than one permit to comply with the law.You may also need a green card. Find out more here: Motorists will need a green card to drive their own vehicle in EUdata-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Brimmond Team welcoming Kirsty Walker from Charlie House to their Kintore offices to launch the companys support of Charlie House charity"  Elecricity HPU to raise funds for charityviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Drivers will need a green card to prove they are insured in the EU in the case of a no deal Brexit"  Motorists will need green card to drive in EUtheres a no-deal Brexit viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Any other areas of concern Another area that could be impacted on is data roaming.Under EU rules the cost of making calls, sending messages or using the internet on your phone in the EU is the same in the UK.ABTA said: ldquoIf the UK leaves without a deal these rules will no longer apply - however, some UK companies have said they may continue to offer this benefit to their customers. title: Caithness Moray link is completed
story: THE Caithness-Moray electricity transmission link will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come, the man who led the project has said.Dave Gardner, director of transmission for Scottish and Southern Electricity NetworksTransmission, was speaking after it was announced that the construction, commissioning and energisation of the link had been completed at a cost of around pound million.He hailed it as a signicant achievement for SSEN and everyone involved."Caithness-Moray has been a highly complex project, requiring very high standards of project design, development, construction and commissioning," Mr Gardner said. "It has been delivered by a team of committed and skilled people, working closely with contractors and other stakeholders."It will support deployment of renewable energy in the north of Scotland for many years to come."Now an operational asset, we will closely monitor the link and associated infrastructure to ensure its continued success as an integral part of the GB transmission system."We would like to thank all those who contributed to the success of the project, from our own teams of engineers and support staff, our supply chain and the local communities who have played host to our project teams over recent years."Caithness-Moray is the largest single investment ever undertaken by the SSE Group and is described as the most signicant investment in the north of Scotland electricity transmission system since the s.The link uses HVDCtechnology to transmit power through a km subsea cable beneath the Moray Firth seabed between new converter stations at Spittaland Blackhillock . Constructed over a period of four years, the project also involved work at eight electricity substation sites.Completed on time and within the allowance approved by the regulator Ofgem, the Caithness-Moray link provides up to MW of capacity to transmit power from the increasing sources of renewable energy from across the far north.The link has already enabled turbines from Beatrice offshore wind farmand Dorenell onshore wind farmto connect to the national grid with a further MW of onshore generation in Caithness and Ross-shire due to connect in the coming months.The completion of the link and other electricity transmission projects is expected to help take the Regulatory Asset Valueof SSEN Transmission to around pound. billion at March , .Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Did aliens visit Wick
story: While millions of people around the country were cheering on the fireworks that brought in the new year, a Wick man and his family say they were witnessing a light show they never expected.Charlie Williamsonsays he had just popped out the back door of his house at Leishman Avenue after the bells sounded at midnight, only to spot a strange light overhead.He beckoned his we Tanya and their three children onto the doorstep from where he says they observed the strange object with flashing lights that ldquohovered in one place for over three hours.Speaking to the Courier, he says he wasnrsquot the only one to witness the eerie phenomenon.ldquoA local woman and some people south of the town also witnessed the strange sight.After Charlie posted a video of his sighting online, media ndash including the Scottish Sun ndash ran stories on his UFO experience.Many readers, however, wrote off the object as merely a drone.Charlie says he is ldquo per cent sure that is not the case.ldquoIt was way too big, he says. ldquoI donrsquot know much about drones other than the size of them but a few people have messaged me saying they wonrsquot fly for a solid three hours. It was windy that night too and a lot of people who fly drones have told me it wouldrsquove been too windy that night to fly one.Keith Banks, an amateur meteorologist who writes a monthly weather column for the John OrsquoGroat Journal, says mphgusts were blowing during the period the UFO was witnessed.ldquoIn my view the very blustery conditions would have effectively precluded a drone from flying, he said.Dedicated drone flyers agree, including Barry Scollay from Wick who says he has been flying the unmanned aerial vehicles for a decade.ldquoNo way a drone would have flown in those winds ndash thatrsquos a certain fact, said Mr Scollay, who has a Facebook page called Highland Aerial Views which has over , followersldquoIt would have to have been able to maintain its location in high winds. Irsquove flown very large drones in mph wind but that was the limit, he says.ldquoYou can [even] hear the wind howling in his video.Whatrsquos more, he says that software in operation at the nearby Wick airport would not allow such a drone to take off.Small hobby drones ldquocanrsquot fly within the airportrsquos no-fly zone.Charlie reckons the UFO was about ft above his head, larger than a car and made no sound.Although he took photos and video on his smartphone he admits that the quality was not the best.ldquoIt was like seeing a car at the bottom of your street, it was that clear. Itrsquos just not as clear with the phone.The object disappeared not long after a police van appeared at around am.ldquoI couldnrsquot get to sleep and kept going to the window and the door to see it but it was gone, he says.Since posting the video online he has had numerous calls from self-professed ldquoUFO investigators.Therersquos been so many of them, he says hersquos now ldquovery waryof callers who ask ldquotoo many questions.ldquoItrsquos like being interviewed by the FBI, he said. ldquoVery weird and over the top with the secrecy.Since his sighting, an organisation called the British Earth and Aerial Mysteries Societyhas said it believes he saw an ldquointerdimensional plasma craft.The craft have also been suggested as a cause for recent disruptions at Gatwick and Heathrow airports.A spokesperson for Wick John OrsquoGroats Airport confirmed that it was closed during the period the object was sighted, and there are also no reports of the emergency services operating in the air at that time.Charliersquos video can be seen at https:youtu.be xdHBiqtkWhat do you think he saw  Email d.scott@nosnwith your suggestions.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Upgrade should just be the start
story: THE pound. million upgrade of the north section of the Berriedale Braes should be the trigger to improve the rest of that part of the A, according to Caithness councillor Raymond Bremner.He made the plea after Transport Scotland confirmed the contract to upgrade the notorious north hairpin bend has been awarded to Dingwall-based engineering company R J McLeod Ltd. Work is due to start this year, be completed by spring  and create  jobs during the construction phase.Councillor Bremner, who represents Wick and East Caithness on Highland Council, said: "While Im keen to see an improvement to the north brae, I still believe we cant take our focus off the south brae. We have two major long-term concerns to focus on here ndash the gradient of the brae and the fact that we are still witnessing serious accidents on the bottom hairpin bend even where there is an escape bed."These accidents are a risk to le, causing road closures and impacting in all sorts of ways on our local community and economy. Improvements to the north brae are very welcome and I hope that it is the start of a bigger vision to improve the entire Berriedale Braes."We can expect the standard lead-in period of about three months and for discussions to be held with the contractor on how they propose to physically approach the works and discussions with statutory bodies like the Scottish Environment Protection Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds among others."He said that archaeological investigatory works have been completed.The award of the contract was also welcomed by Trudy Morris, chief executive of Caithness Chamber of Commerce.She said: "We are delighted to see that after many years of dedicated campaigning by the chamber, Caithness Transport Forum and other local organisations, this project is finally moving ahead. For too long, the Berriedale Braes has acted as a pinch point for travellers on the A north of Inverness, disrupting business and jeopardising investment in the region."It has been good to see other work on A improvements and repairs going to local companies in recent years, and we hope the principal contractor will engage closely with our highly skilled local supply chain as these works progress."Ms Morris added: "Now that the contract has been formally awarded, we hope to see clarication on exact start dates and expectedof works very soon. We would urge the Scottish Government to uphold its previous promise to start works within this financial year so that the north Highlands can start to see the benefit of this upgrade as soon as possible."A Transport Scotland spokesman said: "R J McLeod Ltd has been awarded the construction contract as part of the pound. million project to deliver improvements to the road alignment and the existing tight hairpin bend on the A."Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, hailed it as a positive development for the area. "It will enhance the skills development of the Scottish construction industry, with approximately  jobs expected to be supported in the region during construction."Related articles:Four in running for Berriedale Braes contractSilence on A schemeMonday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: airports chairwoman is appointed
story: IT HAS been announced by Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity, Michael Matheson MSP, that Lorna Jack had been appointed as chairwoman of the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited , operators of several airports, including Kirkwall Airport.Ms Jack is a chartered accountant and a graduate of Aberdeen University. She joined the Board of Highlands and Islands Airports Limited as a non-executive director in March  and chaired its Audit Committee for over three years, until she was invited to take on the interim chair role in October .Ms Jack remains the chief executive of the Law Society of Scotland and is an independent member of the Court of University of Aberdeen and a member of its Governance and Nominations Committee. She is also a trustee and treasurer of the McConnell International Foundation.The appointment is regulated by the Commissioner for Ethical Standards in Public Le in Scotland.• Highlands and Islands Airports Limitedis a public body wholly owned by Scottish Ministers. title: christmas tree collection reminder
story: Orkney Islands Council is reminding folk that their Christmas tree collection service for households on the Orkney mainland, within mph areas only, will get underway from Monday next week.The limited collection for real trees will be carried between Monday and the following Friday, February .The intention is that trees collected will be recycled at the council’s Bossack waste facility, along with other garden waste left at recycling centres around Orkney, to produce a fine soil conditioner.Therefore anyone using the tree collection service is urged to take extra care that all tinsel and decorations are removed from their trees.The soil conditioner can be picked up free of charge, subject to availability, from the Council’s Household Waste and Recycling Centres at Bossack in Tankerness, and Hatston, in Kirkwall.Collections fall on normal refuse recycling collection days and will take place as follows:Area  — Kirkwall : Monday February Area  — East Holm, Deerness, pickup.Householders outwith the mph limits can visit their local Household Waste Recycling Centres at Hatston, Garson, Bossack, Cursiter Quarry, St Margaret’s Hope and Dounby during normal opening title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. title: featured property of the week 5
story: Offers over £,ADVERTORIAL: Westermill is an eye-catching period property located close to the centre of Kirkwall. The property is detached and comprises a large entrance hallway,  spacious bedrooms, one with ensuite, living room, dining room, kitchen, shower room, utility room and downstairs toilet. The property benefits from a large enclosed mature garden to the rear of the property and there are also a driveway and shed to the side of the house.The property has oil-fired central heating, together with a fireplace in the dining room and a Morso stove in the sitting room. There are also fireplaces in two of the bedrooms. Many of the original features have been retained in the property. Viewing is highly recommended to appreciate the true character of Westermill.The property is ideally located on a quiet road close to both the Papdale Primary and Kirkwall Grammar School and it is only a few minutes walk down to the centre of town. To the front of the property is the picturesque Willowburn, as well as additional parking.The living room has a hardwood floor, picture rail and cornice, as does the dining room. There is an archway leading from the dining room to the modern fitted kitchen with  ring hob, double oven, cooker hood, fridge and dishwasher.The ground floor also houses the utility room with plumbing for a washing machine and space for tumble dryer and fridge  freezer. There is a small toilet off the utility room. One of the bedrooms is situated on the ground floor, but could be used as a living room or office space.In the centre of the property is a beautul staircase leading up to a large stained glass feature window and then on to the landing. Off the landing there are a further three double bedrooms, one of which has an en-suite shower room. The main shower room is also located on the first floor of the property.There is a large loft space which is partially floored and could potentially be converted into a further one or two rooms, with ample space on the landing for a staircase.There is a walled garden to the front of the property, bordered with bushes and shrubs. The large rear garden has mature trees and bushes, making the garden area extremely sheltered and private. There is also a patio area and garden shed.Viewing is highly recommended to fully appreciate all that this property has to offer.The Home Report is available by email on request.For further information and to arrange a viewing, please contact Kerry Croy Tel:  . title: survey project sheds new light on hms royal oak
story: A VOLUNTEER e team has been granted permission to extensively survey the official wargrave of HMS Royal Oak in Scapa Flow.New D photogrammetry techniques are being used and still photography and videography will allow the team to capture and share the spirit of the site.In the early hours of October , , U’s commander Günther Prien guided her silently into Scapa Flow, and launched a torpedo attack, In just a few minutes, Royal Oak was gone.  sailors perished, including over  boy seamen.Ahead of the th anniversary of her loss later this year, a team of volunteer civilian ers has been granted permission to e the wreck by the secretary of state for defence.This is part of a collaboration with the Royal Oak Association and the Royal Navy to document the last resting place of the men who lost their lives, so their passing can be remembered and preserved for future generations.The project aims to ensure that HMS Royal Oak is not forgotten, by sharing imagery with relatives of those lost, as well as the wider public.The survey team is using state-of-the-art underwater imagery techniques, in order to produce high-quality photography and video. In addition, D photogrammetry is taking place so that digital D models of the wreck can be produced. By using these techniques, in essence, the team is able to digitally bring HMS Royal Oak to the surface.Survey organiser and licence-holder Emily Turton said: “The wreck of HMS Royal Oak is the final resting place of  men and boys. As the most intact underwater dreadnought-era battleship, she has an architectural grandeur befitting of any national memorial. However, at the smaller end of the scale, artefacts pertaining to everyday le on board are scattered around the site, bringing home the human story of those lost. The site is peaceful, yet vibrant, and supports a thriving marine eco-system. It is both an honour and a privilege to get to know the site.”Full details and further pictures in The Orcadian this week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: update kirkwall town centre roadworks
story: newsUPDATE: Kirkwall town centre roadworksFebruary ,  at : am vw, px"  Work is set to continue next week on street improvements in Kirkwall#s town centre.There will be further repaving on the area around the TSB bank, on the junction between Castle Street and Broad Street, with a one-way system remaining in place.Orkney Islands Council has said once this initial stage is completed, work will then move to the entrance to Albert Street, meaning the street will be closed to traffic from Laing Street. It#s anticipated this work will start on February  and could take four weeks to complete.The current one-way system means drivers can turn into Castle Street from Junction Road and on into Broad Street but vehicles do not have access from Palace Road into Broad Street.A signed ersion via Clay Loan is in place. In addition, vehicles cannot turn into Castle Street from Albert Street – but can drive on into Broad Street.The works are part of the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiative’sPlaces and Spaces project, which will see improvements to the area at the bottom of the Strynd, the creation of a new path to the War Memorial at St Magnus and improvements at the head of Victoria Street.The council has said the works at the top of Castle Street will see new paving and road surfacing laid, and the road surface raised to pavement level. This initial phase of the project is due for completion early May after which works will be suspended for the main summer season.Work at the entrance to Victoria Street is set to begin in the autumn, with a suspension planned, in December for Christmas shopping season.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
